DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE SIR ROBERT ASKIN, G.C.M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death yesterday of the Honourable Sir Robert Askin, G.C.M.G., former Premier of the State of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make some very brief remarks purely because I had a close personal relationship with Sir Robert Askin over some 30 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Robert Askin and his career have been widely described in the media today and are known to all. Basically, I direct my attention to the real matter of concern at a time of such a death. We tend to look at and dwell upon those who have achieved some distinction and greatness in life and overlook the fact that we should turn to those who remain, those who mourn.

SPEECH.PARA: I specifically want to express our deep sadness to Lady Askin, a woman of rare qualities. Mollie Askin was married to Sir Robert for some 41 years. She, in her own way, earned distinction in her local community. Nobody could have been a more loyal and devoted wife to him. Nobody could earn more respect and, indeed, affection from those who came in contact with her. Therefore, I think it is appropriate, particularly as the last few weeks and months have demanded great strength, courage and dedication from her, that we should send to her a very special message.

We acknowledge that in Sir Robert Askin we had in New South Wales a Premier of record breaking qualities. We acknowledge the man himself, who rose from humble beginnings to achieve the highest position in his own State. There are many qualities that one could attribute to him. I, having been privileged to walk alongside him over that journey from his first pre-selection to his retirement in 1975, pay tribute to the man himself. It is a story of a man from humble beginnings who achieved very great distinction, and that has been recognised. On behalf of all senators, and of course personally, I convey to Mollie Askin our sharing of her sense of loss and our sadness at his passing.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite all honourable senators to stand in silence as a mark of respect to the memory of the late Sir Robert Askin.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators having stood in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GILES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 147 citizens of Australia:

That the decision of the Government to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme from October 31, 1981, will deny unemployed youth the significant skills and support that the Scheme provided. This will result in greater hardship and alienation of these young people from society.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reconsider the closure of the Community Youth Support Scheme and continue its funding in recognition of its significant contribution to the welfare of unemployed youth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

(a) the abolition of funds to the CYSS is a discriminatory imposition on the young unemployed of this country.

(2) depriving already deprived youth of any chance of learning skills

PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that ALL Australians SHARE THE WEALTH of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing, therefore your petitioners urge that:-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is it a fact that the former Minister for Industrial Relations yesterday strongly criticised the means adopted in the 1981 Budget to achieve the Government's economic aims? Did he say that families have been hit with higher taxes and charges, small businesses hit and State governments squeezed, while Commonwealth spending has continued to increase? I ask the Minister whether, in her opinion, those criticisms are justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did not have time to read the precise remarks of the former Minister for Industrial Relations in his speech on the Budget, but I did see some headlines covering perhaps some of the items mentioned by Senator Button. Perhaps it would be advisable for me to read the speech of the former Minister before making any comment on it. However, I can say that the structure of the Budget was designed to assist families, indeed all Australians, to give them the opportunity to have as low a rate of inflation as is possible, to have as wide employment opportunities as are possible and to continue the development of this country in a way that will give those advantages to all Australians. If the former Minister has other views, he may express them. The strategy of the Budget as outlined by the Treasurer on Budget night was to achieve the very reverse of some of the things that were mentioned in the question by Senator Button.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to air navigation regulation 249, which restricts the distance from land for flights over water. Is the Minister aware that there are several sea planes, float planes and amphibians operating in the Queensland tourist industry, especially in the Great Barrier Reef area, but that the distances to various outer reefs and sections of the Great Barrier Reef itself are in excess of the stated water distance? Will the Minister consider altering the air navigation regulations to exempt these categories of aircraft from these restrictions and thus provide added and needed facilities for Queensland tourists?

—Yes, I am aware that these limitations have applied. The 50-nautical-mile limitation is a stated safety requirement related to the period of exposure to the risk of engine failure in a single-engine aircraft. Clearly there are a great many parts of the Great Barrier Reef which might provide suitable protected alighting areas for this type of aircraft but which involve flights in excess of 50 miles. The responsibility for aviation safety regulation lies with the Secretary to the Department of Transport. There is the power under air navigation regulation 249 to vary its conditions and limitations. Any submission should therefore be made to the Secretary to the Department. I am happy to facilitate that if Senator Collard has an individual matter which he would like to put to the Department.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. By way of preface, I refer to yesterday's declaration by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that greater attention should be paid by all governments, particularly this Government, to industrial safety. I remind the Senate that, during the last session, Senator Peter Baume said that an interdepartmental committee was determining whether industrial safety in the Commonwealth sphere would be the responsibility of the Minister for Science and Technology or the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister whether any decision has been made. I would imagine that the Minister for Industrial Relations should be the one to look after industrial safety.

—I do have some information on the matter which has been raised by the honourable senator. A review is currently being undertaken by the Public Service Board of the human relations and working environment functions, which are to be scaled down, with any residual functions being transferred from the Department of Science and Technology to the Department of Industrial Relations. The review by the Public Service Board has not yet been completed. The functions concerning industrial safety remain, for the time being, responsibilities of the Department of Science and Technology. This is an area in which, as the honourable senator from New South Wales would be aware, the primary responsibility lies with State departments and the supervision of conditions and so on directly relating to industrial safety rests with State departments. A relatively small Commonwealth function is involved here. It is under review and that review has not yet been completed.

—I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister of the fateful words of Senator Peter Baume at an Estimates committee hearing last session in answer to my question regarding how long the review would take. Senator Peter Baume gave the impression that it would take only a couple of months. I remind the Government that that occurred in April and it is now September. It seems to me that the Government is moving very slowly on a vital issue.

—The further words of Senator Mulvihill in that question will be directed to the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations. Sometimes these matters do take longer in review than was originally anticipated. I accept that this is an area of importance. I qualify that only by reminding the honourable senator of what I said a few moments ago; that is, that it is an area in which the principal operating responsibility lies not with the Commonwealth but with State departments.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ISOLATED PATIENTS TRAVEL AND ACCOMMODATION SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to the Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Scheme, which has done a great deal towards improving the quality of life of people living in remote areas of Australia. People with modest means are experiencing difficulty in meeting the cost of plane tickets even though most of the cost is subsequently refunded to them. This applies particularly to patients who have to travel long distances or who need regular treatment. Will the Minister suggest to the Minister for Health that some way be found to overcome this problem?

—The Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Scheme has been of benefit in most remote areas in Australia. I know of a large number of people in my own state of New South Wales who have sought to take advantage of its provisions. Of course, it is an initiative of the Fraser Government designed to bring benefits to people in non-metropolitan Australia, and it has been appreciated as such. I understand the thrust of the honourable senator's question to relate to the cost, whether or not the initial outlay which people are required to make can be recouped later. I will certainly undertake to put Senator Thomas's very reasonable proposition to the Minister whom I represent to see whether the honourable senator's constituents in Western Australia, and others, can derive any benefit.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Minister will be aware of the stated intention of the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, Mr Hinze, to introduce special legislation to deal with any violence that occurs at the forthcoming Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. The Minister will be aware also of the recent prediction of racial violence at the Games by his chief Aboriginal adviser, Mr Charles Perkins. Does the Minister agree that the stage is being set for a New Zealand-like Springbok situation for Brisbane? Does he agree that the Federal Government could prevent this predicted race violence by legislating for Aboriginal land rights to Queensland Aboriginal reserves?

—The last thing any Australians want to see is violence at the time of the Commonwealth Games. It is an important international event and I think all Australians would want to see it go ahead in a spirit of comity and amity. I think people want to see a successful carnival. If the stage is being set by anyone, it is being set by the Australian Labor Party because the actions which it is proposing to take to pre-empt a reasonable decision by Queensland are the very kinds of actions which can lead only to a hardening of attitudes on all sides. The Australian people want a solution in Queensland which meets the very best aspirations of the Aboriginal communities there, to provide them with the tenure they require on their reserves. I do not think any attempt, for cheap political purposes, to pre-empt the consultative processes in Queensland will be in the best interest of Aboriginals and I certainly do not think it will be in the best interests of Australia.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the implication in the Minister's final remarks that supporting Aboriginal land rights in Queensland is undertaken for a cheap political purpose?

—What is undertaken for a cheap political purpose is the attempt to move in and take action before the State in question has announced what it wants to do, and making a presumption in advance of what that intention is. Even Senator Ryan cannot predict what is in the minds of the members of the Queensland Government and what proposals they will put forward.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to an Age report of 22 August which claims that the Great Barrier Reef is once again threatened by millions of coral-devouring crown of thorns starfish. Will the Minister comment on this report and, in particular, the statement by Dr Robert Endean of the University of Queensland, a world authority on the crown thorns, that it is vital that the Federal and State governments act quickly to put teeth into laws designed to protect natural predators of the starfish? I ask the Minister, firstly, what restrictions and bans presently exist on the harvesting of the fish and shellfish which control the crown of thorns; secondly, are these restrictions and bans adhered to by spear fishermen; and, thirdly, will increased efforts be made by the Government to police and enforce these laws so as to ensure that the natural predators of the starfish are protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain that I have the answers to all the honourable senator's questions. However, having seen the article in the Age newspaper of 22 August, I do have some notes on the statements made by Dr Endean. The Queensland Fisheries Service and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority last year undertook surveys on the crown of thorns infestations on reefs between Innisfail and Cooktown. Further investigations are being developed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, including a detailed historical study of previous crown of thorns populations and their relationships, if any, to human use of the reef.

ANSWER.PARA: The Authority is concerned about the recent apparent increase in crown of thorns starfish populations, but it must be added that despite extensive research there is still no hard evidence to support the suggestion that large crown of thorns populations are the consequence of human activity on or near the Great Barrier Reef. The Marine Park Authority will continue to monitor the crown of thorns situation and to support appropriate research programs into the key questions of the causes and possible controls. In view of experience of the starfish since 1960, it would be unrealistic to expect quick answers.

With regard to commercial spear fishing, the Authority is well aware of problems which may be caused by this activity. Commercial spear fishing has therefore been completely banned in the Capricornia section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park under the zoning plan and regulations which came into operation on 1 July this year. In addition, other regulatory controls for the protection of certain forms of marine life, including the giant triton shellfish, apply throughout the Great Barrier Reef region as a result of existing Commonwealth and State legislation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELECTRICITY COMMISSION OF NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the Electricity Commission of New South Wales is currently trying to raise almost $1 billion to finance new power stations at Bayswater, Eraring and Mount Piper? This is to provide electricity for Mr Wran's plans to give the Hunter Valley an acute case of industrial indigestion. Will the Minister agree that the fund raising by the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, especially on such a huge scale at this time, must lead to further upward pressure on interest rates, causing problems for young people trying to buy their first home and adding to the problems of the small businessman? Is it not true that Mr Wran must bear a share of the responsibility for such upward pressure on interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the extent of the borrowing that is required by the Electricity Commission of New South Wales for the development in the Hunter Valley. I suppose it is accurate to say that there is one loan market and that if any State government or the Commonwealth Government is entering that loan market to a sizable degree pressure is put on the extent of the loan funds available for all other purposes in this country. I would need to refer to the Treasurer any particular implications in the question from Senator Mason. If there is any response that he wishes to make, bearing in mind the activities of the Loan Council, I will see that Senator Mason is advised by the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Has the Minister noted an article in the Sun of 7 September, under the title 'Crisis Warning Over Lack of Teachers', stating that Australia could face a massive teacher shortage unless the Government trains more teachers? If I recollect correctly, a completely different report was publicised a few months ago, indicating that there is a surplus of teachers in Australia due to the diminishing number of school children. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the real position in regard to the availability of teachers in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that there has been a very great slowdown in the birth rate in Australia and therefore a decline in the enrolments in most but not all States. In a large part of this decade there was a very great expansion of the number of teachers in the work force. I think some 30,000 teachers have come in in a matter of six years. This has taken the figure from about 140,000 teachers to 170,000 teachers. That was an enormous increase at a time when the school population rose at a much slower rate. The predictions, as I recall them, were that there would be surpluses of teachers in various capacities, but not in some specialist capacities, for some years and that perhaps in the middle of this decade or beyond there would be some need for increases.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that at the moment persons seeking work as teachers are available in the community and, therefore, are capable of being employed. One of the difficulties is often geographical in that teachers seek to obtain work close to their homes. Many of them are married women with families and, therefore, there is a geographic rigidity. I did not see the article in the Sun. I am not aware of any facts which suggest that at the moment there is a crisis because of a lack of teachers. My understanding is that more recently in New South Wales it was disclosed that a number of teachers were seeking employment and an undertaking was given by the Wran Government that it would provide jobs for all of them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and follows the question asked by my colleague Senator Ryan. The Minister in his answer to that question said that it was wrong to pre-empt what was in the mind of the Queensland Government in relation to Aboriginal land rights and used the expression 'cheap political purpose' in regard to any legislative move to ensure land rights for the Aboriginal people in Queensland. With reference to the question of what is in the mind of the Queensland Government I ask the Minister whether he is aware of reported statements of the Premier of Queensland which read:

QUESTION.PARA: Aborigines did not need land rights as they could buy, sell and own land like other Queenslanders . . . land rights was being promoted by foreign forces who were trying to create a nation within a nation.
The radical left's drive for so-called land rights is just another variation of the old cargo cult.
All Queenslanders now have the right to buy, sell and own land and as such they already have land rights.

I ask the Minister whether he feels-far from pre-empting what is in the mind of the Queensland Government, to use his expression-that there is likely to be any change in those views, if he concedes that they are the expressed views of the Premier, in the immediate future. What process does he expect to effect a change in those views? I further ask what adjectives such as 'cheap political' he would use to describe the views expressed by the Premier, or whether he dissociates himself from such views. Further, what percentage of the Australian people voted for Commonwealth constitutional power over Aboriginal affairs in the 1967 referendum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue in Queensland is that of land tenure. The issue is about whether the Aboriginals are able to get tenure, under adequate terms, for the reserves on which they live. That is what the argument is around. That should be the only goal and the only end people seek to achieve. The Commonwealth position has been made quite clear. I have made it clear on a number of occasions. In this place I have tabled the four principles on which the Commonwealth has based its case. I remind honourable senators that those principles include the integrity of the reserve boundaries, an adequate form of tenure, an adequate role of self-management and consultation with the communities. These are the principles on which the Commonwealth is pursuing this matter of land tenure. It may be that the words 'land rights' are just a slogan which people use. The end which people can achieve must be looked at. If a form of land tenure can be achieved which includes those four principles I believe the aspirations of the Aboriginals in Queensland, as I have heard them, will be met.

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland position has not been stated by the Queensland Cabinet or Government and, in fact, what Ministers have said during this year has moved somewhat. I think it is quite improper to try to assume that we can know what the Queensland Cabinet will decide at some time in the future. If people are talking about deficiencies in what is being proposed, they might find it of some interest to know that a Bill presently before the Senate provides that certain communities and reserves will be completely free from the operation of any law of Queensland. If honourable senators examine the Bill, as they are to be called on to do, they will see that it actually proposes that these reserves will be free of the operation of any Queensland law. I think the people who are proposing that Bill need to be quite certain that they are not putting into statutory form what is the essence of apartheid, that is, that one portion of the community should be under a separate legislative structure and statutory basis from other areas. I know what the people of Australia decided at the referendum, and so does everyone else. The position that the Commonwealth has taken is one designed to make sure that Aboriginals in Queensland are able to achieve that desirable goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to deal with that part of my question as to whether he associates himself with or dissociates himself from the expressed views of the Premier of Queensland, which I quoted.

—To the extent that the Commonwealth Government introduced, passed and administers a land rights Act in the Northern Territory, obviously there are differences of interpretation between this Government and the Queensland Government. I do not intend to dwell on those or to emphasise them. That was our decision in relation to Commonwealth administration and it is still our position.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. In order to assist in the understanding of economic terms and to provide more useful information, would the Treasurer consider using the term 'median average wage' as well as, or preferably instead of, the currently very confusing term 'average weekly earnings', which is a most misleading figure to the majority of people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is true that the meaning of the term 'average weekly earnings' is sometimes misunderstood. The main difficulty with terms such as 'average wage' or 'median wage' is in determining and identifying for collection exactly what should be considered as a wage. Perhaps Senator Archer will appreciate that the present alternative used by the Australian Statistician-'average weekly, ordinary time earnings for full time, non-managerial adult male employees'-presents difficulties, for instance, in a 20 second television grab and it is perhaps difficult to have a term that is easily understood. But it is a matter that I could refer to the Treasurer to see whether there is some other way in which an interpretation could be given or some better degree of understanding could be provided of what is in our minds. As I say, the Statistician does use the term 'average weekly earnings' and, if there is misunderstanding, we may be able to assist in interpretation of that. I will see whether the Treasurer has any further comment that he wishes to make on this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to a statement on page 42 of the report of the Interdepartmental Committee on Economic Strategy released by the Treasurer last year which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Since 1975-76 there has been some success in reducing the ratios of Budget outlays and the deficit to GDP, but the overall burden of taxation (as a proportion of GDP) has increased.
I further quote a statement made by the Prime Minister on 21 August 1981 to the Tasmanian Liberal Party State Council, in which he said:
Statements that the overall burden of taxation on Australians has increased since 1975 are totally misleading.
How does the Government reconcile those two statements? Is it being misled by its top level advisers? If so, what does it intend to do about the source of such misleading advice?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I could comment on the comparison of those two statements, I would need to see both the documents in their full context. Simply taking a sentence or two from either one or the other and asking whether there is a contrast or a deficiency in argument is not good enough. I will refer the matter to the responsible Minister for comparison and a comment for the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government given consideration to reintroducing income tax deductions for interest paid on housing loans to encourage home ownership in the Australian community by assisting in offsetting high construction costs? Is the Minister in a position to make any comment on the subject?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I was asked whether the Government had given any consideration to the matter. The Government considered a number of matters in the context of forming the present Budget, but this matter was not one of the matters adopted as part of the Budget. There are some disadvantages in this form of assistance. For example, it favours those who already own a home relative to those who do not. It could also be said that it does nothing for those who are seeking a home loan but have not been able to find someone to finance their loan. It does nothing to increase the availability of home finance. Bearing in mind that there are some disadvantages as well as what some people would see as an advantage, on consideration it was not adopted in the present Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and relates to the three-year pilot project for homeless youth under the age of 18, announced first in November 1978, and its implementation in Western Australia. Twenty-six months have elapsed and only four Western Australian projects have been funded. Ten other applicants, including several voluntary groups and local government authorities, are still awaiting funding. Several agencies have for some time accepted referrals from the State Department of Community Welfare. The Minister for Community Welfare blames long-standing differences between the State and Federal governments for the delay. I ask: What are these differences? Bearing in mind that it is a pilot program with a three-year limit which must by definition include time for evaluation, will grants be approved in the near future? Can the Minister also tell me exactly how much Federal money has not yet been allocated in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to give the honourable senator from Western Australia all the detail that she has requested. The youth support scheme to which she referred is, as she indicated, a pilot project and the term of the pilot project will expire on 30 June 1982. It is my hope that the evaluation of that scheme will be completed during the course of the latter part of this financial year-that is, before 30 June 1982-so that we can examine in good time the future of the projects which have been funded under the scheme. The sort of thing which needs careful consideration from a Commonwealth viewpoint was thrown up by an element in the honourable senator's question. The honourable senator referred to the fact that some of the agencies in her State and my State of Western Australia have been receiving referrals from the State Department of Community Welfare. I would say to the Senate that I am not anxious to see the expansion of a Commonwealth project which simply involves the Commonwealth taking over State responsibilities with respect to the care of children. I think that would not be a particularly productive initiative on the part of the Commonwealth. We are looking to providing ancillary and additional services rather than merely substituting services for what the State provides.

ANSWER.PARA: The funding of youth support scheme projects in Western Australia has not proceeded on the same basis as the funding in other States. In other States there has been a joint funding of projects between the Commonwealth and State governments. In Western Australia, after some very long discussions which occurred prior to my becoming Minister for Social Security, it was finally agreed that the Commonwealth would fund certain projects on a separate basis-that is, totally fund those projects-while the State would continue to fund its own projects. It is true that only a small number of projects-the honourable senator said four and I think that is correct-have been funded under the scheme in Western Australia. I have before me at the moment requests with respect to the funding of additional projects in Western Australia. However, because of the relatively short time to the completion of the pilot project, I am not very anxious to see additional projects funded when on an evaluation it might be determined that the scheme will not continue the funding of those projects after 30 June 1982. It seems to me that that would be a rather pointless thing to do. I have no doubt it is coincidental but I discussed this area with the Western Australian Minister for Police and Traffic, and Community Welfare, the Honourable Bill Hassell, by telephone yesterday and I anticipate further communications between us over the coming week. I may then be in a position to give more definite information to the honourable senator and the Senate following those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What action does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs propose to take about statements by the head of a Commonwealth instrumentality inciting racial violence in Australia? Would the Minister tolerate such statements by his white permanent head? This is viewed as a very serious matter in Queensland, particularly as it relates to violence being used to try to stop the Commonwealth Games and the fact that tens of millions of dollars have already been spent on these Games. Also--
—Why don't you spend a bit on Aboriginals?
—I am silent while the honourable senator asks questions. I wish she would be silent while I ask my question.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator ask her question. I will protect her from the chair.

—Thank you, Mr President. Will the Minister refer to the Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Grassby, Mr Perkins's racist remarks about Vietnam refu- gees or are Mr Grassby's energies reserved for so-called white racists?

—The Senate has already discussed during Question Time some matters related to the subject raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I do not intend to go over those matters again. I simply say that the action taken in relation to any particular officer is the same as that taken for all other officers under the same circumstances. It will not be varied in any way. No special treatment will be given. Neither will there be any special treatment for that officer to treat him in any less just way than anyone else would be treated. I imagine that what I need first is a proper collection of information and facts and an examination of options. That will be done with the same care, speed and deliberation as it would in the case of anyone else. I will make any decision required. The honourable senator need have no worry about that. In conclusion, if there is any desire that any matter be referred to Mr Grassby for determination, I suggest that those who feel aggrieved should make the complaint.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEAT INDUSTRY: STATEMENTS BY SENATOR PRIMMER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and refers to the meat industry. Following Senator Primmer's statement in the Senate in March 1978, what action was taken by the Department of Primary Industry? What information and what instructions were passed to the Australian Federal Police? Was a police report submitted to the Department of Primary Industry? What was the substance of the report and does this matter fall within the terms of reference of the royal commission?

—The allegations made by Senator Primmer were examined in depth by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, the Victorian Department of Agriculture and the Australian Federal Police. Consequently, a statement was made to the House of Representatives by the previous Minister for Primary Industry on 8 March 1980 concerning the outcome of the investigations. I do not have the full text of that statement with me but I will examine it. To the extent that the questions raised by the honourable senator this morning are not answered by that statement, I will get a further reply for him from the Minister for Primary Industry.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister also refer to that part of the question where I asked whether the matter raised by Senator Primmer falls within the terms of reference of the royal commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I made a statement in the Parliament following a statement made in the other place by the Acting Prime Minister. The terms of reference set out in that statement include the following:

ANSWER.PARA: The Royal Commissioner will inquire into the following matters:

(c) allegations made, whether in public or to a Minister, department or authority of the Commonwealth, of malpractices alleged to have occurred during the past ten years, in the handling of meat for export or in the exportation of meat;
(d) whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective;

I would not want to commit myself on a matter which might be open to argument before the commission but I would have thought that the very breadth of those paragraphs would indicate that the answer to that part of the honourable senator's question is yes. Again, I will give that part of the question, which is a matter which might require some legal interpretation, further consideration. If I wish to vary that reply I will do so in the Senate.

Since the breadth of the terms of the royal commission has been referred to in the question I point out to the Senate that, notwithstanding what I would regard as a rather extraordinarily limited interpretation given to those terms of reference in debate in this place last night, the statement made yesterday makes it clear that the royal commissioner will inquire into the following matters, and I refer to paragraphs (a) and (b):

(a) whether administrative arrangements and procedures for the supervision of the handling of meat for export are adequate to ensure that all meat exported from Australia meets the requirements prescribed by law;
(b) whether malpractices are occurring, or have occurred, in the handling of meat for export or the exportation of meat;

I do not wish to abuse the forms of the Senate by answering at too great a length, but I have read those initial paragraphs of the terms of reference merely to point out that there is no reference in either of them to a requirement of allegations. It was suggested in the Senate yesterday that there was a very limited inquiry because it all hung on prior allegations having been made. It is quite clear that those first two paragraphs of the terms of reference do not require some prior allegation to have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer the Minister to a question to him from my colleague, Senator Kathy Martin, on 26 May last seeking consideration for a period of three years for practical implementation of the Commonwealth tender requirement for all construction work on national roads together with a basic day labour presence, thereby avoiding major retrenchments by local councils. As evidence has now been presented to the Minister of actual retrenchments, namely, by the Tiaro Shire Council, Queensland, and in view of the Minister's statement that the legislation as it now stands does not allow a basic day labour presence or any further extension of time for implementation, will the Minister now give consideration to amending this legislation and saving the jobs of many Queenslanders and indeed the jobs of State and local government employees throughout the nation?

—I recall the question asked some months ago in this regard by Senator Martin but since then I have not gained any further information which I can give to Senator Bonner. I will need to refer the matter to the Minister and bring down an early reply for the honourable senator.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. Who is the architect of the nonsense that those people who do not or cannot tender the correct change on Canberra's ACTION buses will in effect be required to pay a fare surcharge? Has any consideration been given to the regressive effect that this policy could have on the Australian Capital Territory tourist industry and to the adverse comments that Canberra visitors will carry to their neighbours back home?

—I am afraid I have no information on this matter except what I know from the reports on radio this morning and last night. I will need to refer the question to the Minister for the Capital Territory to obtain a reply for Senator Colston.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROGRAM OF AIDS FOR DISABLED PEOPLE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Health to a telex recently sent to the Minister for Health by the South Australian Minister of Health outlining the South Australian Government's view that the Commonwealth should directly administer the program of aids for disabled people in view of the fact that the Commonwealth has refused to give a guarantee that the scheme will have sufficient funds to run for a full 12 months. Is the Minister able to indicate at this time whether the Commonwealth has reconsidered the matter and will guarantee sufficient funds to South Australia for this scheme to operate for a full 12 months and beyond? If not, and in the light of the South Australian Government's refusal to act as an agent for the Commonwealth to administer the scheme, can the Minister say whether the program of aids for disabled people will be administered by either the Commonwealth Department of Health or the Commonwealth Department of Veterans' Affairs, as recommended by the South Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that Senator Hill has an interest in the needs of his electors in South Australia and his question is related to that interest. I am advised that this financial year the Commonwealth made available for the program a total of $2.4m, of which the substantial sum of $200,000 was earmarked for South Australia. Unlike the States of Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania, and the Northern Territory, the South Australian Government has decided not to participate in the implementation of this important program in its State. Of course this will greatly complicate the task of introducing the program in South Australia and of enabling disabled South Australians to benefit from the provision of $200,000 for aids to assist them to live more independently within their communities. The exact level of demand for the aids to be provided under this new program is not known at this stage. For that reason, it is not possible to give a guarantee in the exact terms sought by South Australia. However, what can be said is that this is an ongoing program in terms of Commonwealth funding. My colleague, the Minister for Health, made that point known in writing to all State Ministers for Health but apparently it has been missed by the South Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth's objective of having this program administered through the State health services is soundly based. The main reason for this approach has been that the State health services are very widely dispersed throughout Australia and this method of implementation would give disabled persons the maximum ease of access to the program-an opportunity which will now be denied if we cannot get the co-operation and involvement of South Australia. Following advice of the South Australian Government's decision, urgent consideration is being given to the possibility of alternative methods of introducing the program in that State. Obviously, my colleague is not yet in a position to inform the Senate or the honourable senator which method, whether through a Commonwealth department or some other type of agency, may be suitable. If any other parts of the question remain unanswered I will be happy to refer them to my colleague.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, by reminding the Minister that, in answers to two questions this morning on Aboriginal land rights, he has publicly placed himself in a position in which he now supports the Premier of Queensland and his Minister for Police in their stated opposition both to blacks and to their claim for land rights. The Minister will be aware that the Prime Minister is currently considering a request from me to allow a delegation of Queensland Aborigines and islanders to address the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in order to present their case regarding the way in which they are discriminated against by both the Premier of Queensland and his Government. I ask the Minister: Does he support the right of such a delegation to address the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting?

—The issue raised by the honourable senator is an extremely simple one. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting is a meeting between heads of government and on that basis it is not appropriate for a delegation from Queensland to address it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Following a report in the Australian newspaper that non-residents of Australia hold 21.8 per cent of the shares of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which is above the Government benchmark for foreign shareholdings, what action does the Government intend to take to ensure that no more of this company's shareholding, which is a vital part of the Australian economy, is sold out to overseas interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer to the Treasurer, for early comment, the matter that Senator Watson has raised.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Education: Is the Government considering financing Australian colleges of advanced education which do not meet the deadline for amalgamation announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Will the Government consider giving those colleges a breather of one year to enable the many problems to be satisfactorily resolved and especially to give time for greater consultation with communities affected? Will the Government issue guidelines for the resolution of difficulties caused by superannuation liabilities, accrued annual leave and the future of staff made redundant by amalgamations?
—I will bring that question to the attention of the Minister for Education and seek his response.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, refers to a report in a newspaper today that another Royal Australian Air Force Mirage jet fighter has crashed. Since 1964, 31 of the 116 Mirage aircraft have crashed. The matter which concerns me is that if one takes 31 from 116 one is left with 85. The report states that, in fact, there are only 84 aircraft left and that is because another Mirage aircraft became unusable when it corroded beyond repair. Could we have some explanation of how it is that an aircraft worth so much money should be allowed to corrode beyond repair?

—It is true that one Mirage aircraft became unserviceable due to extensive corrosion. The aircraft was a dual-seater Mirage stationed at Butterworth. The corrosion was caused by a higher level of moisture in the rear of the cockpit which was exacerbated by the climatic conditions at Butterworth. The corrosion occurred in an inaccessible area of the aircraft not normally subject to routine inspection. When it was detected during a major servicing, corrosion had rendered the aircraft unserviceable. Preventive measures have been taken by increasing the frequency of such inspections. As I have said, the aircraft was one of two dual-seaters at Butterworth. There are other dual-seaters stationed in Australia. None has exhibited similar corrosion problems. The preventive measures referred to make this extremely unlikely. Certainly no aircraft has been lost due to corrosion, except for the one in which corrosion was discovered before it did crash.

—I will have to refer that question to the Minister for Primary Industry. I will endeavour to get a reply as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that no provision was made for Commonwealth support of the Australian Children's Television Foundation in the recent Budget? Is it true that the Foundation, which has been jointly sponsored by the New South Wales and Victorian governments, asked for a sum of $250,000 this financial year and that, without this sum, financial support by all the States that agreed to participate in the Foundation is in jeopardy?
—The question will have to be referred to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, as it does require a fairly specific set of answers.

—My question is directed to Senator Baume. It will be of interest to him as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs as well as in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It concerns the lack of television reception at Snake Bay on Melville Island due to the presence of a hill between the township and Darwin. The problem could be overcome quite cheaply by the erection of a mast and a translator. Given the educational and other values of television, will the Minister, in his capacity as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, or in consultation with his colleague in the other place, take the appropriate action necessary to overcome the problem?

—I am aware that the area of the Tiwi Land Council has had some television reception for a couple of years. We have been interested to see the impact of television in that territory. I certainly will take on board the suggestion made by Senator Robertson. I will undertake to have it investigated and try to come back on it to the honourable senator.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs will recall that yesterday I asked a question concerning the Pol Pot forces in Kampuchea and the rumours that Australia would be asked to give military and other aid to those forces. Has the Minister any further information she can pass on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do have a response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the question raised by Senator Bonner yesterday. The Government's attitude towards the Democratic Kampuchea regime is clear. The Government withdrew recognition of that regime on 14 February last. Since then the Government has recognised no regime in Kampuchea. The decision to de-recognise Democratic Kampuchea was based on the attitudes of the Australian public and Government towards an abhorrent regime. Our attitude to that regime has not changed and we do not wish to see the Democratic Kampuchea regime returned to power in Phnom Penh. Australia hopes that a coherent and effective regime truly representative of the Khmer people will emerge in Kampuchea. We have no intention of recognising the Heng Samrin regime and remain completely opposed to Vietnam's military occupation of Kampuchea. The Government believes the Kampuchean situation should be settled by peaceful, not by military, means. We have received no request to provide material support to Khmer Rouge forces.

—Has the Attorney-General, as has been stated in numerous Press reports, the most recent of which was in the Australian Financial Review of 14 August, received a report from the Australian Federal Police concerning the leaking of the 1980-81 Budget? If so, will he table it?
—A report about this matter was received some time ago. We do not make police reports available publicly. We do not publish them or table them.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the fact that many citizens who have pensions are facing financial difficulty. They are losing their fringe benefits because they receive just over the permissible income limit. Because of circumstances such as changes in the exchange rate in cases where they also receive overseas pensions or other minor alterations in their income, they suddenly lose the whole of very valuable benefits. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether there has been any development of the schemes that have been suggested from time to time whereby in some way the loss of benefits might be phased out so that people do not lose the whole of these benefits because they receive a few cents over the permissible limit?
—I asked the Minister that six years ago and have not had an answer.

—The matter raised by the honourable senator is a genuine difficulty within the social security system in that a relatively small increase in income can lead to the loss of fringe benefits. As one honourable senator interjected, it is a matter which has been raised in the past. In the lead-up to this year's Budget I did consider this point. I was not able to put forward any solution to it, but I do have the matter under consideration. I accept that it does give rise to difficulties within the system and it does, I think, complicate the administration of the income test, which is an attempt to ensure that people do not get that sort of sudden loss of a substantial amount. I accept that it is a problem. It is not a problem for which I currently have a solution but it is one on which I have officers of my Department and others working, and I hope that we might be able to advance it in the coming year.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Due to the short notice of 10 days given to patients at the Greenslopes Repatriation General Hospital of the introduction of fees at the hospital, will the Minister make provision for patients who had booked in under the old free system, prior to 1 September when the charges took effect, to continue to receive free treatment until that particular confinement ceases?

—This matter has been exposed a great deal in the media in recent days, at least in Queensland, and I have noticed that Senator Jones has made some remarks in respect of it. The problem stems from the introduction of the new charging system, which applied from 1 September this year. Difficulty does arise in situations where people may not have arranged health insurance to cover them after 1 September. I can answer Senator Jones only by asking him whether he might be able to bring specific cases to my attention. We may be able to determine whether or not a person qualifies under the various provisions as a disadvantaged person and consequently may be able to receive free treatment. I can make no blanket statement in regard to this matter. It is something which will rely on consideration of individual cases.

—Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. During Question Time Senator Baume, in answer to a question from Senator Ryan, made a false and misleading statement that members of the Australian Labor Party supported and were advocating violence to prevent the staging of the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. Senator Ryan was advocating that the Government should enact land rights legislation to prevent violence such as that referred to yesterday in the program AM by an officer of Senator Baume's Department. I want to state categorically that the Labor Party at no time advocates resorting to violence. We support at all times using the due processes of law in an endeavour to obtain justice for all people who rightly claim to be suffering from injustice.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continual failure of the Government to provide adequate funding to the States for public housing.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of housing, particularly public housing, is extremely important. It is clear, when we look at the Budget allocations by the Fraser-Howard-Anthony Administration over the last six years, that this Government considers housing as being of declining importance. Our purpose is to highlight in the Senate, which is supposed to represent the rights of the States, the growing public concern about the cutbacks in allocations of Federal funds for the purposes of providing accommodation through the various State housing authorities. In the weeks since the Budget the Government's chickens have really come home to roost on a number of major issues. Many Government members may not be able to work out the problems but observers, political analysts and, most importantly, the people of Australia have easily identified the Fraser Government for what it is. It is uncaring, cynical, unconcerned and indifferent in relation to the welfare needs of people and much more interested, as the Budget shows, in the demands of the big business corporations, the foreign investors and its financial backers.

SPEECH.PARA: Alongside the abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme and the new sales tax increases this attitude is clearly shown in the Government's refusal to service adequately the housing needs of the nation. The pitiful handouts and drastic cuts in the 1981 Budget in the area of housing just add to the years of neglect by the Fraser Government. Yet surely it is recognised that housing accommodation has risen not in line with rises in the general rate of inflation but at a rate at least two or three times higher than inflation depending upon where one lives in this Commonwealth. The rate of inflation in the housing accommodation area has increased out of all proportion. Housing shortages and the homelessness which now faces so many of our Australian people rank second only to the tragedy of unemployment as Australia's major social problem. The housing crisis in this country has been highlighted once again in recent times, in this case by the firm statement of condemnation made by State housing Ministers at their recent conference. The most prominent of these Ministers has been the Victorian Minister, Mr Jeff Kennett. What did he say? A report in the Age states:
Mr Kennett said the Federal Government did not deserve to win the next election and probably would lose it if it did not provide more money for housing.

The reduction in funding to the States for housing is, in Mr Kennett's words, 'totally unrealistic'. Unfortunately, Mr Kennett believes that the problem should be solved by the Federal Government, not by changing the Government's economic direction or economic policies, but rather by cutting back in areas such as foreign aid, health, welfare, education and other matters which surely deserve some priority when considering the needs of the Australian people. Mr Kennett is not the only Liberal Party member who feels the wrath of the electors fast approaching. On Tuesday, Mr Burr, a Liberal member from Tasmania, in a radio broadcast, publicly attacked his Government's policies on interest rates and housing. On the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM he said:

Housing could well be the key issue at the next election and I believe that if the Government doesn't change its policies . . . I believe the Government will pay a very heavy price at the next election.

So, even Government members and Government supporters are plucking up sufficient courage, which was evidenced in some of the debates last evening on the Budget, to criticise the Government's inadequacy and failure in a variety of areas. These comments underline the crisis within the Government parties on housing and other related issues.

We should not think that the only criticism to be heard is that from a few maverick Liberals. The complaints are widespread and frequent. For example, all State housing Ministers recently joined to condemn the Fraser Government's policies. This condemnation took place only last week at their most recent meeting in Sydney to analyse the effects of the Budget on housing. Today we heard reports from the building industry. It has added its most trenchant post-Budget attack upon this Government. The Sydney Daily Telegraph reports that the national Housing Industry Association, in a letter to Mr Fraser, warned him of:
. . . the electoral consequences of this Government's present inadequate housing policies.
The Housing Industry Association has written to 45,000 master builders warning them that, unless this Government changes its policy, the Government will have to be changed.

I could go on and on with more examples of condemnation from housing groups, welfare agencies, real estate organisations, building associations as well as building unions, all of which seek to change the direction and policy decisions that this Budget has made with respect to housing, but I will not trouble the Senate with further quotations. I will simply say that all the responses to the Government underline two things: Firstly, that the people of Australia have finally got the message that this Government does not care about their housing needs; and, secondly, that the Fraser Government's housing policies will collapse on top of it come election time. As the opinion polls show, it will be thrown out of office because of its welfare housing neglect, its interest rate policies, its cuts to the States and its increase in sales tax and other forms of taxation.

Mr McVeigh, the responsible Minister, when being criticised by a variety of people, was quoted as saying that the States do not know the meaning of the word 'shared'. This is absolute hypocrisy. It is Mr McVeigh who does not understand his responsibilities. He believes that in a word-sparring exercise with State Ministers the matter will simply fade away. I can assure this Government that it will not fade away and that we will continue to talk about the problems of housing in our community. How can a Minister of a government, which has cut real net payments to the States for housing by $526.4m since 1975, have the gall to push the blame on to the States? How does Mr McVeigh explain a cut in capital payments to the States of $54,642,000 in projected 1981-82 prices for this coming year? In response to Mr Kennett's criticism, Mr McVeigh attempts to blame Victoria and New South Wales-the big States-for neglect. Of course the Victorian Government is guilty of neglect in this area, but the fact remains that the Federal cuts have been made and they have seriously impeded the ability of the States, particularly the big States, to carry out their responsibilities. How does the Minister explain the fact that all States have suffered these sorts of major and drastic cuts in Federal funding for welfare housing? The McVeigh double talk and double think is an attempt at pure deception. It is an attempt to palm off responsibility and deflect criticism for what we know is a deliberate Fraser Government philosophy and policy. The Fraser philosophy for housing was spelt out recently by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, in a speech to the Co-operative Housing Societies Association of New South Wales conference on 25 June this year. Mr Howard said that the key instrument in the Government's housing strategy is:
. . . the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement.

This is precisely the agreement which was re-negotiated this year and which has been used to rip money away from the States while placing an extra burden upon them. Mr Howard said that the aim of the policy was:
. . . a significant winding back of public sector demand for funds in the coming financial year.
In plain terms this means that the Government does not want to see the States provide the facilities for housing, especially welfare housing, which is a major State responsibility.

Welfare housing and housing provided by the public sector just does not fit into the schemes of the Fraser Government. Figures obtained from Commonwealth and State housing authorities show that there has been a drastic decline in public sector housing in recent decades. I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which gives details of the houses and flats completed by State authorities as a percentage of the total houses and flats built. The table shows that in the 1950s and 1960s public sector housing amounted to about 20 per cent of total building. Today the public sector accounts for only 6 per cent.

It is interesting to read the speeches of Mr Menzies, the Prime Minister of the 1950s and 1960s. If we examined the sort of Federal funding that was made available to the States by Mr Menzies we would have to say on a superficial analysis that Mr Menzies would be regarded by the present-day Tories as being somewhat of a left wing Liberal. As the Australian economy developed and as Australia's manufacturing base increased, so did he provide funds for a development of our public housing. It is interesting to compare the percentage of public housing constructions projected in this coming year with the percentage in the last period of the Whitlam Government, 1975-76. This Budget projects that public housing will make up 6 per cent of total housing constructions, whereas the Whitlam Budget provided funds on the basis that 12.2 per cent of constructions would be in the public area.
