TALK.START.PARA: —These figures have to be looked at in the light of changes and structural shifts in the economy. Manufacturing, as we all know, no longer plays the part it once did in the Australian economy. The further running down of manufacturing is a major policy decision of this Government and an effect of Fraser's policies. Mining investment and land speculation continue, despite all the current doubts of the resources boom, as the cornerstone of Australia's proposed economic development. For this sort of development the Fraser Government sees no need to provide housing funds, unlike the Menzies Government during its attempts to foster manufacturing in the 1950s and 1960s. Even in the context of Australia's conservative tradition, Fraser is out of step. The Government finds some money to assist housing development in line with its vision of a resource-based economy, however. An amount of $45,000 has been set aside for a public awareness program to promote low cost mobile homes for use in resource development regions and on the outskirts of capital cities. That is all this Government is prepared to do.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the result of this squeeze on the States combined with the interest rate increases and sales tax changes? Let me return to what has been said by the critics of the Government's housing policies-in this case the Real Estate Institute of Australia. The Institute said:

People who have been forced out of the home buyer market and cannot afford to rent in the private residential market will have to join the ever lengthening queue for a diminishing supply of government welfare housing.

So, as a result of this Government's economic policies, fewer people can provide for their own accommodation. They are being forced into the queues for welfare housing at the very time that this Government has drastically and dramatically reduced the amount of funds for the States. What do people do when they cannot get access to welfare housing? They are homeless. To the maxim that Australia is becoming a nation of tenants and landlords we should add 'and homeless people'. How many people are homeless? This we do not know for sure. We can only rely on estimates such as those of the Victorian Housing Minister, who says that there are at least 100,000 households in need of housing in his own State, or the estimates of the Housing Industry Association, which claims that there are 280,000 homeless people throughout Australia. I think even honourable senators opposite would concede that that organisation is no general critic of the Government, that it is not influenced by the philosophies of the party to which I belong. The Housing Industry Association says that a further 250,000 people are living in makeshift or mobile homes. Surely, those figures underline the indifference and indolence of the Government's attitude to this problem. This is a Government that claims to represent and to govern for all of the people in this country. Yet that is the state of the nation so far as housing is concerned.

Mr McVeigh, in debate on this matter in the other place, poured scorn upon the criticism made by the Australian Labor Party and poured scorn on the criticism made by his own political counterparts in the various States of the Commonwealth. We can only say that McVeigh as the Minister responsible does not know, does not care and has done nothing to find out about the basic needs and requirements of the States as they endeavour in their own way to provide some alternative accommodation for people living in the States. Of course, Mr McVeigh's attitude illustrates the attitude of the Government as a whole. The Government does not understand or care about the state of the housing crisis. It does not concern itself with the homeless or with those people, particularly in the capital cities, who are now paying the biggest proportion of their social welfare payments in higher rents.

The Government is squeezing the majority of householders out of the home buying market. It is offering nothing but reduced and inadequate funding for State housing grants and is passing the responsibility off to others. It is not hard to understand how the real estate organisations have reacted. As reported in the Canberra Times on 21 August, the executive director of the Real Estate Institute of Australia, Mr Lawrence, said that Mr Howard had-
. . . made an extraordinarily weak commitment to the housing needs of Australians . . .
The Government appears to be out of touch with the housing world. The article reported Mr Lawrence as having said:

. . . the introduction of sales tax on building materials would increase the cost of new houses by several hundred dollars and would continue to deter the construction of badly needed rental accommodation.
. . . . Home ownership will now fall even more, this will put further pressure on rental accommodation which is already in short supply and no new flats are being built.

Of course, that relates to building in the capital cities. I have not time to detail the comments by the Real Estate Institute of Australia but it gives figures to show how in recent times rents in all capital cities have risen dramatically therefore affecting the capacity of tenants to meet that growing rental commitment. Of course, this was apparent earlier this year when the Age wrote about homes being taken from the poor. The editorial stated:
It is a job we are doing less and less well the longer the Fraser Government stays in office.
. . . . The Fraser Government has still not explained why it has singled out the housing of the needy as an area where spending should be reduced.

The comments I have recorded today and the responses of many other people in the community who are not politically involved make it clear that soon enough the Government will be forced either to change its policies or do what has been requested of it by the Victorian Minister, which is to increase by $450m in this current Budget the amount of money allocated for welfare housing. If it does not do so it will be forced by the voters to face up to its responsibilities which it has neglected. It will be forced to the polls prematurely with a result that will rectify the grave disservice that this Government is doing to the housing needs of the Australian people. We make no apology for suggesting that the Senate particularly ought to be discussing the cuts in public funding to the States for welfare housing. It is in this place that we should be carrying out our responsibilities of protecting the interests of the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we listen to Senator Gietzelt speaking in this place we are never disappointed because he always draws our attention to the vast philosophical gaps that exist between the Government and the Opposition on fundamental matters. But, of course, these gaps exist in all areas which affect the economy including taxation and housing. Senator Gietzelt has sought to make out a case, based on broad generalisations, of a lack of funding for specific purposes in some areas and he has extended his argument to indicate that all housing is being neglected. He did not provide the Senate with the details on the level of home ownership in this country as an example of how people in fact look after themselves and how housing finance generally is made available for them. For instance, he did not mention that in 1947 only 53 per cent of homes were owned by individuals in this country compared with 72 per cent today.

SPEECH.PARA: What has occurred over a period, as we all know, is an enormous growth in the wealth of individual families because of an increase in real incomes. This has enabled them to meet repayments on housing loans to the point at which they are able to look after themselves. Really, that is the core of the difference between the arguments of the Opposition and the Government on this matter. This Government stands for the extension of real benefits to the people through the free enterprise system. We do not try to compress people into public housing in the way that I believe Senator Gietzelt would like us to do, that is, by ensuring that people work in poor houses and perhaps have welfare housing thrown at them without being given a choice as to what kind of housing they would like. That is the kind of difference which exists between this Government and the Opposition.

The policies that this Government espouses will lead to further improvements in the percentage of people who own their own homes. Let me take that a little further because I would like to discuss the section of the Budget which was mentioned by Senator Gietzelt in the context of the total economic program to which clearly it addresses itself. We know that at present there are substantial difficulties in the money markets in this country which are having their effects in raising interest rates. Everybody acknowledges that, and in fact at Question Time today one of the Australian Democrats, I think it was Senator Mason, drew our attention to the fact that in New South Wales the State Government, by virtue of its commitment to establishing new industries in the Hunter River Valley, had in fact put pressure on interest rates and thereby was taking out of the system money which might otherwise have been available for housing. That is a clear example of the kinds of difficulties that exist at present. This Government's policy is aimed at ensuring that downward pressures on interest rates are maintained. Consequently, our aim to restrict activities that may strip money from the housing area by allowing a freer market for the price of money, that is, interest rates, will ensure funds are made available for housing. That is this Government's policy, and through that policy we will ensure that the downward pressure on interest rates is maintained in such a way as to enable the maximum number of people to obtain finance for housing when they want it and according to the style which they and their families enjoy.

That is the core of this Budget which we know is aimed at a very high surplus compared with the standards of the last few years. The Government has aimed at a Budget surplus of something over $1,500m which is a considerable amount of money compared with the deficits that we had become used to especially under the previous Whitlam Labor Government which of course established that disastrous trend in finance some five years ago. That surplus is aimed at taking off the money markets the pressure that is brought on by this Commonwealth Government which needs to finance its activities by either direct borrowings in the financial markets of Australia or raising taxation. If we can restrict its need to go into the money markets to borrow to finance deficits, the pressure on interest rates will be reduced. Accordingly, the philosophy and policy of this Government are to ensure that we have a big surplus this year which aims particularly at ensuring interest rates are kept at reasonable levels. That policy will enable the greatest benefits to be made available to a larger number of Australians.

I refer now to the merits of private ownership versus public ownership. We have observed many times in the past from the statements of Senator Gietzelt and other spokesmen for the Labor Party that the theme, which always has been consistent, is that there should be a greater commitment to public housing. Does that proposition stand up to an analysis of the facts? We know that the Federal Government, in conjunction with the States, has endeavoured over the years to extend finance in these areas. We clearly know from the figures of the last few years that the various States have improved their situation in that regard. There has been the policy of extending the availability of homes to those in greatest need by ensuring that people who do have greater than the average level of income or in some cases very substantial incomes are in fact required to pay market rents for public housing. Those kinds of policies ensure that moneys are made available more and more for those in the greatest need. So, public housing-welfare housing if you like-is made available to the most disadvantaged in the community. This Government's policies have been aimed at extending that availability. Since 1975, through negotiations with the various States, those policies have been implemented.

We know there has been an extension of other programs relating to Aboriginal housing and particularly veterans' housing through the Defence Service Homes Scheme. For instance, the increase in expenditure in this area, which happens to fall within my own portfolio, is of the order of $57m in this financial year. Total housing finance provided by the Federal Government has increased from $555m last year to $660m this year-an increase of $105m or nearly 19 per cent. That total amount of money that has been made available is clearly in the interests of all Australians because it is making available more homes for the average Australian. Obviously the Government is addressing itself to the real needs of the community.

In respect of the roles of the States, Senator Gietzelt has made a number of points in relation to some of the comments that have been recently aired by the Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Kennett. I guess it is always very nice to see a State and a Federal Minister from the same party at loggerheads over particular issues. It is very useful for the Opposition to pounce on that kind of thing in order to generate some kind of feeling that may be the Federal Government's policies are incorrect. Unfortunately, Mr Kennett labours with some very great disadvantages insofar as he sees the position as it affects his own State. He has no total view of the housing scene in Australia which I outlined earlier. It might even pay us to have a little look at some of the expenditure by Victoria on welfare housing. For instance, I note that the average per capita contribution to the welfare housing program by Victoria is $6. I note that the national average per capita contributions-the figure of which this Government needs to take account in meeting its true responsibility for national concerns-is $16 a head. In other words there is a difference of almost 250 per cent between the Victorian figure and the national average.

That does not mean there are not States which do better. For instance, I refer to the position in my own State of South Australia, which of course has had a very long commitment to public housing going back to the 1930s and 1940s under that great statesman and Premier, Sir Thomas Playford. The figure for South Australia is $47 a head. South Australia, that so-called poor boy State, as it is described on occasion by members from more wealthy States, in fact manages to spend on welfare housing $47 a head while Victoria can manage only $6 a head. Does that say something about the finances, or about the attitudes, of governments? I implore the Senate to address its mind to that subject because it shows quite clearly that in fact this is a question of attitude. Indeed, it is up to Mr Kennett to take himself into the Cabinet room of his own State ministry and argue more forcefully than obviously he has been able to do that more of the funds for programs under the control of the State Cabinet be directed to welfare housing. For Mr Kennett to criticise this Government and its Minister for Housing, Mr McVeigh, on the ground that inadequate finance is made available for welfare housing is simply to try to create a scapegoat for his own worries, concern and lack of ability to argue successfully for increased funds.

This subject is not one which I would normally involve myself in. It is a highly political matter and I suppose the Senate ought to address itself to the more general arguments. However, it is important to mention it, because the figures that I have just quoted do show a clear difference in attitude on the part of the various States to welfare housing. They show also that in fact, the Federal Government's attitude in this respect cannot be questioned. As I have demonstrated, the Government has clearly provided funds for the purpose across the board and is advocating and developing policies, particularly broader economic policies-as set out so clearly in the Budget-which are designed to make available vast sums of money for the provision of housing in the various States.

It is of interest to note that in fact in 1980-81 funds lent for housing throughout Australia totalled no less than $7,500m. I point out that, consistent with this Government's policy, the private sector contribution to that total was around 95 per cent. That indicates the extent of the commitment of this Government, indeed of the Australian nation, to housing. As Australians we believe that the great majority of homes should be owned by private individuals. In contrast, the amount made available by Government authorities represented only about 5 per cent of the total. For Senator Gietzelt to argue that there has been no commitment on the part of the Government to develop public housing is to ignore the major part of the argument, which concerns the total housing picture of the nation and whether we are developing policies which are aimed at extending housing as far as possible to all who can reasonably afford it.

As I have pointed out, programs for disadvantaged groups are available in the community. Senator Gietzelt sought to make something of the plight of homeless persons. He mentioned a figure of 250,000 homeless persons, which he defined as including those in mobile homes or in other makeshift forms of accommodation. He ignored the point that, because Australia has a rapidly developing economy, mobile homes often conform to the chosen lifestyle of many who work and live in outback areas and near mining sites and development areas of that kind. Of course there are also others who choose a lifestyle different from that implicit in living in suburbia and consequently make their homes in different areas of Australia. That is not to say that this Government does not have a commitment to those who want better housing but find it difficult to provide that for themselves.

During the last financial year, a sum of $22m was earmarked for grants to the States in respect of Aboriginal housing programs. A further $10.7m was allocated under the States Grants Aboriginal Housing Program of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. A further $22.1m was provided by this Government in grants direct to the Aboriginal housing associations for the provision of rental housing. An additional $8.3m was devoted to loans to assist Aboriginals achieve home ownership. Those facts show clearly the commitment of this Government to the development of programs which are consistent with its approach to private enterprise and private home ownership, but more particularly are aimed at assisting those groups which find it most difficult to look after themselves. Consequently, over time, with the implementation of those programs, we will see an extension of home ownership in this country to the widest number of individuals possible.

It is important to note that the program in respect of Aborigines and programs in respect of other disadvantaged groups comply with the general principle of extending the greatest care to those in the greatest need. Our policies in discussions with the States have been towards that end. Over the years, we have seen an increasing interest in the States towards ensuring that those who can afford to pay for housing and currently occupy what might be described as welfare housing pay rents at market or almost market levels. Of course this ensures that funds are made available for those who really need substantial welfare housing. That is the kind of policy to which this Government is committed and which it is seeking to extend through its various policies. More than that, the real answer to the housing problems of any nation really rely greatly on the total commitment to control of the economy through monetary and fiscal policies. Since 1975 the Fraser Government has clearly demonstrated such a commitment as well as its success in achieving ends which are in the interests of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing to hear the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, in speaking on a matter of public importance such as this, ignore the real and pressing need of many in the community for housing. One would imagine from his speech that there was no particular housing problem in this country; that the policies of the Government, which he claims in an extraordinary statement are having a downward effect on interest rates-at a time when interest rates for housing and every other purpose in this country are at a record level-would solve the problem and that we really need not be too concerned about it. Senator Messner talked about the philosophical differences between himself and his party and Senator Gietzelt and his party. Obviously there are philosophical differences which extend beyond that.

SPEECH.PARA: The philosophical differences are not only between the conservative parties in this Parliament and the Australian Labor Party but also between the Liberal Party of today and the Liberal Party of yesterday, of the 1950s and 1960s, which was concerned with home ownership, particularly with maintaining a level of public housing for those who could not take part in the home ownership battle. There are also the very real philosophical differences between the Liberal Party federally and the Liberal Party in the States, and not just in relation to Mr Kennett and the Victorian Liberal Party. After the last meeting of the Commonwealth and State housing Ministers, the State Ministers got together and produced a statement complaining, firstly, about the attitude and arrogance of the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr McVeigh, and, secondly, about the attitude of the Federal Government to this very real problem and the failure of the Federal Government to maintain funds for housing in the States.

It is very wrong, I would suggest, to ignore the fact that increasing numbers of people are opting out of house purchase in this country and living in unsatisfactory housing conditions. It is wrong to ignore the fact that this very real problem of homelessness is recognised by the Senate as the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare is presently inquiring into one form of homelessness-the problem of homeless youth in our community. It is wrong and stupid for Senator Messner to ignore the fact that there are very real differences between his Government and the housing industry in this country. Over the last few months the builders in this country have repeatedly made claims on the Government to increase expenditure in that area, otherwise the consequences will be disastrous.

It seems to me that there are two main problems with housing now. They have always been there but one is much more emphasised now than it has been in the past. There is the old problem, which is increasing, of the plight of those people who cannot move into the market to buy their own homes and who cannot find public rental housing. These people remain in our community precariously housed in a declining rental market with the insecurities of costs and tenure that this implies. One of the most distressing problems for any member of parliament in this country, State or Federal, is to deal with the people who arrive, frequently at the end of the week, without adequate housing, only to find that there is no public and very little private rental accommodation available to them. The member of parliament is frequently placed in very difficult situation and in a situation of helplessness.

The second problem is a new one and is increasing. It would be unwise of the Government to ignore it. It has been here before but it has not been seen in any great size since the Depression of the 1930s. The problem concerns the endangered group of buyers who cannot afford to keep up their mortgages. If the Government chooses to ignore the reports in recent months-reports which will obviously increase after this Budget-of large numbers of people having to opt out of their mortgages and having to sell their houses, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne, I believe it does so at its peril. It also does so at the great expense of the people in our community.

Until recently, a person who had saved and paid the deposit on a house, plus all the legal costs of the purchase of that house, may have been short of money but usually, with care, he could survive the first year or so and then be relatively secure. The main advantage in the past was that in the early years those mortgage payments were stable or would move only marginally. People could budget for repayments and watch rising housing costs and inflation increase their equity and lower their repayments as a proportion of their income. Whatever one may feel of this process, it has been part of the Australian tradition of home ownership. It has allowed more than 70 per cent of Australian households to feel that they have a firm stake in the community. It is clear that this is changing. Senator Messner spoke of 72 per cent home ownership in this country. One notices that in a similar debate in another place even members on his own side of the Parliament admitted that this had dropped to 70 per cent, or just below, in very recent times.

Rising interest rates are providing a threat to new home owners. The weekly amount that such people could manage to pay with careful budgeting in the past is rising out of their reach because of the sharp rises in interest rates. If a purchaser bought a house with a loan of $30,000 at an interest rate of 11 per cent over a period of 30 years the total repayments would have been $88,210. The yearly repayments would have been about $3,538. The rise in interest rates to 12 1/2 per cent has sent payments up by nearly $8 a week and the total has risen by nearly $10,000. Another rise which is expected by everyone in the community and which was predicted in the Budget will add perhaps $5 a week to this bill and bring the total to be paid on such a loan up to just over $100,000. The result of this is that more people are opting out of mortgages and more people are going into public housing. It is this problem which worries Mr Kennett and his colleagues in the States.

The States have the responsibility of providing public housing in the community, a responsibility which they carry out, and have traditionally carried out, with funds from the Federal Government. Escalating land prices, high building costs, high interest rates, the introduction of new sales taxes on building materials, and the redirection of funds into resources development and away from housing on the one hand, and pressure on real wages and increasing direct and indirect taxes on the other have made the dream of home ownership more remote and will continue to do so. At a time when fewer people can bridge the deposit gap, fewer people can afford repayments and a disturbing number of people have to give up the houses which they are purchasing, there has in fact been a decrease in funds to the States in real terms, making it extremely difficult for those States to keep up with the need for welfare housing.

One of the unfortunate results of this has been the unseemly row taking place between the Federal and State housing Ministers in public and in the Parliament. The most vehement critic has been Mr Kennett. He has, quite justifiably, expressed concern at the fact that the public resources for public housing have been decreased by more than 50 per cent in real terms in five years. The response of the Federal Minister has been a continuous campaign of abuse against Mr Kennett in particular and the other housing Ministers to cover his own and his Government's inadequacies. Mr McVeigh called Mr Kennett 'arrogant' and 'ignorant'. Mr McVeigh then proceeded deliberately to mislead the Parliament, as Senator Messner has done today, by including in the housing funds the talks about funds for veterans' housing and aged persons' accommodation which have traditionally come from other departments. Traditionally these funds have been excluded from the sorts of housing figures that Mr Kennett and others have quoted in the past. He has done this to prop up the figures for his own Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute sophistry on his part.
—Yes. He has done this repeatedly. His performance in the House today is a repetition of that.
—Are they not needy people too?

—That is absolutely typical of the remarks of Mr McVeigh. The remark is absolutely unworthy of someone like the Minister who just interjected. Of course they are needy people. The expenditure of the Minister's Department on defence service houses has increased over the years just in line with inflation. The expenditure on aged persons' accommodation has decreased in real terms over the years. To pluck out these figures suddenly and add them to the budget of Mr McVeigh's Department, which has decreased more than 50 per cent in real terms in recent years, and then to claim that not to include them was to ignore the Opposition's concern or the Government's concern for veterans and aged people is unworthy of the Minister and this Parliament. It is one of the problems that we are facing in trying to get rational debate in this discussion. Mr Kennett is not blameless. As the Minister pointed out, Mr Kennett's Government has given welfare housing a low priority. Mr Kennett's Government has been responsible in the past for the building of some of the most inhumane high-rise residences in this country. But that does not mean that Mr Kennett has not got an argument and that the other housing Ministers have not got an argument. The expenditure which we are talking about has dropped from $700m in 1975 to $200m in the same dollar terms. There has been a decrease from 4 per cent to one per cent in the percentage of Budget outlays to this area. These facts were admitted in debate in the other place. The effects of this decrease in expenditure will be exacerbated by other parts of the present Budget, such as an increase in the sales tax on building materials, which will lead to an increase in building costs and an increase in interest rates which will inevitably follow the monetarist policies of the Government. Other factors which obviously will occur have not been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in the supplementary rent allowance and the restriction of that allowance to only those people in private rental accommodation will have two effects. First of all, it will affect the State housing commissions which will have either to up the rents or increase the rent subsidies out of their own housing budgets for pensioners and other people who are in public rental housing. The inevitable effect of the increase in the supplementary rent allowance in a tight housing market will be an increase in rents. It will increase rents for low rental accommodation in which people on low incomes have been living. To do those two things and at the same time to decrease the available funds for housing in this community particularly for public rental housing, inevitably will lead to people being forced into accommodation they cannot afford and into unsatisfactory accommodation.

I find it extraordinary that Senator Messner should view with equanimity the fact that estimates from the Minister's own Department and others sources point out that 250,000 people in this country are living in caravans and other forms of mobile homes. Senator Messner's reply is that these people are doing that because they prefer to or they are doing it because they are working in places such as mining areas where people traditionally live in that sort of housing. I suggest that Senator Messner go to Gladstone in Queeensland to see if the extraordinary number of people living in caravans there are doing so by choice. They are doing so because there is no other accommodation, because there is no social infrastructure built into that area. I suggest he go to the Latrobe Valley where an extraordinary number of people are living in mobile homes or unsatisfactory accommodation, again because there is insufficient housing built into the industrial developments in that area. They are not doing so by choice; they are doing so from necessity.

It is quite clear that this Government, despite the words of Senator Messner, through its actions in the Budget both in increasing the costs and increasing the difficulties which people will have to face to own their own homes and by decreasing the amount of money available for public housing expenditure, is exacerbating a severe and difficult situation. We need better answers than the sophistry we get from Mr McVeigh in another place; we need better answers than the mouthing of monetarist theories in this place. Therefore, I urge the Government to think again and reconsider the matter very seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the matter of public importance, the subject matter of which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The continual failure of the Government to provide adequate funding to the States for public housing.

Perhaps it would be best if I started by reading my speech from last year. This matter seems to be Senator Gietzelt's hardy perennial. Every year since I have been here I think we have debated the same matter. He produces the same arguments and we produce the same answers. Apparently, he still has not really caught up with all the information and points of view. A similar matter was raised in the House of Representatives early this week. At that time the details that could normally be used to lay to rest this sort of fallacy that the Opposition has put before us were provided. I will try to avoid providing that information again and will rely on a few other tacks wherever possible.

Whether members of the Opposition are social democrats or democratic socialists, they still want to make more and more people dependent upon the state. If a government can own the roofs over peoples' heads, it is an excellent start towards total control. I have raised this matter before during the last five years. It is one of the arguments I will try to avoid wherever possible. However, one can be assured that the Dedman edict is still alive and well. The two points we do not seem to have resolved in the past are, firstly, that this Liberal Party and this Government believe in home ownership. At present, about 72 per cent of Australians are in their own homes. That figure has almost reached what can be called a reasonably practical optimum, because of all the circumstances that go to balance the situation. Secondly, although Senator Grimes put the record straight today, the Government believes that housing is primarily a State function. All the rules and regulations come from the States. All sorts of arguments are different between the States. The States have different overall priorities but I have found, in touring around the various housing departments and speaking to the Ministers in the States, that none of them want Federal intervention. All they want is our money and a chance to have someone else to blame.

The States alone have responsibility to determine their priorities for expenditure. They are able to use their money however they feel inclined. I have no objection to that but I believe it is just another area in which the Federal Goverment, probably quite wrongly, decided to interfere in State functions and provide funds for specific purposes. I believe we would be much better off if the Government provided the money to the States on an untied basis and let them use it however they decided. I do not think that would make any difference to the proportion of money spent by the States on housing. They would still give housing the same priority that is has now. States such as South Australia see their priorities, and they provide money. States like Victoria do not give the same priority to housing and do not provide the money. It is funny that the noisiest States seem to spend the least of their funds on housing. At the same time, they would like to spend much more of the Federal Government's money. What do they do with the $500m in untied grants that go to them each year? Do they put that into housing? I think not.

What do the States do with their own money? Some people believe we should spend unlimited amounts of money on anything, and this is where the Opposition excels. Members of the Opposition always prefer the Government to spend the people's money, instead of letting the people spend it on their own. Where is the evidence that government has greater wisdom than the people on how money is spent? I admit that at least the Opposition's view that the Federal Government should spend multi-millions of dollars on housing is consistent with the Opposition's approach. With debate on the Budget only a couple of weeks old and with only a few speeches having been made, I was amazed to find that it is not only housing on which the Australian Labor Party is proposing enormous increases in Government expenditure but also other areas have been suggested. I refer to some of the remarks that have been passed already in various places. Senator Button castigated the Goverment in the early stages of the debate because tax has been increased. That means he wants to cut tax again. He said sales tax should not have been included.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the type of tax he was talking about and you know it.

—It is tax. He also referred to the cost of $10 a week to every person in Australia in respect of health insurance. He referred to the fact that the outlay on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has been increased by 100 per cent. I suppose we should not have done that. He said the Government had saved $212m by short changing somebody else, and he mentioned also a figure of $240m. I presume this means that the Labor Party would spend that $212m and $240m to which he refers. The attitude of the alternative government is quite clear from Hansard, and I notice that it is the same in the other chamber. Mr Les Johnson suggested that there is $280m that should be paid to the States. He accused the Government of increasing the pharmaceutical benefits scheme from 45c to $3.20, which indicates another area that he would use for this purpose. He lists all the postal charges as being in this category. Money comes from somewhere, and it comes only from the productive sector. The more we want to spend, the more we have to raise. The Opposition is talking about eliminating billions of dollars from petrol, and hundreds of millions less in sales tax. Besides that, we have propositions before the Senate about large interest subsidies. We are even talking about paying Tasmania millions of dollars to keep it poor, not utilising its natural resources. Before we start to take these proposals really seriously, we should ask the Opposition to quantify the money it is talking about. What constitutes adequate funding? Is it $20m, $50m, $200m, $1,000m? I ask members of the Opposition to tell me. SPEECH.PARA: People in Australia are paying adequate tax at the moment, and I think that most people in Australia believe that they are paying adequate tax. According to a table produced by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) which appeared in the House of Representatives Hansard last week, Australia is paying 28.81 per cent in taxation. What it will do is remove the bonuses from people who no longer need welfare, but who still get them at a cost of millions of dollars a year to the people who really need it.

SPEECH.PARA: The States have authority to use the funds in a variety of ways, including interest subsidy, I believe that currently that is the major use to which housing funds can be put. I urge that the States should use these funds in a proper way. I believe that they have not expended enough effort to sell off some of their vast areas of raw land and convert the money into housing. An interesting situation arose in Tasmania last week when the Government announced that it would provide $1m on an interest subsidy basis. What really interested me was that this money would be available to prospective applicants who, in cases where both the husband and wife were working, had a combined income which must not exceed $450 per week. I do not really classify that as being welfare housing, and I think it is a misuse of funds at a time when so many other things are needed. I believe that insufficient effort has been made by the States to sell houses to occupants at the market price and get the money working again. I have said these things over and over again in this place, but I have not seen any evidence from the States that they have made any effort in this regard. Housing is primarily a State function. The Commonwealth provides funds for welfare, and not enough of the money provided by the Commonwealth to the States is going to welfare--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much appreciate the opportunity to speak on this matter of public importance because it is in the area of housing that the Australian Democrats believe an important opportunity has been lost by the Government in framing the current Budget. In our alternative Budget we advocated doubling the total amount of money available for housing, that is, doubling it over last year's figure. This would have meant an additional expenditure of about $400m in total in various areas. We singled out the home building industry as an area for stimulation in the economy for some very pertinent reasons. Firstly, there is no doubt that a great need exists for additional expenditure on housing, and at a later stage in my speech I will quote figures in support of that claim.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the housing industry, if encouraged to expand, and expand rapidly, would take up the slack in the economy. We are under-utilising our resources by nearly 10 per cent, and I am talking about our human resources. That 10 per cent is made up of the unemployed and those people who would work if employment were available. I repeat that we have a 10 per cent under-utilisation of our human resources. It seems to the Democrats that the home building industry is the area which should be focussed on to take up that very serious slack in the industry. Firstly, the building industry is labour intensive. Secondly, it is almost entirely Australian owned. Thirdly, no less an authority than the A. V. Jennings organisation claims that Australia's home building industry is one of the most efficient in the world on the basis of man-hours per home unit size.

So, we have a labour intensive, Australian-owned and very efficient industry in need of great and urgent attention. It seems inconceivable that the Government did not take these very pertinent facts into account when framing the Budget. The Government must be concerned about unemployment. It must be concerned about the rapid decline in home ownership in this country. It must be very much aware of the great Australian dream. A very large percentage of Australian capital is invested in home ownership. That is the way the Australian people want it. People have come to this country from over-crowded areas in Europe and elsewhere and they have developed it because it has open spaces and because the possibility of a person owning his own home and plot of land is real. Why should Government strategy pull the shutters down on that great Australian dream, the vision of what this country is about? I will cite the figures on home ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is about public housing.

—I will get on to that in a moment. I think that in considering public housing we have to look at the home building industry in total and the fact that there is a very real need for public housing. The level of home ownership was sliding down even before the increases in interest rates. In August 1980, 71.9 per cent of homes were owner-occupied. This compared with 73.4 per cent in November 1978. This was a drop of almost 70,000 householders who were not owning or buying the home they lived in. It will undoubtedly get worse because every one per cent increase in interest rates adds $238m to the annual interest bill of Australian borrowers.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to a survey carried out recently by the Brotherhood of St Laurence in Victoria. It found that in Victoria 100,000 families were eligible for public housing compared with a stock of around 40,000 dwellings. That figure is supported by a recent survey by the Australian Housing Industry Association which showed a shortfall of 280,000 dwellings in this category on a national basis. This trend inevitably leads to great pressure within families and causes increased social dislocation throughout the country and greater demand for emergency and institutional housing. This area requires very urgent attention. I think we are all aware of the precarious position of women's and young people's refuges and hostels for wards of the state and probationers. This is becoming more critical day by day.

The first is that we have to conserve our capital so that sufficient money is available to finance mining developments. The second is that high interest rates will dampen the economy sufficiently to contain the wages explosion. I will talk about the first of those reasons. It seems to me to raise questions of priority. Do we want a mining boom or do we want houses for people to live in? The second argument about high interest rates dampening the wage explosion does not seem to me to make any sense at all. High interest rates diminish people's ability to buy food, clothing and other necessities and increase the wage earner's needs and, therefore, his agitation to increase his wages.

I conclude my remarks by reiterating that the home building industry is one area which, unfortunately, has not received the attention it deserves. There has been a drop of 25 per cent in the allocation to the States in the public housing area. This is very serious. As the figures show, it will greatly increase the hardship on the wage earner in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance proposed for discussion by the Opposition, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The continual failure of the Government to provide adequate funding to the States for public housing.

I think what this debate boils down to is a matter of political philosophy. The question is whether we support the idea that people own their own houses and provide an atmosphere in which they can do that or whether we support the idea that the Government provides as much housing as possible so that people live in the servile situation of paying rent for the rest of their lives. We, on the Government benches, support the idea that as many people as possible should be assisted to provide their own houses. I think that has been overlooked by those honourable senators who quote figures as to the amounts of money that go into public housing.

As has been indicated previously by honourable senators, home ownership in Australia is running at around 72 per cent. That is one of the highest percentages for member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and it is something Australia can be proud of. I think all honourable senators would recognise that it is the desire of most people in Australia to own their own homes. I found it rather amazing listening to the previous speaker, Senator Siddons-who, in his private life, one could say was a doyen of private enterprise-to hear him supporting the proposal that we should be pouring millions more dollars into public housing. I know that the members of the Australian Democrats are having problems in coming to grips with the role in which they see themselves in the Senate and in determining whether they are to be the official Opposition, part of the Opposition or whatever. Nonetheless, it seems to me that at this stage they are trying to out-socialise the socialists, which I find a rather strange role for them to see themselves in.
I reiterate that we on this side of the chamber want to see as much done as possible for people to own their own housing and for that to be done through the private sector.

The role of the Federal Government in housing is pretty limited. It is basically a State function. We are told that quite often by the States and, indeed, we accept that it is their role. All the laws and little nuances associated with housing are connected with the States and their functions. We want to have as little to do with it as possible. We do provide money. Over a fair period, we have provided a large amount of money, some in tied grants, some in untied grants and some in repayable loans. It is interesting to note that in the last 10 years the amount provided by the Government has gone up and down. It is misleading to look at that and say that one government in one year gave a larger amount of money. As I have intimated, some may have been in the form of repayable loans and some in straight out grants. The amount provided in the Federal Budget from 1971-72 to 1981-82 has risen by in excess of 500 per cent. So the Federal Government is doing its bit, but within the philosophy of providing the conditions whereby as many people as is possible can own their own homes. Of course, with such things as rising interest rates and costs going up the ability to repay loans is always a cause of concern for us, for the home owner and for young people in particular who are buying their own homes and more often than not their first homes. The repayments on a $30,000 loan have increased by about $15 a week since 1978. But at the same time the average weekly earnings have increased by approximately $80 a week. I think those figures should be considered when we are looking at repayments. To put it into percentage terms, house repayments, as a percentage of average weekly earnings, have fallen from 27.2 per cent in December 1978 to an estimated 25 per cent in August 1981. While recognising the fact that increases in interest rates do create a problem, one must consider the overall picture and look at the salaries now being paid and the ability to repay and to meet those increased costs. I think the figures show that the position is not as bad as some people would like to make out.

In his speech Senator Grimes mentioned Gladstone. Australian Labor Party senators seem to have a fixation with Gladstone. I think the fixation also seems to be on the part of southern Labor senators. I do not blame them for that at this time of the year. Senator Button mentioned Gladstone in previous speeches. He comes from Melbourne and Senator Grimes comes from Tasmania. I know where I would rather live at this time of the year; and it is certainly not Melbourne or Tasmania. Gladstone, with all the problems of a growing town, is a great place in which to live. As I have said, the residents are sick and tired of southern media and southern politicians using their city as an example of the worst place in which to live. It is quite a desirable place in which to reside.

Mention was made of the caravans. Of course there are caravan parks in Gladstone, as there are at Middlemount, Moranbah, Dysart and Blackwater. Every developing town has a caravan park. There is almost a caravan culture. Many of these people would not want to live in any other manner. They rather like the idea of living in caravans. It is certainly not my ideal as I am a pretty stable sort of guy when it comes to housing. But a lot of people do like living in caravans and they will move from one developing area to another. So the existence of caravan parks is no great hassle. Even for those who do want housing, at least they are living as a family unit in the developing towns, close to the work force. I think that is far better than men living in single barracks with their families living hundreds of miles away.

As I said from the start, it is our basic philosophy that everybody who wants to should own his or her own home. But, at the same time, we recognise that there is a need and this need is covered in many and varied ways in the Budget. There are the lower socio-economic groups which cannot afford their own homes at this stage even with all the Government does to help them. There is welfare housing, low rental housing. We assist pensioners in paying their rent. So we recognise that there is a problem and a need. I also think that the States have to play a role in providing welfare housing. Their attitude is altering now after a fair bit of reminding from the Federal Government that quite often people who live in welfare housing no longer need to be there. At last we are seeing the States starting to put a market rental value on those houses. I think that is how it should be. I have heard some of my colleagues speak of driving around welfare housing areas and seeing two cars parked outside a house with a boat in the front yard. That is not what welfare housing is all about. It is there to provide housing for those in need and, when those peoples' incomes are such that they can pay market rental values, they should do so or move. I do not think it is the taxpayers role to fund that situation. We provide the conditions whereby more people can own their own homes.

Interest rates have been mentioned. There is no need for me to go into any economic detail, for two reasons: Firstly, it has been done before; and, secondly, I am not an economist and I do not really understand the intricacies of it anyhow. Suffice it to say that the deficit that any government runs has a marked effect on the money market. The interest paid only reflects the value of the money of the day. If we look at the Budget figures for the last 10 years, it is interesting to note that in 1971-72 there was a deficit of $134m whereas there is an estimated deficit of $146m for 1981-82. But in between time we have seen that deficit blow out three times to in excess of $3 billion. That places tremendous pressures on the money market. It has the effect of driving up interest rates. What this Government is all about, as has been said time and time again, is implementing policies to ease those pressures, to balance our budget and to run a good economy. The figures going on the board are showing that our policies are having an effect. By doing that, the pressures of the Government on the money market are diminishing. As a result, we should relieve the pressures on interest rates. It is no use dealing with the symptons in one area. If we do that we will only get a distortion of the situation. Measures to assist people who are paying interest rates on housing loans would have no effect on the business community, the rural community or people who are borrowing for whatever reasons. The best way to handle a situation like this is not to look to doing a band-aid job on the symptoms but to get right to the cause of the problem. One of the causes is the pressure that the Government puts on the money market.

Entrepreneurs start to build different types of homes when the cost of housing goes up. Within the last two weeks, I and colleagues from both sides of both Houses have looked at a manufactured house which is based on modular construction. It is a method whereby very comfortable housing can be provided at far less cost. Such entrepreneurs are always around when there are increased pressures and costs or increased interest rates. As a matter of fact, this sort of thing gives a needle to entrepreneurs to get out and do something better. This is happening all the time. They are constructing good, comfortable housing of a size which young couples might want to buy. This type of housing can be provided some thousands of dollars cheaper than existing house designs. Rising costs can even have a beneficial effect. I reject this matter of public importance. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is a report of Telecom Australia entitled 'Australian Telecommunications Commission-Service and Business Outlook for 1981-82'. The report is dated August 1981. It is a very important document because a lot of questions have been asked in the Senate, particularly by one issue experts such as Senator Townley, about telephone charges and things of that kind. There is currently a community debate about charges for the telephone services, new telephone services, the extension of the Telecom network and so on. All these matter are matters of public concern and interest. It is in that context that a reading of the report before the Senate should be commended to all honourable senators.

This report vindicates the concern which the Australian Labour Party has expressed for some time about the Fraser Government's attitude and policies towards Australia's great public enterprises generally. One of the signs of bad management in a business or in a government is a perspective which focuses on the short term at the expense of the long term. Businesses, like any enterprises, have to be concerned with long term planning-something which is remote from the considerations of the present Government. A clear sign of short-sightedness in any business is the squeezing of the capital investment capacity of that business. The Fraser Government's record on this score is abysmal in relation to Australian public enterprises. Capital investment generally throughout the economy has been cut by 56 per cent in real terms since 1975-76. Nowhere is such a policy shown up more clearly than in relation to Australia's great public enterprises-the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Australia Post, the public transport commissions and, particularly, Telecom. The telecommunications industry is one of the most capital intensive industries in Australia, as it is anywhere else in the world. It is most important that the capital requirements of Telecom be considered in the context of that international situation. Because the telecommunications industry is a capital intensive industry, the Fraser Government commissioned a report to be prepared by independent consultants-the McKinsey company-on the capital requirements of Telecom. That report was made available to the Fraser Government in June of last year. I have asked Senator Baume on, I think, three occasions whether the Government will table the McKinsey report on the capital requirements of Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall only one, but I may be wrong.
—The next two questions were about when I would get an answer to that question.
—When indeed.

—'When indeed', says Senator Baume. The rhetorical question I ask again is: When indeed will we get an answer to that question about the McKinsey report on the capital requirements of Telecom? The answer is that this Government, which brings into this place wishy-washy freedom of information legislation and so on, and which contains people such as Senator Lewis who in Ballarat last week boasted about Telecom's great record under this Government, does not want that report published because the McKinsey organisation, when it investigated the capital requirements of Telecom, came out with a report saying that the Government's policy in relation to this matter was wrong, that a telecommunications organisation such as Telecom, which as I said before is capital intensive in its very nature, had a much greater requirement for capital investment for its long term needs and, increasingly it has been said, to fulfil its short term needs. Our national telecommunications networks are vital parts of the economic infrastructure of this country. That is presumably why the Government commissioned an independent organisation to report on Telecom's efficiency and capital requirements. That report, which was given to the Government 15 months ago, has never been published because it is critical of the Government. Our society is legitimately concerned about the vast investment in an organisation such as Telecom, about the size of that organisation, and about its future development. For a debate to take place in this Senate and in this country about Telecom without the publication of that information is nothing short of scandalous.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has created a situation in which Telecom's capital investment which ought to be growing, according to the McKinsey report-Capital and Policy Requirements for the 1980s-and, in all humility, to me, has in fact been cut by 16 per cent in real terms since 1975-76. Not only has the Government squeezed Telecom's capital investment but also it has raised the interest paid by Telecom on existing loans. The results of this are becoming apparent.

Waiting lists for telephone installations have been growing for some time. Some months ago in answers to questions on notice it was revealed that in just 12 months the number of applications for phone installations which had been deferred for over three months had grown by 300 per cent in some areas. When I asked the Minister for Communications whether he could assure the Parliament that waiting lists in the worst areas would improve, he gave me a candidly frank answer. 'No. Waiting lists will not improve', said the Minister. The McKinsey report asked why and stated that it was because the capital requirements of Telecom were not being met. That is the short answer. We are in the business of short answers with Mr Sinclair because his answer was no. The McKinsey report answer was that the requirements of the organisation were not being met because of the unavailability of capital.

The McKinsey report makes it quite clear that waiting lists will not diminish but will grow. The report that we are now considering on business outlook makes it clear that waiting lists for phones will grow. Many honourable senators will know of the places where the greatest backlogs in phone installations have occurred. For example, the waiting lists in the eastern suburbs of Sydney, areas like the Gold Coast in Queensland and country rural towns in Victoria are growing rapidly. Despite a fall in demand for new telephone services because of the penetration of the availability of telephones throughout Australia there will be over 112,000 Australians waiting for phones at the end of this financial year, according to the report now before the Senate. This is 15,000 more people waiting for phones than were waiting at the end of the last financial year.

Mr May, the Acting Chairman of Telecom Australia, someone who is conscious that the former chairman was sacked and never replaced, uses the following sort of diplomatic language to make the problem quite clear when laying the responsibility with the Federal Government:

It must be realised that with a limited capital program improvements in the network will not be as great as desirable and there will undoubtedly be some increase in the waiting times for service, particularly in high growth areas, such as the coastal regions of northern New South Wales and Queensland. In short it will not be practicable to make all of the improvements in service which some users would expect nor as quickly as they would desire.

In fact, the figures in this report show that in 1980-81 Telecom was able to satisfy 82 per cent of demand for new phone installations. According to the report now before us, in 1981-82 it will satisfy only 79 per cent of demand. Telecom has demonstrated not a perfect performance but a fairly high degree of efficiency. With restrictions on its finance, staffing and activities it has nevertheless targeted for a business growth of 13 per cent and a productivity gain of 7 per cent. Comparatively that is not a bad sort of record when we look at the general performance of business organisations in Australia. Telecom has also resisted to some extent this Government's attempts to run down its capital program. I will quote again from the report which stated:

With the restriction on borrowings, and the higher interest to be paid on past advances by the Commonwealth, the work of developing the telecommunications network in Australia to meet current and future demands could not proceed without this generation of substantial resources from within the organisation.

That is to say, Telecom's capital needs have been met insofar as they can be met by generation of capital resources from within the organisation, that is, from profits. This year we have seen the first round of increased charges by Telecom. I remind the Senate again that Telecom is one of the few organisations in Australia-I would think the only one-that between 1975 and 1981 did not increase its charges. Hands up any honourable senator who can think of any private enterprise organisation whether it be the lolly shop on the corner or the Myer emporium that has not increased charges in the period 1975 to 1981. All honourable senators remain mute and fixed in their places. There are no hands going up because there are not any other organisations in that situation. The fact of the matter is that charges have gone up in 1981. Telephone charges have increased and delays have developed in the provision of new services by Telecom because of the Fraser Government's policies. Let there be no doubt about that because that is the evidence of the Telecom report now before the Senate and it is the evidence of the independent inquiry which the Government set up and which it refuses to publish.

This Government has not only failed the people of Australia in terms of telephone charges and the provision of new telephone services but also it has been grossly cowardly in facing public debate as to why those things have occurred. It is not prepared to have a frank debate on the documented evidence in relation to this issue. It hides behind the cowardly veil of ministerial privilege, or whatever it might be called; not the Laurie Oakes syndrome as it is called but another veil of ministerial privilege. That is why in a sense this Parliament becomes an absolute farce if the Government will not front, in terms of debating the issues on the evidence available, but hides behind alleged confidentiality in relation to a report about Australia's largest employer-an enormous organisation in terms of capital investment. I assert quite strongly-this is supported by the two documents I have mentioned-that higher telephone charges and the unavailability of new telephone services are the direct responsibility of this Government towards Telecom. The statement in the report strongly implies that price increases could have been averted. Mr May, the Acting Chairman of Telecom, a man in limbo as it were after the unhappy fate of his predecessor, said that. He said that higher prices could have been averted had the Government adopted a more liberal attitude towards Telecom borrowing.

There are other disturbing aspects of this Government's downgrading of Telecom. Telecom directs about $250m a year towards the maintenance of unprofitable country services in Australia in the development of the country network. That figure is growing by about $40m a year. Already schemes for automation of exchanges in the country have been cut back because Telecom cannot continue to finance at the same level that unprofitable area of its activities. But this Government's restrictions on Telecom revenue and capital raising and its proposed hiving off of profitable activities to private enterprise pose much greater threats to country people than the possibility of restrictions on automation. This will lead, in the long term, to a dramatic downgrading of telecommunication services. This will lead to Mr Fraser's user pays principle in the country. Country people should be warned that when the users pay for telephone services in the country they will pay through the nose. They will pay roof top prices if they have to be susceptible to the user pays principle in relation to telephone or Australia Post services in the country. Already people are paying significantly higher telephone rentals in some areas. Some telephone rentals are in the order of $500 a year now. If the user pays principle came into country areas, country people would pay on average about $200 a year more for their telephone rentals than they do now. If the user pays principle really came into country areas some people would pay $15,000 and more for the installation of a telephone.
I want to make one or two other remarks about Victoria. The State of Victoria is sad, very sad, when one looks at it from any point of view. It is a sad State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Geelong is all right.

—Yes, apart from the football team mentioned by my colleague Senator Grimes, which is the brightest jewel in the Victorian crown, the State of Victoria is in a very sad situation. It is at the eye of the economic storm in this country. It is at the eye of the economic downturn.
—It is worse than South Australia.

—Yes, it is worse than South Australia. It leads all States in the downward spiral of Government performance. In dealing with the State of Victoria, let me briefly turn to our absent colleague, Senator Lewis, who, if I might say so, typifies everything that is wrong with my State. Senator Lewis was in Ballarat last week and he explained to the worthy burghers of Ballarat through the columns of the Ballarat Courier that Telecom had a brilliant record over the past five years. It is the only organisation, he said, which has not put up prices since 1975, a fact which he seemed to attribute to the policies of the present Government. Senator Lewis went on to say that Telecom should not have a greater borrowing capacity. I am sorry he was not present for the tabling of the report in this chamber but I just commend to him a thorough reading of it because I hope the next time he goes to Ballarat-he describes himself as the Government's representative in Ballarat; I would have thought anyone who said that would need to wear dark glasses-he will tell the people what is happening to them in terms of Telecom's charges and in respect of the installation of new telephones.

SPEECH.PARA: In June 1975 there were no deferred applications for the installation of new phones in Ballarat. As at April 1981 there had been an increase of 337 per cent in the number of deferred applications for the installation of new telephones in Ballarat. The time taken to complete the installation of phones has increased by 74 per cent. Those figures are available on a town by town basis in answers to questions which have been put in this Parliament. Those figures for Ballarat are repeated across the country in regional towns. I hope, as I have said, that when people like Senator Lewis receive complaints about this sort of thing they tell the truth about Government policies and tell the truths which are revealed in the report now before this Senate.

It is interesting to note that in relation to demand for new services, which is dealt with at page 6 of the report called 'Service and Business Outlook for 1981-82', all States have remained static except Queensland where demand has increased. Queensland senators are to be congratulated no doubt on their efforts in stimulating that additional demand. Only in Victoria has demand for new telephone services declined. The decline in demand for these services in Victoria reflects the general economic malaise in that State and the great sadness which has fallen upon us down there. The State was once the brightest jewel in the crown of liberalism, as I recall the single eloquent phrase of Sir Henry Bolte during his long career. That situation of course has all changed and when people like Senator Lewis talk about Telecom to the people of Ballarat they should put some of these figures to them and should consult this sort of report which is now before the Senate. People such as Senator Baume should be more diligent in persuading the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) that any real debate about Telecom has to take place on the basis of honest assessment of the facts and independent evidence which have not been made available to this Parliament but which ought to be made available. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Annual reports of companies, departments and commissions such as the Repatriation Commission sometimes make fascinating reading and sometimes do not. One of the problems is that in this place we always get them just before we are due to speak and therefore our reading of them is usually fairly cursory. What one can say about this report is that it is certainly well printed; it has a nice cover.
