But there are some things in the fairly sketchy report which I think we should look at and ask the Minister to comment on at some time.

That section of the report headed 'Introduction and highlights' concentrates heavily on the increased work load associated with repatriation functions. The interesting comment for those who take an interest in the matter is that the report says again that all indications point to no significant change in the work load of the Repatriation Commission for many years despite the time that has elapsed since the last big war. It says that new initiatives have been added, and this contributes to the work load. It says that another factor in the work load is the drastically increased time taken to process claims and appeals because of the new administrative changes which were introduced last year and the year before and which were not accompanied by increased staff or improved methods to cope with those administrative processes. The Commission in fact reports that it is aware of the present unsatisfactory position in relation to times taken to process claims and appeals and it is doing all it can to overcome the problem. However, it is likely to be some time, says the Commission, before the position will be satisfactory. I am sure that every member of this Parliament will realise how unsatisfactory the present situation is in the Department of Veterans' Affairs in relation to appeals and the processing of claims. It certainly is not satisfactory to the ex-service organisations of this country or to those of us who, repeatedly, receive letters on the subject.

As the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I receive many complaints about the inordinate delays that have been occurring, although many of the changes to the legislation were meant to overcome such delays. Certainly, the vast majority of the representations made to me in my capacity as shadow Minister concern delays. Some cases go back for years. Some of the veterans who are involved are not even alive by the time their cases are finally heard. This is not a satisfactory state of affairs and it is becoming worse. As the Commission makes clear, that situation will continue. It is an example not only of justice not being done but also of justice not being seen to be done. For instance, in 1980 some 7,053 entitlement claims were outstanding but, at 30 June 1981, some 9,483 were outstanding. In 1980 3,122 applications for increased disability allowance were outstanding. As of 30 June 1981, some 4,099 were outstanding. At the end of 1980, some 2,260 appeals to the Repatriation Commission were outstanding. As at the end of June 1981, some 2,999 were outstanding. Thus, the picture, as far as appeals and administrative functions of the Department are concerned, is not good. That fact has been noted on many occasions by veterans and their representatives.

For the first time, the report contains a section-it is two pages in length-which is devoted to the health of Vietnam veterans, a subject which did not even make the report last year. One hopes that it is an indication that the Government at last realises that specific and special problems are suffered by those who fought in Vietnam, but there is a long way to go. That is why some honourable senators are interested in the Senate's taking over the role that the Government should be fulfilling in the matter and instituting its own inquiry. Certainly, an epidemiological study has been instituted but to date the pilot study involves only 600 veterans of the 40,000 who served in Vietnam. Doubt has been cast on the methodology employed and the difficulties which will be created by trying to undertake a survey of that type.

The report notes that recent initiatives include the establishment of a special unit within the Department to monitor Australian and overseas studies of exposure to toxic chemicals such as herbicides. I am certainly glad to see this happening and to find that at last the Minister admits that something is going on. Earlier this year, I tabled the so-called Fleming report in the Senate. That report deals with overseas and Australian literature on problems attendant upon the use of herbicides. It originated in the Minister's Department and deals specifically with these matters, but the Minister spent most of his time arguing that the document was not a report and resisted strongly any suggestion that it should be made public. At least the Department admits now that there is a problem and that it has a special unit to report on such documents, no matter what the Minister may call them.

The other initiative listed in the report is a counselling service. That is welcomed but is essentially a capital city type of setup. I believe it has been ineffective in counselling Vietnam veterans, many of whom, it seems, contemplate committing, or have succeeded in committing, suicide because of the remoteness or ineffectiveness of the Department in handling their problems. I believe that this hastily established service will encounter difficulties.

The report, like all such reports, suffers from having been prepared prior to the presentation of the Budget and immediately thereafter becoming out of date in respect of benefits and allowances. There have been changes in benefits and allowances and we will be able to discuss these when the Government finally brings down the legislation for their implementation.

One chapter is entitled 'The International Year of Disabled Persons'. It provides a very good example for those who are interested of the way in which a department will write a chapter to fill a few pages in a report but not take much notice of what it is doing. The chapter begins:

During the International Year of Disabled Persons, public attention has focused on the problems and needs of the disabled. This concern should not fade as the year ends, but rather, 1981 should be the beginning of new solutions, new awareness and a new understanding.

That is the standard introduction to any document written on the International Year of Disabled Persons. The chapter then goes on rather surprisingly to point out that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has actually been dealing with disabled persons since 1920, and gives two examples-its treatment of strokes and its treatment of amputees, but upon being read it is seen as obviously a fill-in chapter-something thrown together to help fill the report.

Finally, I note that some 200 medical papers are presented. Many are of obvious value to repatriation patients, but one or two I would be fascinated to read in order to ascertain their association with the Repatriation Commission. One is entitled 'The Menstrual Cycle, Personality and Academic Performance'. Another is called 'A Very Unusual Worm', and yet another 'A Funny Yoke-Tale of an Unscrewed Pin'. But I can find no papers relating specifically to the problems of Vietnam veterans. There are no papers on the effects of toxic chemicals, nor are there any on the so-called post-traumatic stress syndrome, which the Minister would have us believe explains all of the symptoms associated with Vietnam veterans-symptoms which some veterans believe may be related to their exposure to herbicides. The closest that we come to the problems of Vietnam veterans in the papers presented under the auspices of the Commission is one entitled, 'The Role of Life Events in Depressive Illness. Is there a substantial causal relation?' I daresay there may be some reference in that paper to the Vietnam veterans but it would seem that most of the papers presented deal not at all with the problems of this very important, young and neglected section of our ex-service community. During the Estimates committee hearings my colleagues and I will pursue many of the matters raised in the report. I hope that the Minister will be able to fill in many of the gaps that it leaves unfilled. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

Honourable senators will know of the publications program and appreciate its high standard. I make these publications available to groups within my electorate. In September 1970 an approach was made to the Federal Government for funding. I should perhaps refer to the document itself to inform the Senate of what happened from then on. In September 1970 Mrs Marie Breen approached the Minister for Social Services, the Honourable W. C. Wentworth, regarding Commonwealth funding. I move ahead to 3 May 1972, where the report notes:
Letter to Mr Wentworth from Mr Malcolm Fraser (Minister for Education and Science)-
Who now has other responsibilities in Australia-
commending the significance of the proposal but unable to offer funds from the Education grant. Other sources of funding proved unsuccessful.

We had to wait until May 1975 when Senator Murphy's Family Law Bill provided for the Institute. The present Government does not come out of this situation with a great deal of commendation, if one might put it that way. On the matter of funding, the report had this to say:

If we read through the document it becomes clear, if we do not see the implications in that brief statement, that there is inadequate funding both for resources and for staffing, particularly for the latter. DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF REVIEW ON MIGRANT ASSESSMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report of the Committee of Review on Migrant Assessment is a moderately lengthy one and, of course, we have not had the opportunity to read it in great detail. It is a report of a committee which was appointed six months ago, on 6 March, with Dr Charles Price of the Australian National University as chairman. It was set up to review the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System and our immigration policy. Some issues which arise out of the report should be looked at carefully. The Committee pointed out that there is strong support in the community for some form of selection based on factors known or believed to determine settlement success, and that family reunion is one of the strongest components in the success of settling migrants. There has been a strong demand from the ethnic communities to take this factor into account. It has been of major emphasis in the Australian Labor Party policy, which has stated also that in an immigration policy at a level consistent with national interest and humanitarian obligations, family reunion must have a high priority. We persist with that view and we are glad that the Committee report subscribes to it.

The Committee also found a knowledge of the English language was desirable but that there is a strong feeling in the migrant community that the present emphasis within NUMAS requirements for English language capability is unfairly discriminatory. It certainly is discriminatory and will become even more discriminatory if a good knowledge of English before the migrant comes here is a major determinant in an immigration policy. However, because some facility with the English language is considered in this report, and of course by everybody, to be a major determinant of settlement success in this country, the Committee has raised the very important issue of the need for more resources to be put into post-arrival services and social security. If one is to achieve settlement success, one needs to do everything one can in this country to ensure that success. It is necessary to provide assistance so that people can increase their facility with English and also it is necessary to provide social security assistance when they first come here.

In fact, there has been a decline in post-arrival services for migrants under this Government. For instance, in order to match the allocation for migrant education under Labor's last year in government, this Government would have to spend an additional $37m this year. The Department of Social Security has reduced its migrant services section and its interpreter services section, and is now told to contract out to the private profit sector its translation services. All these factors will affect to some extent the post-arrival settlement of migrants and will make things difficult for them and therefore difficult for the rest of the community.

It should be noted that the expensive W. D. Scott report on the Information Needs of Migrants has been totally ignored by the Government, the most recent example being the refusal by the Government to use television and radio, as recommended by that report, to inform migrant workers of their rights under the new health care arrangements. This refusal to use the most effective media-it is well known to be the most effective-will make life difficult for those in the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health who are trying to get some success of what is a very difficult and almost impossible health scheme.

In the administration of NUMAS, the highest points are given to professional and trade qualifications, the demand for prearranged employment, and transferrable assets. In considering personal and settlement factors, the criteria are very much more subjective. Marks are awarded for preparedness to settle, responsiveness, initiative, presentation and adaptability, whatever all those things mean to various people. Family unity and sponsorship earn far fewer credit points. The Committee's task included an appraisal of the consistency of these subjective criteria in the application of NUMAS. In general, the Committee found that there is a high degree of consistency in the scores at different immigration posts overseas. However, there is an interesting point in that the ability to issue what are called catch-up points to candidates who do not score an immigration approval on the NUMAS points score was used fairly restrictively. In the survey, 95 per cent of cases from Athens, 78 per cent of cases from Rome, and 76 per cent of cases from Belgrade had relatives or friends here, but insufficient use was made of the catch-up scheme for people of low score, despite an official policy of relaxation of the NUMAS guidelines in these circumstances.

The Committee sought participation with contacted organisations in Australia through the ethnic communities director and the ethnic media, but both these organisations, with the publication from the ethnic media, were casualties of the razor gang. As we pointed out at the time, this was a pathetic penny-pinching exercise. One could even describe it as censorship. It prevents ethnic groups knowing how other ethnic groups view Government policies in relation to attitudes to and experiences of NUMAS. Exchanges between various communities, and exchange of information in particular, are very important.

Inevitably, in the cross-section of views which were presented to the Committee there were totally contradictory bases of belief. For instance, some people believed that migration should be restricted to white Christians, others that migration should be completely non-discriminatory. Some said that migration disrupts employment, others said that migration generates unemployment. There was that sort of generalisation all the way through. It is important that, although a majority of submissions in all categories stated that NUMAS was not working satisfactorily, the Committee disagreed and found that the policies were consistently applied. I believe that, on the basis of this report, it is not likely that the Government will drastically review its policies. The Opposition, through its spokesman, Mr Young, was prepared to take a bipartisan approach on this matter, but we certainly echo the reservations of the ethnic communities, who have continually expressed concern about the restrictive nature of and the Anglo-Saxon emphasis on migrant recruitment and particularly on migrant approvals.

We also endorse the findings of the Committee that the maintenance guarantee system at present in operation should be discontinued, firstly because it does not work satisfactorily; secondly, because it is not administered satisfactorily; and thirdly, because it causes considerable distress amongst migrant groups, as any senator or member who deals with the migrant community would know. Any immigration policy should encourage people who need and want to migrate to Australia and can be seen as contributing to our national interest. Because many sections of our community now are not Anglo-Saxon, consideration should be given to weighing not only the points system outside the country but also the support systems which are here for migrants and to which governments can contribute. If we are to develop a proper migration policy we must not do what we have done in recent years, that is, neglect the post-settlement services to migrants.

Equally, we must make sure that the debate amongst both the ethnic communities and in this Parliament is an informed and sensible one. I point out that a Public Service committee has recently produced a special report entitled 'The Commonwealth as an Employer of Migrants'. It is a report on a subject which is of great interest to us in this Parliament and to the community. If anyone should be showing a good example in the employment of migrants it is the Government, and it is important that we are able to see what is being done and how successful it is. However, the Government has decided that, although this report is not secret, journalists may have a copy of it only if they do not quote from it.

According to the Commonwealth Public Service Board, 21 recommendations were listed in this special report and these have been brought to the notice of every Federal Minister. The Board states that the recommendations are aimed at achieving equal employment opportunities for anyone of ethnic background, either currently employed or seeking employment in the Federal Public Service. That is a noble aim. However, it states that journalists will not be given a copy of the special report if they intend to quote from it. It says that the report is not secret, but it will be given to journalists only on condition that it is not quoted from and is used only as background. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs says that the report is simply a working document which could easily be taken out of context if anyone thought that it had official Government approval.

It is this sort of attitude by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, other departments and the Government which I find very difficult to understand. What they are saying is that they have reports that they consider and from which they make policy. They are not secret reports, they can be taken away and read. They can be used somehow as background briefing, but they must not be quoted from because the general public is not bright enough to understand that these are background reports and that if they are quoted from directly the general public may be misled in some strange way. I see no reason at all why members of this Parliament or members of the public in general cannot see the reports, see the results of Government decisions made as a result of those reports, and make a rational judgment themselves. The best way to make something seem mysterious or sinister in this community is to put 'confidential' or 'secret' on it or put ridiculous restrictions on it such as that. Quite obviously, most journalists will not accept the report under those conditions. They will do what I intend to do, that is, acquire a copy of the report in some other way and then quote from it as freely as I like.

I think that it is absolutely nonsensical, if we are to have informed debate in this community and in this Parliament and if we are to judge properly the validity of the decisions made by the Government, that we receive information such as this so that we can weigh up the facts, weigh up the various opinions, and make our own decisions. I am sure that the general public can do that. We are a democracy. We allegedly have freedom of information of some sort in this country. Presumably we are sufficiently educated and have sufficient judgment to make up our own minds, and for the Government to impose silly restrictions-and I suggest that those restrictions have been imposed at the behest of the Public Service Board or someone in the bureaucracy-on reports such as this merely clouds the issue, makes sinister those things that are not sinister, confuses those things that are not confusing, and merely demonstrates, I believe, the lack of confidence the Government has in its own decisions and the information on which it makes those decisions.

I hope that everyone reads the report and considers it carefully. I am sure that it will be looked at with great interest in the ethnic communities. I believe I am to be followed by my colleague Senator Mulvihill, so I will leave it to him to continue the debate.

I hope that the next program will have more relativity regarding the various continents in which political suppression is the order of the day.

The only other point I make is that one of the issues refers to representations from some State and Territory governments for special concessions for migrants prepared to settle in those parts of Australia where population growth is most desirable. In conclusion I say that I hope it will not be too long before the Minister replies to these semi-findings. The speech read as follows:

The main purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the amendments to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act forecast in the statement the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) made to the Parliament on 14 May 1981.
It may assist honourable senators in their understanding of the problems that are to be resolved if I were to briefly explain the essential background.

For many years, contributions and retirement benefits payable under the Defence Force scheme have been calculated by reference to the rate of salary payable in respect of the substantive rank held by members. Additional salary paid on the basis of a higher acting or temporary rank has been disregarded for defence force retirement benefits and defence force retirement and death benefits purposes mainly because of the transitory nature of the acting and temporary rank arrangements.

In May 1980, the Federal Court of Australia decided, however, that the intended link between 'rank' as defined in the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act and the annual rates of pay regulations made under that Act had not been properly established.

Accordingly, as the legislation now stands, acting and temporary rank rates of pay are to be taken into account for both contributions and benefits purposes in respect of all service rendered since the commencement of the scheme on 1 October 1972.

As a consequence, a relatively small number of pensioners, estimated to be of the order of 550, are entitled to higher retirement benefits; and a very large number of both pensioners and serving members are required to pay additional contributions without any corresponding increase in benefits.
I turn now, to the practical effects of the Bill before the Parliament.

First, it restores to the scheme, with effect from 14 May 1981, the original intention that members contributions and retirement benefits be calculated on the basis of the annual rate of pay applicable to substantive rank held by the member during service.
Second, it makes special provision for all those persons who during the currency of the present scheme have held acting or temporary rank, in the way I go on to explain.

Pensioners entitled to additional pension benefits will be paid these benefits in full, including any available commutation amounts, from the date of their retirement. As from 14 May 1981 however, their pensions will be adjusted by reverting to what they would have been if calculated according to the substantive rank held on retirement and taking account of any additional commutation lump sums received.

The pensioners to whom I have just referred, that is those in receipt of or entitled to an additional benefit, will be required to pay additional contributions based on their acting or temporary rank rate of pay but only in respect of that period of acting or temporary rank service that immediately preceded their retirement.

All additional contributions that would otherwise be payable in respect of acting or temporary rank are waived. In other words, only persons who retired or died while holding acting or temporary rank and qualify for higher levels of pension benefits are liable to pay additional contributions to the limited extent that I have indicated, and currently serving members will not be disadvantaged by having to pay higher contributions in future because of their temporary higher rank status.

The other amendments for which the opportunity has been taken to include in the Bill, involve the rationalisation of the provisions relating to pensioners who re-enter the Defence Force. They are designed principally to cut down the high costs of additional pension and commutation benefits that so frequently become payable to pensioners who re-enter the scheme for relatively brief periods.
In summary, they provide that only pensioners who re-enter on an appointment or engagement for a period of not less than one year shall again become contributors to the scheme.

On their second or subsequent retirement they will be entitled to appropriate pension increments for their additional service but be excluded from further access to the commutation provisions. They will no longer be required, however, to repay portion of their commutation proceeds during their period of additional service.

Pensioners who re-enter for brief periods of less than one year will not again become contributing members: Nor will their retirement pensions be cancelled on re-entry as is currently the case. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Robert Ray, I remind the Senate that this is his first speech in his chamber and I would ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him. I now call Senator Robert Ray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can only really understand these Bills in the overall context of the Budget. It is a contention of the Australian Labour Party that the Budget will do little to restore prosperity in Australia. Of course, we are not the only critics of the Budget. The Bank of New South Wales, which has been no friend of the Labor Party over the years has said that the Federal Government's Budget strategy is based on an economic gamble. It goes on to say that the Budget will prove to be inflationary instead of bearing down on inflation and the money supply will have to grow faster than the Government has budgeted. The Bank of New South Wales goes on to say that the Budget is a catalogue of economic paradoxes which calls for wage restraint yet relies on inflationary growth of average weekly earnings to bring down a sizable Budget surplus. It is bad enough if that sort of conservative institution does not like the Budget, but let us have a look at the views of a former Liberal Party Treasurer and Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The underlying assumption in the Budget was the need to take fiscal and monetary steps to dampen down expansion and enthusiasm. This policy no longer sits easily with the necessity for economic growth. Nor is it consistent with the economic and financial facts that are now becoming public.

Of course, there are many features of the Budget that we on this side of the Senate would disagree with but it is probably more appropriate today to concentrate on a few of them. Our most obvious objection, of course, is to sales tax. The Labor Party opposes the sales tax increases contained in this Budget. We concede that indirect taxation is inevitable in our present society but see little reason why it should be increased now or in the future. It is a regressive form of taxation. If one is a low income earner, one pays exactly the same amount of sales tax as someone on a high income. If one wants to buy a new car, the sales tax for someone on $10,000 a year is exactly the same as for someone on $30,000 or $40,000 a year. There is absolutely no equity in this case.

It is sometimes argued by Government members that in fact the consumer has a choice whether to buy. This would be more appropriate if the items being taxed were merely luxury goods, but of course, as we all know, it covers such a wide spectrum of goods that the consumer has no choice but to actually purchase products and pay sales tax. No family can avoid buying shoes or buying clothes and the prices of these will go up. Indeed, whilst it is claimed that food is exempt, the price of food will go up merely because nearly all food is packaged and there is sales tax on packaging. I suppose the consumer could at least decide not to buy any dog soap, which will now be 17 1/2 per cent dearer. We will probably have a lot of dirty dogs running around the country, if not running the country. One of the most iniquitous areas of sales tax will be the tax on knowledge-a tax on books and newspapers. I believe Lord Willis adequately summed it up when he said:
I think it is one of the most scandalous things I have ever heard of.

Maybe now only the private schools will be able to afford books and I hope that does not please any of those opposite. It is a rather strange Government that six months ago could claim that it was not going to introduce more indirect taxation, and this at a time when the value added tax and various retail taxes were being considered, and then indicate that it would not be an appropriate thing to do. We now have a situation where a few months later the Government is introducing sales tax on a range of goods never before covered and increasing the actual level of sales tax on many other goods. In May, consultation was promised with the Confederation of Australian Industry before any such changes were to be made in this area. The way in which the Government has introduced these taxes is causing great dislocation in industry. We now seem to have a situation where the Government seems to be trying to fight inflation by lifting prices. There is no doubt that the sales tax increases will be passed on to the consumers as manufacturers have said they simply cannot absorb the costs. As a result, the consumer price index will increase and any chance of reducing interest rates in the immediate future will go by the board.

The Labor Party is therefore going to oppose the sales tax Bills when they come into the Senate. We have asked for support from others and, of course, it has not been forthcoming. The argument that if the Senate rejected the sales tax proposals it would be creating a 1975 situation is ludicrous. We are talking about 1.25 per cent of revenue: The domestic surplus is about three times this level. We are not talking about catastrophically interfering with the Budget. The proposal by the Australian Democrats to add a meaningless amendment to the Budget will probably get a good laugh in the House of Representatives, especially as the Democrats have already indicated that they will pass the Budget, unamended, a second time. Such cream puff grandstanding fails to come to terms with the real issues of sales tax. I further find it rather difficult to understand how a credible political party can take eight days to determine what their principles are. Certainly we in the Labor Party do not have to consult a lawyer to establish what our principles are. Probably the West Australian Democrat President, Mr Geoff Taylor, was quite correct in what he said about the Democrats' attitude to sales tax-and I am glad that shallow thinking has not prevailed and he has not been removed from office.

If honourable senators want evidence that this Government is incapable of handling the Australian economy, they need look no further than the sorry story of interest rates. Skyrocketing rates of interest have made it impossible for four out of every five Australians seeking savings bank loans for their first homes. Since the beginning of the 1980-81 financial year, over $1,000m has been loaded on to the cost of home purchases. This has cruelly eaten into the spending capacity of many Australian families. The money tied up on loan and mortgage commitments has been denied to the consumer market place. It is ironic that this Government, which has from time to time claimed to represent small business and the farmer, has done more than anyone to depress the money market.

Bill Hayden has identified Australia as possessing the dubious distinction of having the second highest real rate of interest in the world-just marginally behind the United States of America. Yet, tragically, this Government has budgeted for a domestic surplus of over $1.5 billion. This simple failure to spend in a productive way what the Government intends to take in through the highest taxes in Australia's history is, I believe, a bitter indictment of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party. They have run up a massive trade deficit and the Budget implies the only solution is an uncontrolled flood of foreign capital.

The current account deficit of $6,700m is estimated, in the Budget's figures, to be covered by a $7,000m capital inflow over 1981-82. Relying on this level of foreign intervention in our national economy may be not only unwise but also irresponsible. At any rate, where does this money go? In large part, the experience is that this money is invested in stock exchange speculation, real estate speculation and in the buying up of profitable commercial and industrial operations. This Government is quite content to see continued pressure on short term interest rates to rise. It has done nothing to lower long term interest rates. We may well question the accuracy of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) when he predicted a growth in the money supply for 1981-82 of 10 to 11 per cent.

The Government's sanctimonious calls for wage restraint sit uneasily with the conservatives' dependence on growth in weekly earnings to boost tax receipts. At the lauded wages summit, Australian Council of Trade Unions President, Cliff Dolan, expressed the common-sense approach of Australian wage and salary earners: There can be no promise of wage restraint unless relief is given in the areas of interest rates and taxation. Since then, home loan interest rates have gone up by one per cent and there have been no alterations to the tax scales. In addition, wide increases in indirect taxation, the most regressive form, have been announced. How can restraint possibly be justified?

The average Australian is losing the interest battle. For many people the last increase was the last straw. If families do not sell up, the pressure will be on the mortgage holders to do so. The budgets of many Australians are tightly fixed to the whole repayment syndrome, especially on homes. For many, the emotional and material needs of life have been subjected to trying to keep up with the interest spiral. This problem hits Australians regardless of their social position. In fact, its impact, if anything, is greater on those assuming middle class expectations and life styles. Local families have been forced voluntarily to surrender their homes because they just cannot keep up any more, something unheard of in good Liberal voting suburbs 10 years ago. Perhaps now the traditional supporters of the Government are beginning to see with their own eyes the dead end of conservative policies. The upwardly socially mobile are beginning on the long road down.

The Government has made room for the speculators and the quick profit merchants by consciously and deliberately undermining the spending power and the community security of Australians. The result will be, as it has been since the Fraser Government took office, the lowering of living standards. Members of the Financial Counsellors Association of Australia have testified to the incredible financial, social and psychological pressures imposed on families by rising interest rates. One counsellor in the outer-eastern Melbourne suburb of Dandenong has told how three of every four families dealt with have credit of over $20,000 excluding the home. Only 18 months ago the figure was around $10,000. I wonder whether there is any honourable senator opposite who would be prepared to swap places with one of those families? Forty years ago, Menzies founded the Liberal Party on his appeal to the so-called 'forgotten people'-the Australian middle class. Key to it was the legendary importance in Australian life of owning one's own home. Today the Liberals have betrayed their heritage. If Menzies were alive today, I am sure he would be amazed to find that his party no longer shares his understanding of the Australian dream of home ownership.

High interest rates have slashed lending for home construction. This Budget will further increase home costs. I have a horrible feeling that this Government, sheltered in the cloisters of Canberra and easy prey to ideological cranks, just does not know what impact the interest rate explosion is having on the community. The mirage of a resource-led economic boom has blinded it to the impossible situation of Australians locked into credit repayments. The Federal Government's sabotaging of the housing industry does not end just with rising interest rates and sales tax on building materials. The Housing Industry Association has attacked the Federal Government over the Budget. One of its representatives, Mr Bill Kirkby Jones, has said that the housing sector is being asked to bear an unfair share of monetary restraint. He goes on to say that the Government refuses to heed industry advice and is unwilling to restore home ownership opportunities. The Victorian Minister for Local Government, Mr Lieberman, has joined the critics of the Commonwealth Government. He says the Commonwealth can easily afford to offer assistance to young families-that it would not break the bank.

Yet by far the most dramatic criticism has come from the Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Kennett. This has come as quite a shock to those who follow Victorian politics as Mr Kennett has always been regarded as one of the troglodytes of the Victorian Liberal Party; an arch conservative who has shown very little compassion over the years for the underprivileged. Quite clearly, being given the portfolio of Housing and actually having to see what welfare housing is all about has sparked some sort of sense of social conscience in this rebel Liberal. I refer this explanation for his conversion and discount those rather unkind people who say that he is just trying to save a discredited State Government. Mr Kennett has pointed out that it is an absolute disgace that the Federal Government has cut Budget allocations for housing from $285m in 1980-81 to $250m this financial year. He has further pointed out that, as far as Victoria is concerned, there is a $7m loss. Whilst we might be getting $58m, at the same time we are repaying the Commonwealth Government $65m for previous housing loans. In other words, the Commonwealth is making $7m in excess of what it is paying out this year. This led to the situation in which Mr Kennett made the following rather startling statement:
The Federal Government, instead of investing in homes that provide security and satisfactory living conditions, are more willing to let families be destroyed and then pay the cost.
I think that bears repeating. He said:
The Federal Government, instead of investing in homes that provide security and satisfactory living conditions, are more willing to let families be destroyed and then pay the cost.

Mr Kennett telexed Senator Harradine and the Australian Democrats asking for the Senate to do something about the situation. Honourable senators will note that he has not telexed the Labor Party, as he quite rightly assumes that the Labor Party is concerned about housing and that its policies naturally are for increased expenditure in this area. He has not wasted the cost of a telex on us as he is so certain of our support. Mr Kennett finds it hard to understand the Government's inhumane attitude to housing. I would, of course, suggest to Mr Kennett that the Government should reduce the amount of stamp duty on home purchases in his own State. He might also combine with the Federal Government, as I earlier indicated, to do something about the interest payments that many people in Melbourne's suburbs are finding very difficult to meet.

The whole housing area raises one of the greatest dilemmas in Australian politics today, and that is the constant buck-passing between Federal and State governments. The Federal Government says, quite often, that this is a State matter, whilst at the same time not supplying enough money for the States to pay for this area. In turn, the States continually bleat about the Commonwealth not providing enough money and not accepting responsibilities in these sorts of areas. This constant buck-passing between Federal and State governments is quite often a cynical political exercise in which one or the other can drum up some political support. We had the situation where the Premier of Victoria, who was previously Treasurer, last year sent out Christmas cards complaining about the inequity of Victoria's share of taxation.

I think one can come to only one of two conclusions about this matter. Either the Federal Government, the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and the Treasurer are completely mean individuals, totally unfair to Victoria and secretly supporters of the State Labor Party or the Victorian representatives who come to Premiers Conferences are simply poor negotiators; people who cannot get a fair share for Victoria. I really do wonder what the community is going to think in the next State election, when the Federal Liberals come down to campaign for their State colleagues. After all the aggro, after all the criticism of the Federal Government from the State Government, no doubt they will join ranks just for a pitiful five or six weeks and then go back to their normal buck-passing exercise.

Another matter that has seen Federal-State antagonism has been the matter of health. Australia has lurched into its fifth new health scheme like some punch drunk fighter. Since Medibank was introduced by Labor several years ago, every counter move in this field by the Liberal-National Country Party Government has been directed towards the lowering of community health standards. Since the conservatives grabbed power in 1975, Commonwealth health outlays have decreased by over 20 per cent in real terms. In fact, in this Budget, Commonwealth health funding itself has dropped by over 20 per cent. Certainly, allocation has been made for payments to the States, and overall there has been a 10 per cent increase in expenditure.

The Government has presented an unjustifiable bonus to private insurance funds. It has forced medical and hospital benefits into the ideological strait-jacket of the 'user pays' philosophy. It has failed to meet the responsibilities of a government in the twentieth century. The facts are as follows: Most families are being compelled to pay from $9 to $11 a week as the result of the health insurance changes; State governments have been forced to impose the means test on their public hospital services; charges have been increased for standard ward accommodation; and charges have been introduced for medical services and outpatients. In contrast, the Australian Labor Party is proud of its commitment to a universal health insurance scheme. Under the Liberals, basic medical and hospital cover is hitting the average family for $10 a week-$500 a year. When Labor introduced the original Medibank, this basic insurance was provided for the entire community as a right in a civilised country.

According to the latest Gallup Poll in the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial of 2 September 56 per cent of Victorians oppose the health insurance changes introduced by this Government. Forty-two per cent believed that the private funds did not provide value for money. Yet the Liberals are forcing families to pay a new tax to the tune of $1,200m a year not to the Government but direct to the private insurance funds. A quarter of the community previously covered by public health is now dipping into its pocket to build up private insurance empires. There is no thought given to the relative capacity of each family or individual to pay. Taking consideration of that capacity is the central plank of Labor's health platform. Health services financed through taxation or Medibank contributions are graded on overall capacity to pay. Health insurance hits everyone the same. In other words, those most in need are hit hardest. This is not the Labor Party's concept of social justice.

Pious claims of small government do not work when we are talking about the health of the community. Even with 20 per cent of the people entitled to health care cards through their disadvantaged or pensioner status, the bureaucracy just does not work. On the first day of the new scheme, almost one million Victorians were without proper health care. There are 200,000 Victorian families eligible for free health care but only 6,000 cards, covering 25,000 people, had been issued prior to the operation of the new scheme. Tens of thousands of Victorians are still ignorant of their free health status or are unable because of their situation, to handle the bureaucracy and prove their rights. We are back to square one, perhaps even worse than the pre-Medibank arrangements, when less than a third of those entitled to government assistance actually got what was their right. Just as bad is the arbitrary definition of the 'disadvantaged'. The Government has refused to implement any sort of progressive scale; it prefers the hard and fast cut off point, regardless of the injustices that it inevitably involves.

More and more we are leaning towards the American health system, if only for the satisfaction of the Government's libertarian pretensions. Yet no one could argue that the United States is a desirable model in the health field when 9.5 per cent of the American gross domestic product is spent on health, largely through the sort of funds that we are seeing emerge in Australia. This compares with 6 per cent of the British national product devoted to its national health scheme. It is impossible to believe, presuming that one is rational, that the average American is 50 per cent better off in health services. Even if one has to queue under a national health service, one gets efficient treatment when it is needed. There is no incentive, as there will be with fee for service insurance, for unnecessary or excessive treatment or surgery. Because doctors are in a position to boost health services to their own advantage, the cost of health care will rise and keep on rising.

The Health Minister, Mr MacKellar, has said that people who found it hard to pay health insurance should give up smoking and going to the TAB. The only joy left to these poor souls will come every three years when they trudge off to the polling booth and vote against the MacKellars of this world. No Government has treated its own enterprises with such contempt as this one. To destroy an efficient government organisation to satisfy some nebulous political philosophy will be to the disadvantage of all Australians. The belief that people in the Public Service are non-productive and that prosperity will only be generated by private enterprise is totally false.

The sale of the Coburg Clothing Factory and the Bendigo Ordnance Factory at bargain prices to ideological cronies will do nothing for the Australian economy. One of the most blatant examples of the Government's mistreatment of its own enterprises is that of Australia Post. We all know that the Australia Post Courier Service ceased operating on 30 June 1981. Here we had an efficient service, profitably run, by no means a monopoly, providing fair competition for private firms. Apparently, the Government does not want to impinge on the profits of its supporters. We will see over the next few years the running down of Australia Post and Telecom; the most profitable areas will be sold off and the non-profitable ones retained. No private firm would want to undertake mail deliveries to remote areas. Australia Post will therefore have to be subsidised from Consolidated Revenue, or differential rates applied to country areas. I hope the National Country Party realises the implication of the Governments destruction of our postal services. It is proposed, in a time of high unemployment, to use private contractors as much as possible, expecially in the area of mail cartage. Some 1,100 jobs could be lost in the Australia Post area. Of course, no one would be sacked, just redeployed to areas that they do find suitable and in due course, it is hoped that they would resign. The reduction in staff and increased mail volume implies a productivity increase in the order of 7 per cent to 10 per cent in one year. The staff ceiling of 31,064 people is totally unrealistic.

Australia Post is considering the following steps if current services are to be maintained: firstly, greater use of part time and casual staff; secondly, the closure of post offices for lunch just when the rest of working people want to use them; thirdly, a rationalisation of postmen's delivery rounds, whatever that means; fourthly, amalgamation of Telegram delivery services; and finally, withdrawal of lightly used street posting boxes. These are all under consideration by the Postal Commission at the moment. The more the Government runs down postal services the more the general public will complain and the more easily the Government will be able to sell off the more profitable areas in Australia Post. The treatment of Australia Post is just one example of the way the Government treats its own enterprises. Similar measures will occur with the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Trans Australia Airlines and other vital Government instrumentalities. The Government should recognise that we are a mixed economy, that there is no private enterprise Camelot and that vital community services cannot be measured by profitability alone.

The clearest example of the Australian Government's abrogation of responsibility to the States is in the field of education. It is in this particular area that State Budgets really feel the strain, with well over 40 per cent of their expenditure going to education. We have at the moment a situation where it appears that the deliberate policy of the Government is to favour non-government schools. When one looks at the figures for 1982, the general recurrent expenditure on government schools stays fixed at $269m whereas capital expenditure is reduced from $131.1m to $124.7m. Now to have a cut in capital of 5 per cent is bad enough. When it is taken over a period since 1976 it can be seen there has been a 36 per cent cut in the capital program for government schools. For non-government schools in this particular year, the general recurrent grants have increased by 11 per cent. Next year, 1982, will be the first year that the non-government school program will absorb more funds than the government school program.

Having taught in the government school system, and having visited many schools, it becomes apparent that education in government schools is being adversely affected by the lack of funds. Many of Victoria's high schools are of what is called light temporary construction, built 15, 20 or 30 years ago. Most of them were only supposed to last from between 15 and 25 years. The expenditure by the Victorian Government on cyclical maintenance has been reduced over the years not only in money terms but also real terms. If one tours throughout rural Victoria, or in metropolitan areas, one finds that schools are physically falling apart. Many of the schools are forced to use their school council funds on long term maintenance-something that was never meant to be.

The Labor Party has always taken the attitude that education funding should be on the basis of need. The Government directs funds to non-government schools, whether they need the money or not. It is my contention that a government must look after its own schools, must raise them to a standard where no one would necessarily want to send their child to a private school. It is all very well to argue for freedom of choice in education but if the Commonwealth Government is going to reduce government schools to the level of slums, naturally people will take their children away to private schools. One must congratulate the Government on the occasion of this Budget insofar as it was not leaked in advance. What does trouble me is the degree of objectivity used in framing the Budget. Has this particular Government responded to the interests of its own supporters when framing it? On 27 August 1981, the following excerpt from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald clearly exposed the point I am trying to make. It said:
The Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has been warned by major manufacturing interests who are vital Liberal Party donors that their funds will be withdrawn if the Federal Government cuts tariffs.
The article continued:
One Liberal Party source told the Herald that the interests involved were six figure donors to the Party and come from the backbone of the Party's financial base.

A simple solution to any Government's being blackmailed by its financial backers-I am not suggesting this one is-would be to introduce public funding. There is no provision in this Budget for public funding. I have heard Government members argue that public funding is a waste of taxpayers' money and could be spent better in other areas. This Budget contains many areas that would serve as examples of waste of the taxpayer's money. None more so than the $342,000 being allocated to de-register the Builders Labourers Federation. Since I first pondered on this matter the allocation has grown to $670,000. But even worse is the $5.4m devoted to the Industrial Relations Bureau-a total waste of money on a white elephant that just has not worked. If we are to have honesty in politics I think it is essential that some form of public funding of political parties takes place. In the last election the Liberal and National Country Parties outspent their opponents at a rate of about four to one. The unequal disposition of resources contributed to an unprincipled advertising campaign aimed at deceiving and duping the electorate. Public funding would stop all political parties from being involved in illegal activities as far as fund raising goes. There is not a political party in Australia which at some stage has not been involved in an illegal event in raising money be it a raffle or anything else. It would no longer be necessary for a New South Wales Liberal leader to have to raise money through illegal gambling nights with the equipment supplied by, let us say, undesirable elements. I think that public funding of elections will come, in spite of opposition from the Government. I think it is inevitable. Mr President, you have allowed me a rather free range on the Australian Capital Territory Acts. In conclusion I would like to congratulate you on your assuming office and on behalf of the new honourable senators thank you for the courtesy and help you have given us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take advantage of this first reading debate on the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Amendment Bill 1981, which is a money Bill, to make a number of points on matters which concern me. But before doing so, I extend my congratulations to all those honourable senators on both sides of the House who have made their first contribution in this place. I think all senators concerned did well in the thoughtful contribution they made. Clearly the Senate will be a much better place in view of the calibre of those honourable senators who have made their maiden speeches in this place over the last 24 hours. I congratulate every one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters I want to refer to fairly briefly are matters on which I consider there has been considerable neglect on the part of the Government in its obligation to respond to questions that are raised in this place from time to time. It is not often that I speak on a money Bill. But I am aware of the fact that on numerous occasions honourable senators on both sides, and particularly on the Opposition side, have raised in first reading debates on money Bills matters which they consider to be of some consequence or importance and which do require, I believe, a response from the government of the day. Otherwise it seems to me there is no point in senators utilising the opportunity that is available in a first reading debate on a money Bill to raise matters which in their opinion are of some importance.

I wish to refer to three instances over which I believe the Government has been neglectful and has in fact demonstrated a degree of contempt for the contributions that have been made by senators. Initially I refer to a contribution which has been the subject of some debate in the Senate, that is, the contribution that was made by Senator Primmer on 7 March 1978. Whilst it is true that the Government has taken certain steps now to set in train a royal commission to inquire into this matter, the fact is that it has taken the Government three and a half years to act. It will be four and a half years since the matter was first raised before we will be in a position to act on the statements which were made by Senator Primmer. Detailed as they were and general as they were as well, they did point the finger at what clearly was a very irresponsible attitude in the meat export industry. After all, Senator Primmer did say that over a period a number of meat works, some of which have Commonwealth registration to slaughter for export and others which do not have this registration, had been processing meat for export which had not been inspected by Commonwealth meat inspectors. He also referred to an official complaint that had been made the preceding year in 1976-77 by the Romanian Government which was purchasing beef from us. Senator Primmer also referred to a number of companies which he believed may have been involved in this illegal practice. He at least cast sufficient doubt about this matter to warrant investigation.

I find it incomprehensible that the Commonwealth Police, the then Minister for Primary Industry or responsible Ministers in this House failed to seek to have any explanation from or discussions with Senator Primmer. The consequences have been very grave for the meat export industry of Australia. There were no follow ups. There were no attempts to establish whether any evidence was available from Senator Primmer, whether the evidence that he had could be made available or whether there should be an investigation. His contribution was completely and utterly ignored. Therefore, I think the Government has to accept some censure because of the fact that it failed to respond to what has now been proved to have been fair warning-several years' warning-of the magnitude of the problem. It obviously will have severe repercussions not only in respect of our exports to the United States but also in respect of our exports to Japan and other European countries. Australia's trading reputation has been seriously damaged by the failure of the Government to respond to the allegations. I think it is an indefensible position that the Government did not see fit to delegate any officer from the Department of Primary Industry, the Commonwealth Police, the Department of Administrative Services or the responsible Ministers concerned in this place to establish the veracity or otherwise of the statements that Senator Primmer had made.

I remind the Senate that during the debate on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation legislation similar allegations were made by honourable senators about a number of incidents which they considered to have been breaches of proper conduct by members of ASIO. Again neither the then Attorney-General nor any other member of the Government sought to confirm or deny the allegations. They were just passed over and no action flowed from the Government. I just want to remind the Senate of a third instance in which I believe the Government has been neglectful. On 11 June 1981 I raised in this place a number of serious allegations that had been made to me in respect of a ballot conducted by the Commonwealth Electoral Office in respect of a trade union election. I made the assertion that in one particular post office 380 ballot papers precisely were stolen and in the presence of one or two candidates those ballot papers were then opened and filled in by the candidates themselves. The persons responsible for the conduct of the ballot, the persons to whom the ballot papers should have been delivered, did not receive them. They were not aware of the fact that there was even to be a ballot. As a consequence, as I indicated in my speech, that interference was sufficient to decide the ballot at that time.

I also drew the attention of the Senate to other irregularities that had taken place in respect of postal ballots involving that union. Again, nobody from the Commonwealth Electoral Office, the Commonwealth Police, the Department of Administrative Services or the Attorney-General's Department sought to have any discussions with me about these matters. I have now been informed that in respect of that ballot other irregularities have been discovered. It is true that they are allegations, but I just wonder what is the use of honourable senators consciously drawing the attention of the Senate to these matters if in fact no action follows. We are treated in a way which I find is very unsatisfactory. It is disdainful that we should be put in a position in which, having raised these matters, we have to tell our constituents who ask what has happened about the points that have been made that the Government does not care because the Government has not responded in any shape or form. I think I am entitled to bring these matters to the attention of Ministers. I suggest, when senators do take advantage of opportunities on first readings to raise matters which they consider to be of importance, the matters should at least proceed past the point of just putting them on the Senate record.

The other matter I want to draw to the attention of the Senate is the dispute that is taking place at the moment in the Australian Taxation Office and the apparent failure of the Government and the section of the Treasury that is responsible for the Taxation Office to resolve the current dispute. I think it is a matter of some importance to the Government. It certainly is a matter of considerable importance to taxpayers. Certainly it is a matter of some importance to the employees-they are members of the Federated Clerks Union-who work in the section of the office involved in the dispute and who have seen fit, because of the cutbacks arising from the decision of the razor gang to reduce staff in this section which collects revenue and dissects taxpayers returns, to agree to a go slow resolution, to the placing of an overtime ban and to a work to regulations campaign.

The Government has not seen fit to resolve this matter to the satisfaction of the employees and certainly not, I am sure, to the satisfaction of the Parliament itself. This industrial action is unprecedented and has been taken by the union only as a last resort. It concerns a loss of jobs in the Australian Taxation Office. I do not want to canvass the matter of the razor gang cuts that have been made across the board by the Government. The views of the Opposition on that score have been clearly expressed. We disagree philosophically with the Government's policy in that regard. But surely the Government should consider the consequences of its action in this area of activity-the collection of taxation revenue and its dispersal over a wide range throughout the Commonwealth, to the State Governments and so on. The unions state that the Government's action will affect drastically the collection of tax and will affect equally drastically the professed decision of the Government to stamp out tax evasion. This dispute should not remain unresolved. The Government's decision to cut back on the Public Service should not apply to this section of it, which surely ought not to suffer any reduction in staff whatever.

The union officials concerned met the Treasurer (Mr Howard) back in July to discuss the matter, so the dispute has gone on now for a little more than 2 1/2 months. The unions protested the staff reductions and presented the Treasurer with a petition signed by all of the staff, but it took him five weeks even to respond to it. I do not wish to be too critical of him in that regard because I assume that at the time he was heavily involved in the preparation of the Budget, but I point out that one of the important aspects of the Budget is the collection of revenue. That delay occurred and even when the Treasurer did respond the union considered his answer to be unsatisfactory. Absolutely no positive assurances were given concerning the question of staff reductions.

The point made to the Treasurer by the union representatives-people who are our employees, who are charged with guarding our interests and collecting revenue for the Commonwealth-was that the staff cuts would result in the loss of many millions of dollars in tax revenue. Naturally, as ordinary wage and salary earners, they felt that the failure to overcome tax evasion, which is such a characteristic of the tax system of this country would mean that ultimately they would be called upon to pay a higher rate of taxation. In short they believe that the shortage of staff will prevent the enforcement of the tax laws.

The union is not one that normally resorts to industrial action. It puts into effect what has often been said to be the policy of this Government. A postal ballot of the members of the section was held and decided overwhelmingly to take industrial action because of their opposition to staff cuts in the Australian Taxation Office which pose a threat to their future job security. They will have less staff available to do the work. I believe that is important because the payment of refunds to millions of taxpayers will be affected by the go-slow and other industrial action that is taking place in the Taxation Office. The morale of union members is at a low ebb because, as a result of these staff shortages, they are unable properly to carry out their job. As the president of the union, Mr Paul Tregillis, said: 'You really have to question how serious the present Government is about enforcing the taxation laws'. Although the Treasurer claims to be cracking down on tax avoidance, he is reducing the very staff which deals with outright tax evasion. Mr Tregillis makes the comment that it is a little like a Government claiming that it intends to get tough on law and order and then, as a first step, reducing the numbers of the police force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.30 p.m., pursuant to order of the Senate I now call on General Business.

DEBATE.TITLE: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN ABORIGINALS (RIGHT TO ELECTORAL ENROLMENT) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In May 1980, my colleague Senator Chaney, who was then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, described the Bill that we are debating today-the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill-as 'a totally unsatisfactory approach to the very serious problem which I agree exists, namely, ensuring that Aboriginals freely and fairly exercise their right to vote.'

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse the remarks of my colleague. The Bill is still a totally unsatisfactory approach to a serious problem. The Fraser Government is concerned to ensure that Aboriginals can exercise freely their right to vote. We are concerned that no Australian should be disadvantaged in getting his name on the electoral roll.

The Liberal Party and this Liberal Party Government believe in free, fair and regularly held elections. We believe that all who are entitled to vote, all who are entitled to enrol, should be able so to do. The Government administers an Electoral Act that embodies those principles. The ideal of enrolment which is espoused in this Bill is one with which we agree. We have made an election commitment to change the voluntary electoral enrolment for Aboriginals under the Commonwealth Electoral Act and to make it compulsory. We have done so after consulting, and obtaining the agreement of, the National Aboriginal Conference; so, in terms of the ideal espoused, I do not think there is much argument.

What, then, is the issue on which this Bill is based? Western Australian legislation currently requires that enrolment cards for new voters be witnessed by either an electoral officer, a justice of the peace, a Clerk of the Court or a police officer. I believe that is the crux of the problem. I do not deny that this requirement may be somewhat restrictive and therefore inconvenient, but it is also inconvenient to electors generally in remote areas. It is not an inconvenience which is limited to Aboriginals. I do not deny that Aboriginal people, particularly those in remote areas, may be reluctant to approach, or may be intimidated by, persons eligible to witness enrolment cards. I am aware that these categories of witness may not easily readily be available in remote areas, yet the remedies proposed are for Aboriginals only, not for all who might potentially be disadvantaged by the conditions set out by Senator Walsh.

The Bill that is before us is no solution to the difficulties that I have mentioned. The Bill is ill-considered. It is fraught with constitutional and practical difficulties. What is more, its operation is likely to result in inconsistencies and anomalies, many of which will bring confusion and hardship to the very Aboriginals it is designed to protect.

Before I deal with these problems in detail I question the urgency which Senator Walsh says attaches to this matter. The Bill deals only with Western Australia but no elections are due in that State for another two years. Senator Walsh said that he hoped the Bill would become an Act by the end of this year and he has chosen to bring this matter on for debate now when many other matters, including Budget legislation, are before the Parliament. One might ask: What is the urgency? Why is there a need to press such an ill-considered Bill now? I observed that more than a year ago-in fact, in May of last year-my colleague Senator Chaney informed the Senate that he had received not a single complaint that any Aboriginal had been unable to obtain enrolment in Western Australia. That was after the last Western Australian election. That was after Senator Chaney had drawn attention in the media to the fact that he would be keen to hear whether any Aboriginal had been disadvantaged by not getting access to an appropriate witness.

I have yet to receive one representation from or on behalf of Aboriginal people in Western Australia giving details of anyone who has been unable to get enrolled. There has not been one example, not one complaint, not one instance of a disability which requires relief. There is, as yet, no issue. No disadvantage has accrued to anyone. No one has been deprived of his or her right to vote. There is no issue. There is only a set of rules in relation to witnessing with which Senator Walsh does not agree and which many people may choose to criticise. I understand that these rules and the Act in Western Australia were introduced after an appropriate judicial inquiry. To justify intervention there should be at the very least a real, an immediate, a burning or an important issue. Here there is none.

There is a whole host of undesirable elements of the Bill which is before the Senate today, not the least of which is the way it goes against the nature of our Federal system, a system based upon a Constitution with a sharing of responsibilities. Western Australia is only one State among six. The Government believes we should encourage each of the States to do those things which are theirs to do under the Constitution. Commonwealth intervention before there is an issue-that is the centralists' paradigm-should be a last resort. It should be done only in special circumstances. Interference certainly should not be resorted to, as it is being proposed here, when we have as yet no evidence of disadvantage to a single Aboriginal Western Australian. I find it both totally unnecessary and highly undesirable that we should attempt to confer a Commonwealth franchise on Western Australians for State electoral purposes irrespective of that State's franchise requirements, both present and future, and especially where we cannot say that there has been for any Aboriginal a complaint that he or she has not been able to enrol where he or she wishes so to do. I also find it undesirable that the Bill should seek to impose Commonwealth duties on State electoral officials. This is not something which the Commonwealth does and it is not something which the Commonwealth has done unless it has been with the consent of the State concerned.

Serious administrative difficulties are associated with this Bill. They give rise to doubts as to whether the Bill could be put into effect. They give rise to doubts as to whether the Bill could really be of any assistance to Aboriginals. There are many provisions which would confuse rather than assist Aboriginals in Western Australia. I give some examples: Firstly, the definition of 'Aboriginal' in clause 3 of the Bill does not in express terms include Torres Strait Islanders. What an oversight. Surely Senator Walsh knows that quite a few islander people live in his own State. Perhaps that is just an example of sloppy drafting. Secondly, there are differences in the definition of 'Aboriginal' in the Bill and the State Electoral Act, which might mean that the benefit sought to be conferred by the Bill--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the Uriah Heep of the Senate.

—Hello! We have someone sitting in someone else's seat in the Senate. The benefits sought to be conferred by the Bill may not extend to all who are Aboriginals within the meaning of the State Electoral Act. This could lead to confusion in the minds of persons who have always regarded themselves as Aboriginals under the State Act and who may suddenly find that they do not have rights under the Commonwealth Bill. One would have thought that the definitions could have been brought into line, one with the other. Thirdly, a person seeking to take advantage of the Bill would need to establish that he satisfied the requirements of the definition of 'Aboriginal'. A simple assertion of fact that he was an Aboriginal would not be sufficient. He or she may be required to bring expert evidence to establish his or her rights in terms of the definition which has been put down in this Bill by Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.PARA: Fourthly, the present Commonwealth and State eligibility laws are basically the same, so far as they are relevant. There is one exception-that is, that the State law has a requirement of three months continuous residence in the State, which is not a prerequisite for Commonwealth enrolment. The enactment of a Commonwealth law would mean that an Aboriginal could secure State enrolment without satisfying additional State residence requirements. That would be conferring an additional right upon Aboriginals which is not a necessary part of overcoming the problem to which Senator Walsh has referred. Fifthly-this last example could often work against Aboriginals-if Western Australia were to change the voting qualifications in some way, for example, to lower the voting age to under 18 years, the Bill as it is proposed would not have effect on Aboriginals because those Aboriginals under 18 years who might otherwise qualify under a West Australian law would not be able to go on the roll because they would not qualify under Commonwealth law.

There are further difficulties. In addition to proving that someone comes within the definition of Aboriginal within clause 3 of the Bill, there is also the need to establish that the person concerned was on the Commonwealth roll. This in itself may not be as simple as it sounds. In some cases where difficulties arise the proof required may not be readily available to Aboriginals with literacy problems, those in remote areas-the very people whom this Bill seeks to protect-those who are itinerant or those whose names may be spelt in different ways. If we can have no assurance that these problems will be overcome, then really the Bill requires more work done. Further problems would exist if an Aboriginal's name appears on the printed electoral roll but not on what is called the official roll.

I find clause 7 of the Bill particularly unsatisfactory. Clause 7 prevents the State from checking or verifying the accuracy or the validity of Commonwealth enrolments. Yet Commonwealth enrolments are to be used as a critical factor in allowing people to go on the State roll. Whereas Commonwealth enrolment can be challenged under and in accordance with the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act if it is not accurate, this Bill would leave no scope for such challenge when it comes to conferring a Commonwealth franchise for State purposes. So we could challenge a person in relation to his right to vote in a Commonwealth election but we could not challenge that same person on his right to vote in a State election. This is as unfair as it is unnecessary. There is no guarantee that it would work to the advantage of Aboriginals; it could work to their disadvantage.

These are but a few of the practical difficulties associated with the Bill. They demonstrate that the benefits of the Bill may be totally illusory. But of as great, or even greater, significance is the doubt as to whether the Commonwealth is competent to pass such legislation. It appears that there are major obstacles in the way of Commonwealth legislation giving Aboriginals voting entitlements in any State elections. The only relevant Commonwealth constitutional head of power under which it may legislate on the matter is section 51 (xxvi). This section empowers the Commonwealth Parliament to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws.

There seems to be no other head of power which is relevant to what is being sought in this Bill. I put it to honourable senators and especially to my friends in the Australian Democrats, who have told us that they will listen to the debate before making up their minds, that this is a very significant matter. The only head of power is the Aboriginal head of power.
