So, this legislation could well be challenged as being properly characterised as a law in respect of State electoral requirements rather than a law in respect of 'any race for whom it is deemed to be necessary to make special laws'. If this were the case, the law would then be considered as beyond the competence of the Commonwealth and, accordingly, invalid.

There is also the very real possibility that the validity of any such Act might be challenged on the ground that it would be a law telling a State instrumentality what to do. It is directed against a State instrumentality; it seeks to alter provisions relating to elections for the Parliament of the State of Western Australia. To draw an analogy, in the past a Commonwealth law conditionally forbidding private banks conducting business for a State government was held to be invalid, for the same reason I have set out. It attempted to tell a State instrumentality what to do. It was held to be invalid even though the Commonwealth had power under another placitum, of section 51 of the Constitution, to make laws in respect of banking. So, there is some doubt about the constitutionality of this Bill. These are matters which would almost certainly lead to legal disputation in which plausible arguments could be advanced, denying the Commonwealth legislative competence on this matter. Where would that leave the Aboriginal and Islander people of Western Australia?

As I mentioned earlier, the Government is concerned that no Australian should be disadvantaged in getting his or her name on the electoral roll. We are equally concerned to ensure that Aboriginals freely and fairly exercise their right to vote. In June 1979 the Government initiated the Aboriginal Electoral Education Program, under the auspices of the Australian Electoral Office. This program is directed at Aboriginals in remote and rural areas of Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory, in the belief that this kind of educational program will assist Aboriginals to understand and to use their rights to enrol and vote. Our commitments, including our election commitments, are quite clear and our concern that Aboriginals should not be disadvantaged in terms of their right to vote is quite clear.

Rather than providing solutions, we believe this Bill opens up a whole host of difficulties. We believe it is unsatisfactory. Should circumstances arise with specific examples of disadvantage, specific examples of where Aboriginals have been denied the right to vote-I emphasise specific examples-we believe Western Australia would want to re-examine its legislation. Of course, we would be interested in specific examples. We, too, might then want to look at the matter again. But, at this point there has been no complaint. No one can claim that he or she has been disadvantaged. On that basis, we will not support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the private member's Bill introduced by my colleague, Senator Walsh from Western Australia, to provide State electoral roll enrolment rights for Western Australian Aboriginal people. I remind the Senate at the outset that the purpose of the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill is drafted to create a situation where citizens of Western Australia who are Aboriginals are not impeded in enrolling on the State electoral roll. The situation at present is that many Western Australians are so impeded. All States except Western Australia and Queensland have a common electoral roll; so we are specifically concerned with the impediments to enrolment placed in the way of Aboriginal citizens in Western Australia. The Bill does no more than guarantee that Aboriginals in Western Australia, when enrolling for State elections, will receive the same treatment under State electoral law as under Commonwealth law. It allows the State to continue to have its own electoral rolls and does not seek to interfere in the manner in which the State organises its own elections, other than to the extent noted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), in the plethora of spurious reasons he gave for finding himself unable to support this Bill, emphasised the fact that he had received no complaints from Aboriginal citizens of Western Australia regarding their ability to enrol on the State roll, and he pointed out that his predecessor, Senator Chaney, claimed he also had received no complaints. I find that a totally unconvincing reason for refusing to accept Senator Walsh's Bill. Are we to have in Australia government by neglect? Is negligence simply to take the place of proper action to ensure human rights? Surely it would occur to the Minister that if an Aboriginal person is impeded in enrolling on the State roll because of distance or because of not having the opportunity to find a justice of the peace or a policeman to witness the enrolment form, then that person might also be, for the same sorts of geographic and social reasons, impeded in the making of a complaint. If a person does not feel brave enough to face a Western Australian policeman to assert his or her right to enrol, surely the Minister will agree that it is highly likely that that person might also feel rather nervous about entering a complaint to an unsympathetic Federal Minister about his denial of human rights.

It seems to me rather distressing that a government which has, in only the last session of Parliament, established machinery for a Human Rights Commission in order to take some steps towards complying with its obligations under various international human rights treaties, should now say 'Well, we cannot interfere; if something is a matter for a State government then human rights are no longer relevant'. That is what I understood the Minister to be implying when he said that until he receives a complaint there is no case for Federal interference. What will this Human Rights Commission do if any complaint tgthat a person might have is to be dismissed on the grounds that it is something to do with being a citizen of a State rather than a citizen of the Commonwealth of Australia? I would assume that being a citizen of any part of Australia should confer equal human rights on that citizen, and if we are to have human rights machinery which is to be taken seriously at all then that human rights machinery should not stop at the boundaries of any particular State.

The Minister also attempted to hide behind a number of rather pedantic quarrels with the drafting of the legislation. In particular, he mentioned that the definition at one point did not include Torres Strait Islanders. It was perfectly open to the Minister and to his predecessor, Senator Chaney, to suggest drafting amendments to Senator Walsh. I am assured by Senator Walsh-I think he is on the record as saying this-that he approached Senator Chaney, sent him a draft of the Bill and said he was open to any drafting amendments of that kind that could be made. As honourable senators, particularly those representing the Australian Democrats, will know, private non-governing senators or members face enormous difficulties in the drawing up of private members' Bills. We do not have the legislative resources that are available to the Government. So, if some minor drafting errors which could easily have been corrected by suggestions by Senator Baume or his predecessor are the sum total of the Minister's objections to the Bill, he has put forward a pretty pathetic case.

I must comment also on some of the other objections the Minister has put forward. He seems to think that by providing automatic enrolment on State rolls, by virtue of a person being a Commonwealth enrollee, we are creating a situation which would somehow in the future restrict the rights of people to get on the State roll. This is the exact reverse of the intention of the Bill, and the exact reverse of the letter of the Bill. We are not saying that a right to Commonwealth enrolment shall be something that is less than a right to State enrolment; we are saying that by virtue of Commonwealth enrolment one's rights can be extended to State enrolment, so it is an extensive right that is being conferred and not a restrictive right. The Minister seems to have interpreted that provision in a quite contrary way.

The Minister also suggested that there are grave doubts-at least, some doubts; I cannot really imagine that they are grave-about the constitutional powers of the Federal Government to act in the way that the Bill provides. I want to point out to honourable senators that some doubt about constitutional powers is, in itself, no excuse for inaction when an important issue of human rights is at stake. It has often been the case in the constitutional and legal history of this country that doubts about constitutional validity have not stopped Federal governments from acting, and those doubts have been resolved in the High Court of Australia. We have the High Court to resolve questions of doubt about the constitutional powers of Federal governments. The former Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, has said on a number of occasions that the existence of a doubt about constitutional powers is not a reason not to act, that the High Court is the proper place to resolve such doubts. I point out that the Whitlam Government's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975 was passed by the Senate at a time when the coalition parties had a majority in the Senate, and they did not challenge that Act. That Act uses Commonwealth powers in precisely the same way as Senator Walsh's Bill would use them, so this sudden nervousness about constitutional doubt seems to have been introduced and invented for the purpose of obstructing this very sensible piece of legislation which Senator Walsh has presented to the Senate.

I remind honourable senators that the Court Government in Western Australia passed amendments to the Western Australian Electoral Act in 1979 which require all enrolment cards to be signed before an electoral officer, a justice of the peace, a clerk of the court, or a policeman. Previously, an enrolment application could be witnessed by an elector, as is the case with the Commonwealth Act, as is the case throughout the rest of Australia. The amendments also make it an offence to persuade a person to apply for a postal vote. The Minister in his opening remarks did admit that these provisions could provide difficulties. He did not deny that difficulties had been so created. Indeed, with regard to the amendment making it an offence to persuade a person to apply for a postal vote, this provision has already been used against community workers who allegedly assisted in obtaining postal votes for the Western Australian State election in February 1980. However, the case, which was against Steven Hawke and four others, was dismissed, with costs awarded against the Western Australian Government.

The 1979 amendments have worked. In the last year the gap between Federal and State enrolments has grown rapidly. At 31 March this year there were 42,117 more electors on the Commonwealth roll than on the State roll. That, it seems to me, is a rather large number of potential complainants for the Minister to dismiss in the way he attempted to do. Of those 42,000-odd people, there is little doubt that a large number of them would be Aboriginals. Indeed, some of them might be migrants and other people whose rights also have to be addressed in this matter. However, at this stage we are specifically concerned with Aboriginal voters. I do not think that that gap of over 42,000 electors is something that the Minister should attempt to dismiss. It is a significant number of people who must in some way be affected by the discriminatory provisions of the Western Australian Electoral Act, and I think that those 42,117 people are entitled to the protection that Senator Walsh's Bill will give them.

We are attempting to remove these impediments and to ensure that there is universal franchise in Western Australia for State and Commonwealth elections. We expect the support of the entire Senate in this matter. I remind honourable senators that on 6 June 1979 the following urgency motion was moved in the Senate, supported by the Government, and carried without dissent:
That Aborigines should have the same opportunities to enrol and vote in State elections as in Federal elections.

That motion was passed by the Senate in 1979 without dissent. I think it is a matter of shame for the Senate that the Federal Government has failed to act on this motion of the Senate, hence Senator Walsh's private member's Bill. It is unacceptable that a government which has special constitutional responsibility for its Aboriginal citizens and which is a party to the ratification of the United Nations Convention on all forms of racial discrimination should tolerate discriminatory State laws. Unfortunately, this is yet another area where the Fraser Government's failure to act stems not from inadequate constitutional or legal powers, not from lack of a mandate, but simply from its concern to avoid any conflict with its State governing coalition partners in Western Australia. I assert that the Liberal Government in Western Australia has implemented this blatant attempt to keep Aboriginal people off the State roll because it knows that its policies are unacceptable to Aboriginal people, to its Aboriginal citizens, and it is not prepared to pay the political price of those unacceptable policies. The Australian Labor Party and, I trust, the Australian Democrats want to see the enfranchisement of Aboriginal people in Western Australia because we believe that it is only through the ballot box that Aboriginal citizens of Western Australia will be able to change those policies which are unacceptable to them.

The failure of the Western Australian Government to ensure justice for Aboriginal people is a matter of record. I refer to the report to the Parliament in 1980 by Mr Grassby, the Commissioner for Community Relations. This report documented discrimination against Aboriginal people through the legal system, by police, in employment, housing, hotel services, the media, health services and education. An entire chapter of the report was devoted to the discriminatory practices of the Western Australian and Queensland governments. Further documentation of the sorts of policies that Aboriginal people have to put up with when they are disenfranchised appears in the report of the World Council of Churches. I have that report here and I have a number of examples marked, but out of respect to other honourable senators who wish to contribute to this debate I will not read them at this time. Suffice it to say that there is documentary evidence-evidence which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, has not attempted to deny, to give credit where it is due-that in the State of Western Australia a number of discriminatory policies are implemented by the Western Australian Government, which policies Aboriginal people have no chance of changing if they are not on the roll and cannot vote. It is as basic as that.

My own investigations into the Kimberley area of Western Australia left me in no doubt that policies with regard to employment, provision of essential services such as sealed airstrips, roads, and health services, and of State laws to protect Aboriginal land and sacred sites from the depredations of mining companies are totally inadequate. I expect that my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Ruth Coleman, will be saying more on that point. There is no doubt in my mind that the policies of the Western Australian Government in regard to Aboriginals, as I saw them in train in the Kimberley region, are totally unacceptable.

Although the specific purpose of this Bill is to ensure that those on the Commonwealth roll can also vote in State elections, we are not complacent, I must point out, about access to the Commonwealth roll by Western Australian Aboriginals, particularly those living in remote areas. The Federal Government, in particular the two relevant Ministers, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, and his colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, and the Commonwealth Electoral Office have been totally unco-operative with my attempts and the attempts of my Western Australian colleagues to ensure that Aboriginal citizens can in reality exercise their constitutional right to enrol on the Commonwealth roll. I have urged the Government to ensure that Commonwealth electoral enrolment forms and electoral information be provided at polling booths during the forthcoming election for the National Aboriginal Conference. Over $700,000 will be spent next month to ensure that all adult Australian Aboriginals have access to a Commonwealth electoral office polling booth for the National Aboriginal Conference election. For almost no extra cost, voting enrolment forms could be provided, but the Government has chosen to say that providing enrolment forms would constitute a violation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That claim, of course, is rubbish, and at this point I wish to quote an opinion to that effect from the law and government research section of the Parliament. The opinion states:

In relation to the words of section 158 (aa), the supplying of enrolment forms and electoral information per se, would not amount to threatening, offering or suggesting violence, injury, punishment, damage, loss or disadvantage in order to induce an enrolment or a promise of enrolment, or a refraining from enrolment.

The view that providing electoral information and forms would interfere with an Aborigine's right to choose whether or not to enrol can be contrasted with the view expressed by Isaacs J. quoted above.
The view expressed by Mr Justice Isaacs states:

Without limiting the effect of the general words in the preceding section, 'undue influence' includes every interference or attempted interference with the free exercise of the franchise of any voter or with the free exercise by an Aboriginal native of Australia of his choice whether or not to enrol as an elector . . .
One part of having a choice to do something necessarily would entail the opportunity to do that thing . . .
That is the point I have made to the Minister, but the Minister chooses to be impervious to it. The document continues:

If a person is uninformed, unaware and has information actively concealed from him or her, then it may result that the person forms a political judgement different than that which she or he would have formed. To take the matter to its logical conclusion, complete lack of information . . . would result in a choice not being able to be made at all.

Depending on the nature of the information, which is a question of fact, the supplying of information would not usually constitute an 'interference' or attempted interference of an Aborigine's free exercise of choice whether or not to enrol as an elector. A Court may also have difficulty in finding the supply of electoral forms is such an interference.

Of course it would. I have also approached the Western Australian State Electoral Office asking it to provide the opportunity for Aboriginals to enrol on the Western Australian State roll for the National Aboriginal Conference elections. Of course, the Electoral Officer has refused.

In conclusion I say this: The purpose of the Bill is simple and clear. It is to ensure that there are no discriminatory impediments to the enrolment by Aboriginal citizens on the Western Australian State roll. The purpose of this Bill has already been endorsed by the Senate. Our international obligations under various binding treaties require that this discrimination be removed. The only possible reason the Government could bring forward for rejecting the Bill is a shameful one. It is its reluctance to come into conflict with the Government of Western Australia. That reason is not good enough. I hope the Government will not try to sustain this reason. I urge all honourable senators to support Senator Walsh's Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally I support the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill 1981 introduced by my colleague Senator Walsh some weeks ago. I say immediately that the only intention of this Bill is to ensure that Aborigines have the same right as all other Australians who reside in Western Australia. Senator Ryan, in speaking on this Bill, made the point that already we have found a discrepancy between the State and the Federal electoral rolls of something like 42,117 people. Some of those people would be Aboriginals. I am disturbed to find that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has not received any complaints-nor, apparently, did his predecessor-about people who wanted to exercise their right to vote at the 1977 and 1980 elections not being able so to do because their names were not on the roll.

SPEECH.PARA: Their names were removed from the roll by the State Government in a number of nefarious ways. Inspectors were sent to various camp sites where it was known that the community was not in residence at the time. Finding the people not in residence, the inspectors left their little printed cards saying 'Your name will be removed from the electoral roll' which, to many people, meant very little. Their names were, in fact, removed from the electoral roll. We now find a situation in Western Australia in which directives by Ministers are disadvantaging Aboriginals. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs says in this place that he has no evidence of any disadvantaging of any Aboriginal in Western Australia.

I will give the Minister a number of examples. One incident of which the Minister should have been aware occurred during his recent visit to the Kimberley region undertaken in, I think, early June. The Minister and I had the opportunity of seeing a disadvantaged group of Aboriginal people living under a directive from the Western Australian Government. I took the opportunity to see those people. The Minister did not. I refer to those Aboriginal people who left the Nicholson Downs station because of maltreatment by the white owner-manager and who were camped on the edge of Halls Creek with one canvas fly between 35 and 40 people, no fresh water except that which was provided in a 44-gallon drum each day by the shire and no other form of shelter. I chose to go and see them. I chose to take some action on the matter. I found it extremely difficult to do so because of a directive issued by the Western Australian State Minister for Community Welfare which said that there were to be no dealings between the Department and those communities represented by the Kimberley Land Council. It was a shameful act on the part of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs not to see those people and not to take some action to ensure that facilities were made available so that their health standards did not fall. That was just an indication of the disadvantaging of the Aboriginal people who reside in Western Australia. The Western Australian Government has shown its contempt for all voters' rights with the gerrymandered system which operates in that State. It has also amply demonstrated its contempt for the Aboriginal people by virtue of the various directives which have been undertaken by its Ministers.

We have to accept that some of the 42,117 people-the figure cited by Senator Ryan a short time ago-are, in actual fact, Aboriginals. We have to accept that some of them live in fairly remote areas. We have to accept that some of them do not, for three or 12 consecutive months of the year, reside under the same tree, in the same tent or in the same humpy. We have to accept that that is the lifestyle of the Aboriginals and they are entitled to that lifestyle. But we have to accept also that if they want to exercise their vote they have a right and a responsibility so to do. The Minister said a little while ago that the Federal Government is now moving from voluntary to compulsory voting for Aboriginals. That will be a great step forward. It will be part and parcel of the integration of white and black. It will be part of an acceptance by the Commonwealth Government that Aboriginal people have a right and a responsibility to vote and the majority of them want to accept that responsibility.

The Minister also spoke of illiterates. I do not believe we can ever accept the premise that because a person is illiterate or under educated he has no right to an opinion or, in actual fact, has no opinion. He may not be able to read and write but that does not mean that he cannot think. A larger number of Aboriginal people in Australia-and it is a very shameful thing to admit-are under educated and illiterate. It is not their fault that they are illiterate. It is the fault of many governments, both State and Federal, that there are such large numbers of illiterates. Being illiterate does not mean that they are incapable of thinking. It does not mean they are incapable of voting. It should not be an impediement to their ability to cast a vote. We have already been through an exercise in--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to make that very point.

—The Minister did not make it quite clear enough. I hope that I have now clarified the situation not only for the Hansard record but also for the Minister and the people who may be interested in what I have had to say about this matter. I have said that the Western Australian Government is particularly unconcerned about the democratic rights of Aboriginal people, particularly when it comes to their exercising the right to vote. The Government's most recent demonstration of that fact lies in the amendments to the Electoral Act which have now made it virtually impossible for people who are not accustomed to bureaucracy to be able to get their application forms witnessed.

SPEECH.PARA: Some three or four years ago I spoke in this chamber about a situation which was occurring in the town of Fitzroy Crossing. I do not intend to go over that situation again. However, I intend to raise the point that Aboriginal people in that township were subjected to a certain amount of harassment and cruelty by a member of the police force. I could not imagine any Aboriginal amongst the nine communities resident at Fitzroy Crossing being prepared to go to a police officer to get him to witness his application form just so that he could exercise his right to vote. I think the Minister would have to agree that that is the bureaucratic wall which I am talking about and which will be seen by a large number of Aboriginal people. They will now not be able to vote and will not be able to have their name placed on the Western Australian State roll because they cannot bring themselves to approach this wall of bureaucracy.

The criterion for registration is to have the form authorised or witnessed by one of four people, one of whom I have mentioned-a police officer. Another person is a justice of the peace. We do not have justices of the peace living on the corner of every street in every small town in Western Australia. The Minister would be aware of that. He would know that there are very few justices of the peace in the Kimberley region, for instance. Similarly, how often would an Aboriginal come into contact with a clerk of the courts unless he perhaps appeared before the clerk of the courts? If he did, would the Minister anticipate that at a later stage that person would have enough confidence in that same clerk of the courts to go back to that court and ask the clerk to witness his signature so that he could, in actual fact, have his name placed on the electoral roll? I cannot see that happening and I think the Minister would have to agree that it would not.

The changes to the boundaries in a number of the seats in Western Australia are a further indication of the West Australian State Government's absolute contempt for the Aboriginal people. It has done this under special legislation and changed the boundaries to ensure that the one Aboriginal person who represents all the Aboriginal people in the West Australian Legislative Assembly will remain there. It has made his seat so secure that Mr Ernie Bridge will remain a member of the Legislative Assembly for the Kimberleys for the rest of his life. The West Australian Government has broadened the area to such an extent that almost every Aboriginal community in the Kimberleys is now contained in his seat. At the same time it has concentrated the surrounding seats, which are incidentially held by members of the Liberal Party, into small areas on the assumption that it has made them safe for the Liberal Party. Where it has got this information from, I do not know; but, if there is a small number of voters, one has to disenfranchise or disenchant only a few of those voters to lose one's seat. Perhaps the Liberal Government in Western Australia will find at the next election that it has created a situation where the member for the seat below the Kimberley region will lose his seat because there are so few electors who are prepared to put up with the absolute contempt that is being demonstrated by the legislation being introduced by the Western Australian Government.

My colleague Senator Walsh has already made it quite clear in this place that the West Australian Act about which we are concerned, the Electoral Amendment Act, imposes conditions for enrolment designed to intimidate Aboriginals. I hope that proceeded to demonstrate to the Senate, that these Aboriginal people who live in a tribal situation in a community area, who are isolated from the mainstream of the communities, are already feeling intimidated. They have little contact with that wall of bureaucracy and they are not going to go out and actively search for it in an endeavour to get their names on the electoral roll.

In 1979 an inquiry, headed by Mr Justice Kay, was held in Western Australia. His report pointed out what we already know about electoral enrolments, that is, that very few white people understand the electoral system. It is therefore more difficult for Aboriginal people to understand it. He said:

It is the duty of the authorized witnesses to ensure that the claimant knows what he or she is doing. Authorized witnesses should, therefore, be persons who have a reasonable knowledge of the provisions of the Act which relate to enrolment and voting.

If everybody understood the Electoral Act and if everybody understood how to vote, there would not be the need to see every single political party so strongly represented outside polling booths handing out how-to-vote cards on election day to ensure that the majority of votes were valid ones. But we all do it because we are aware that we already have a complicated electoral system which is very difficult for even educated people to understand. It makes it very much more difficult for those people the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and I have referred to, that is, those illiterate and under-educated people in our community. No other group in Western Australia is so clearly discriminated against by paternal government legislation which not only makes it particularly difficult for Aborigines to enrol, but also, I think it is fair to say, makes it virtually impossible for them to enrol. This paternal attitude towards the Aborigines that 'we really do not want you to have the right to vote because you may then become a political force' is an attitude which has been adopted many times. It is not a good attitude to adopt towards any disadvantaged group in our community. We tend to think of the majority of Aborigines as being illiterate people, but both I and the Minister know a large number of Aboriginal people who are highly educated but who still do not understand our electoral process. The passage of this Bill will not mean that every Aborigine is going to exercise the right to vote. It will simply mean that we are providing them with the opportunity to exercise that right if they so wish. The Minister said earlier that we would be departing from normal procedure; but Western Australia and Queensland are the only States that do not already have dual rolls. I cannot understand why the Government is obviously not going to support this Bill and why, at the same time as the Minister is professing concern for the Aboriginal people, he is not going out of his way to ensure that those people who are at present being impeded from casting their votes or who are being precluded from registering on the State electoral roll, receive the support of the Liberal Party in this chamber. I hope that there will be a number of free thinking people on the Government side who will see this Bill as being absolutely essential to ensure that no discrimination exists against any people living in the State of Western Australia. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be speaking while you are in the chair, Madam Acting Deputy President. Your presence certainly adds dignity to this chamber. The Bill that we are discussing-the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill 1981-is a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Walsh. It is a Bill for an Act to ensure that Aboriginal electors of the Commonwealth in Western Australia are not prevented from enrolling for an election for the Western Australian Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In his reply to the second reading speech, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) did not cavil at the principle that Aboriginal voters should be encouraged as much as possible to enrol, not only on Commonwealth rolls but also on State rolls. I believe there is a unanimity of view, at least in relation to the principle, but that the methods by which it can be obtained are being disputed.

I wish to look at the legislation and not to discuss so much that principle that we all agree upon. It is aimed at giving the Aboriginal voters the same right to enrol on State electoral rolls as they have to enrol on Commonwealth rolls in Western Australia. I believe that that principle would also be generally accepted in this chamber. Western Australia's 33,000 Aboriginals do not have to be on the rolls but, under the State Electoral Act, if they are, they must vote. I believe that the circumstances leading up to the drafting of this Bill are fairly broadly understood. It is possible for the Australian Democrats to say, without appearing biased, that the particular amendments introduced into Western Australia were deliberately designed to lower the Australian Labor Party vote in the north of that State.

If one has knowledge of the Kimberley area I think it is probably fair to say that amongst Aboriginal voters there is probably a greater tendency to vote for the Australian Labor Party than for the Liberal Party or for the National Country Party. That suggests that the Liberal Government of Sir Charles Court sees the changes that it introduced as political changes aimed directly at the black vote. In saying that, I believe that we should be very clear that since foundation we have had manipulation of electoral rolls, manipulation of electoral boundaries and manipulation of weighted electoral boundaries in Australia. We are now heading towards our second century and still in this country we have blatant examples of the manipulation of the democratic process. It will probably not be until a referendum which enshrines basic democratic principles is carried in this country that we will not continue to see-and see well into the future-attempts by State and Federal governments to manipulate boundaries or to use other means to gain political advantage for themselves. However, I believe that the Minister does not support that principle. Having had many discussions with him and having listened to his various speeches here and elsewhere, I do not believe that he does support any manipulation which has occurred by Sir Charles Court. Nevertheless, I believe that his defence of the Government's action in not supporting this Bill is based on a number of grounds which are not strong ones.

I would like to make a point about this Bill which I think is extremely important. Although this point has been brought up by other speakers, I think it should be reiterated. The Electoral Act of Western Australia provides that where a claimant's name does not appear on any roll the enrolment card shall be signed by:
(I) an Electoral Officer;
(II) a Justice of the Peace
(III) a clerk of courts; or
(IV) a Police officer; or
(ii) in any other case, an elector, or a person qualified to be enrolled as an elector, of the Commonwealth Parliament or of the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia.

In other words, this provision is aimed specifically at those people not on the electoral rolls. If we ask ourselves about that it becomes fairly obvious that to draw a distinction between those who are not on electoral rolls and those who are is probably in the case of Western Australia and every other State of Australia to be biased against Aboriginal voters as they are not obliged to have their names recorded on any rolls. Consequently, one would assume that a higher percentage of Aboriginal voters would fall into category A than category B. I believe that at no time was that differentiation promoted, established or argued for in the debates that took place in the Western Australian Parliament. If there is a differentiation, I believe that we need to put a very strong argument for any differentiation between those two categories of voters. If there is not, I believe it is fair for us to look for one. I believe that that, given the events which led to these changes in the Western Australian Electoral Act, must disadvantage the black voter in Western Australia.

We are all very much aware-apart from Western Australian senators, as a Queensland senator I am probably more aware than most-that Aboriginals have an extremely uneasy relationship both with the courts and with the police. It is unlikely that they would be willing to approach them either to have an enrolment card witnessed or to gain access to something which is relatively uncomplicated. That that is a fact says nothing necessarily about Aboriginal voters as distinct from white voters, except that when we look at the statistics in relation to convictions in Western Australia we can see very clearly the predominance of the law bearing down so much more vigorously on Aboriginals than it does on whites. The fact that that uneasy relationship exists is a cultural element, but it is also an element of the way in which justice is administered in that State. This being the case, I believe we need to look further at what types of irregularities might occur by putting those two categories into the legislation.

One of the important elements which has not been raised so far in this debate is that of the normal laundering operations that go on in electoral offices. If one dwells on that one will again notice how in Western Australia and indeed in Queensland white Australians are advantaged over black Australians. For example, white Australians are much more likely to receive and to reply to the normal letters which are sent out if they fail to vote in referendums, elections or whatever. Aboriginals who live in remote areas are less likely to receive such notices for reasons which were raised by Senator Coleman. If they do receive the notices they are less likely to return them. Another factor arises from the voluntary nature of enrolment. A white voter is compelled to ensure that his name in on the rolls. Established procedures exist to ensure that the names of white voters who are not on the rolls are picked up and returned to the rolls if indeed they should be there. On the other hand, Aboriginal voters are not compelled to be on the rolls and if their names are removed there are no procedures to have them reinstated. Therefore, the onus rests solely on the Aboriginal to check and constantly check that his name is on the rolls. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs said that in fact no cases of discrimination had occurred to date. That is impossible to tell.

It may well be the case that an Aboriginal voter's name has been removed from the rolls and that that Aboriginal voter is unaware that his name has been removed from the rolls. There is no procedure to ensure that the Aboriginal's name is reinstated on the rolls. Unless an Aboriginal voter wishes to check, and check constantly, whether his name is on the rolls, when he comes to cast his vote against or for the Government at the next election he will suddenly discover that he is not enrolled. As we heard before, he will probably then remain unenrolled for the reason that to have his name reinstated he would need to go back before a justice of the peace, a clerk of the courts or a police officer.

I believe that some of the other points raised by the Minister have substance. However, I do not think they bear crucially on this Bill. The first point relates to the definition of 'Aboriginal' in the Bill itself. The Bill defines 'Aboriginal' as a person who is a member of the Aboriginal race of Australia. The interpretation in section 5 of the Western Australian Act, which would be the crucial one in a dispute raised by the Minister, says:
The principal Act is amended-
(a) as to section 4-
(i) by inserting immediately before the interpretation 'absent voter' an interpretation as follows-
'Aboriginal' means a person who is an Aboriginal within the meaning of that expression as defined by section four of the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Act, 1972;
Section 4 of the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Authority Act of 1972 states:
In this Act, unless the context requires otherwise-
'Aboriginal' means pertaining to the original inhabitants of Australia and to their descendants.

I would suggest that both of these definitions could be fair game for lawyers. Nevertheless, I doubt whether any court in fact would find that there was a difference between 'Aboriginal' meaning a person who is a member of the Aboriginal race of Australia and 'Aboriginal' meaning pertaining to the original inhabitants of Australia and to their descendants. So I do not believe that would cause very much concern.

An issue which causes the Australian Democrats some concern is the issue of State rights. We believe very strongly that there is a useful element within our federation in respect of the tension that exists between State and Federal governments. We believe that that tension is a creative tension within our federation and should not be done away with or harmed in any way unless such action is absolutely necessary. However, I believe in this regard that perhaps the Minister speaks for himself and not necessarily for the Government. We have already had in the last couple of weeks of the Budget session some very interesting examples in this place of the Government having very few scruples in directing State governments to do or perform certain activities in areas which are their constitutional responsibility.

For example, I refer to one area-education. Fairly obviously in this area the Federal Government has had representations from every State Government, not only privately to the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), but also publicly in the media to the effect that they do not wish their role in relation to the spending of education funds to be at the whim of the Federal Minister for Education. They do not wish to be bound to certain policy judgments that the Federal Government may make in that regard, in which case I believe that while the Government has shown no scruples, the Minister-he may very well have shown scruples in relation to the States-may be speaking for himself and not the Government. While we accept in substance the principle of the objection of the Minister to the Bill, we do not believe it bears on the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill because we believe there is a good and proper reason for interfering in the operations of the State Government of Western Australia.

The third major argument that the Minister brought forward I believe is an important one and pertains to Federal powers. Senator Ryan raised a number of issues in this regard. Basically, I believe the points she suggested are correct. I believe that we should ask ourselves in regard to every piece of legislation that comes into this chamber: 'Is it constitutional?' That is a proper type of question to be asked. Therefore, I believe the Minister is quite correct in raising that matter in debate. I believe it is a point to which we should give due consideration. However, I think that we can do no more in this regard than pay attention to the changes the people of Australia have made in recent times in handing quite deliberately to the Commonwealth powers in relation to Aboriginal people. Having regard to that referendum and to those very strongly held propositions of the people of Australia, I think that the Commonwealth Government ought to involve itself heavily in the affairs of the Aboriginal people and their welfare. This Bill does no more than attach itself to that popular democratic voice.

In the flux of time we may discover that the High Court in its wisdom, or otherwise, has decided that this is not constitutional. Indeed, its judgments from time to time have seemed rather odd to laymen. Those judgments as to the constitutionality of this proposed Act or any other Act are for the High Court alone to determine within its powers under the Constitution. I believe that Parliament can do no more than act in good faith so that the Bills it passes are within its powers to legislate on. If this is the stance of the Parliament I believe that Parliament has acted rightly and correctly and can do no more. I do not believe there is an obligation on this Parliament-certainly not on this chamber-to stay away from any Bills which may offend the Constitution. If that were the case, most of the path finding legislation that has passed through this House in the 80 years since Federation would never have been attempted. Such legislation was attempted, often in the face of great rivalry and conflicting legal opinion. I believe in this regard there is nothing more that the Senate can do other than to say it believes this Bill is constitutional and therefore ought to proceed.

The Australian Democrats will support this Bill in its passage through the House and we hope it will be presented to the House of Representatives as soon as it passes through this chamber. I hope that Liberal and National Country party senators, who we know have, as do the Australian Democrats, freedom to exercise a conscience vote on all these issues will accept and grasp that nettle. There are at least some honourable senators who will exercise that right. I believe some honourable senators who have exercised that conscience vote will be voting for this Bill. If that is the case, the Bill will go forward to the House of Representatives and I hope there it will be received with respect as the judgment of this chamber and given weighty consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Government for making time available to bring the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill 1981 on for debate today. It may have been possible to bring it on for debate in another way but I prefer that it be done in the way it has been done. I also thank the honourable senators who have spoken and the Australian Democrats for their indication of support for the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that Senator Baume presented a quite unconvincing apologia for what has become the typical Fraser Government refusal to take action in matters pertaining to Aborigines against reactionary governments in Western Australia and Queensland. Senator Baume cited Senator Chaney as having said in May 1980 that the Bill was unsatisfactory. That was a broad comment in respect to any technical defects which the Bill may have; we do not believe the Bill has any serious technical defects. Prior to the Bill being introduced in November 1979, I contacted Senator Chaney and invited him or his Department to submit any criticisms of a technical nature about the Bill or the way in which it was drafted either to me or to other members of the Australian Labor Party involved with it. I said we would be eager and anxious to discuss appropriate changes. No such approach was made by Senator Chaney. However, Senator Baume claims-like Senator Chaney earlier-that the Bill is unsatisfactory for a variety of reasons. I will go through those reasons seriatim. Firstly, he criticised the definition of 'Aboriginal' under clause 3 of the Bill which states:
'Aboriginal' means a person who is a member of the Aboriginal race of Australia;

He said that was unsatisfactory. Actually, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975 uses exactly the same description. If the clause is unsatisfactory, it is obviously something that was not apparent to Senator Baume and those other Liberal and National Country Party senators still here who voted for that Act in 1975. Nor, obviously, was it apparent to Government Ministers and their advisers when the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1966 was introduced and enacted by this Government and which contained exactly the same definition of 'Aboriginal'.

The Minister also criticised the Bill on the ground that it excludes Islanders. There may be some validity in that point but I suggest that really is nitpicking. There are very few Torres Strait Islanders in Western Australia. Senator Baume conceded that the impediments to enrolment of Aboriginals under existing Western Australian law exist and incidentally, exist in no State but Western Australia, and the effect of those impediments is not limited to Aboriginals. That is true. However, we took the view that only in matters pertaining to Aborigines did the Commonwealth have the power to insist that the Government of Western Australia effectively cease to apply those impediments to the enrolment of Aborigines. However, if the Government is anxious to extend the purpose of this Bill so that it covers all Western Australians who might be disadvantaged by this impediment, I think I could guarantee, even at this early stage, that it would have the full support of the Australian Labor Party. One way to do that would be to hold a referendum for constitutional amendment to impose the Commonwealth roll as the roll for all of the States instead of just four of the States-as it is now-as the minimum entitlement for enrolment on a State roll. The Minister said that no complaints had been received about the impediments which he admitted were imposed by the Western Australian law. That opens up a number of possibilities. One possibility raises the question of why any Aborigine who had monitored the record of this Government with respect to Aboriginal rights in standing up to the State governments of Queensland and Western Australia would bother to complain to this Government? Another point made by Senator Ryan is that the people who are disadvantaged are unlikely to be the sort of people complaining to Federal Ministers anyway. I do know of one case in Wiluna prior to the last State election in which there was wholesale rejection on technical grounds of applications for enrolment. But most importantly of all, at the time the present State Electoral Act became operative at the end of 1979 the gap in Western Australia between the aggregate enrolment on the Commonwealth roll and the State roll was, in round numbers, 5,000 as it had been for several years previously. By March 1981-15 months later-that gap had grown to 40,000. So it is quite obvious that a great number of people in Western Australia have been deterred from being admitted to the State roll by this provision and a very high proportion of those people would be Aborigines.

Senator Baume said that the Bill is not urgent. I want to make two comments. The first is that it has been on the Senate Notice Paper for almost two years-ever since November 1979. It was introduced in my absence by Senator McIntosh. The second point is that Senator Baume says the Bill is not urgent because there will not be an election in Western Australia for 18 months. That is probably true. An election is not due in Western Australia for 18 months, but assuming the Government changes its mind as indicated by Senator Baume and allows this Bill to pass, we would also be concerned about the effective application of the legislation. I am advised that the most expedient way in which this Bill, if it became an Act, could be effectively applied would be for the Commonwealth Attorney-General to seek a court order to enforce Commonwealth law in Western Australia. I think, with the present Attorney-General (Senator Durack), that is highly unlikely. The alternative, more difficult and slower way would be for individual Aborigines to seek a court injunction requiring the State electoral officer of Western Australia to place on the roll as a matter of right any Aboriginal who was already on the Commonwealth roll. So although it is probably 18 months to an election, considerable time would be required for the effective application of this Bill should it become an Act.

Senator Baume complained that with respect to clauses 6 and 7 there would be difficulty in determining who is on the Commonwealth roll for the purpose of establishing a right to be on the State roll of Western Australia if the Bill were passed. That may be so, but I observe that the problem is obviously not insurmountable since that is precisely the system which already applies in four States. Those four States-Western Australia and Queensland are excluded-use the Commonwealth roll as the basis for compiling the State roll. He also set up the man of straw with a superhypothetical suggestion that the Western Australian Act might be amended so that persons under 18 would be entitled to vote in Western Australia. The enrolment right established in this Bill in no way restricts the right of enrolment of the State Electoral Act to those who are enrolled on the Commonwealth roll. What it does is establish for Aborigines a right to demand that they be placed on the State roll irrespective of whether they have complied with the formal enrolment provisions. It does nothing to prevent any other person who may be entitled to be on the roll in the future in Western Australia from being so enrolled.

Clause 8, which Senator Baume criticised, is deliberately designed to prevent the Western Australian Government subsequently subverting this Bill should it become an Act, as the Western Australian Government would be quite capable of doing. He said that the Bill might be challenged in the courts on the grounds that it had more application to the Electoral Act of Western Australia than it did to Aborigines. That, of course, is possible. I note, however, that this Bill is derived from the same assumed head of power as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act of 1975. It uses precisely the same head of power that was enacted by this Parliament. It was supported by the then Opposition, Senator Baume included.

I want to make just a couple of other comments. I was very pleased to note that Senator Macklin accurately identified the purpose of this Bill and also the purpose behind the amendments to the Western Australian Electoral Act of 1975. I thank the Australian Democrats for their support. I am very disappointed that the Government as a whole is not willing to vote for this Bill. The Democrats have indicated that they will vote for it. I sincerely hope that Senator Harradine will, and at the very least I hope Senator Bonner will see fit to place his allegiance to his race before his disciplinary obligations to the Liberal Party. If the Senate does not pass the Bill, that will constitute yet again failure to use Commonwealth power over recalcitrant States and further tarnish Australia's international reputation on race matters.
Question put.
That the Bill be now read a second time.
