TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate is of the opinion that 1981, being the International Year of Disabled Persons, would be an appropriate occasion for the Federal Government to monitor very carefully the way in which its $1,000 million contribution to Australian hospitals is expended in the care and treatment of disabled persons.

(2) That the Senate notes that in 1979 a twenty three month old Down's Syndrome boy was admitted to a ''recognised hospital'' under Schedule B2 of the then Commonwealth-Western Australia hospital cost sharing agreement and that he died the following day in circumstances in which his parents and many other people believe that insufficient effort was made to preserve the child's life.

(3) That the Senate is of the opinion that disabled persons who suffer from physical and mental handicaps and incur some additional form of illness require particular assistance and attention; and to this end the Senate recommends that the Minister for Health investigate existing practices in hospitals which are partially funded by the Commonwealth through the States and report to the Australian Parliament.

The motion which I have just moved is slightly different from the motion which was placed on the Notice Paper on 25 November 1980. The reasons for the slight amendments are as follows: The boy's age was 23 months and not three years. Secondly, I have placed the word 'then' before the words 'Commonwealth-Western Australia hospital cost sharing agreement' because the agreement was in existence when that incident occurred and was current when I placed the motion on the Notice Paper, but the agreement was replaced from 1 July of this year. Thirdly, the hospitals in the States still benefit from the Commonwealth funds but in all States except my own State of Tasmania and South Australia the funds are channelled through the States in the form of general purpose grants identified for health. Fourthly, I have deleted the reference to 'recognised hospitals' in paragraph (3) of the motion because, if I had left it in, it would have referred only to Tasmanian and South Australian hospitals, not those in all States which receive their funds through general purpose grants. The amended motion is really just to tidy up what has happened since it was put down in November 1980.

In November 1980 a person who had previously raised this matter in the Federal Parliament-Senator Martyr-was not a member of the Senate. In November 1979, I think, he raised this matter in the House of Representatives. The matter concerns the death of a 23-month-old Down's syndrome child in the Princess Margaret Hospital in Perth. It is a story of tragedy. It is one which goes to the heart of the consciousness and conscience of the people of Australia. I refer to an appendage to the coroner's inquiry which was detailed in Perth on 13 November 1979. I refer to a letter from the foster mother of the baby, Christopher Derkacz. It was written the day after Christopher Derkacz died, which was 22 January 1979. I refer to this documentation because I feel the facts speak for themselves. I will rely not on any rhetoric that I can drum up but on hard factual information. This letter was written to the hospital on 23 January 1979, as I say, by the foster mother of Christopher Derkacz, the Down's syndrome child:
As you requested, I am writing this letter to confirm the phone conversation we had this afternoon regarding the events leading to the death of our fostered son, Christopher Derkacz.

Firstly we would like to say that Christopher was a healthy child with no abnormalities except that he was a Downes Syndrome child. On Sunday the 21st of January Christopher was cutting an eye tooth and was rather grizzly. At around 7.00 p.m. Christopher started gasping for air. We rang the Emergency Service and a doctor arranged for him to be immediately admitted to hospital. The doctor thought he would be alright in the car and wouldn't require an ambulance. On the way to the hospital Christopher's breathing was laboured but he was not gasping.

On arrival at Princess Margaret Hospital the casualty doctor quickly examined Christopher and we took him straight to the intensive care unit where he was put in a steam tent. The casualty doctor called an anaesthetist and they discussed Christopher's treatment. The doctor came into the passage way with us and told us that Christopher had croup-which confirmed the emergency doctors diagnosis. He said that they would give Christopher an anaesthetic and examine his throat to see if it as epiglottitis or an inflammation of the tubes. He explained these two types of croup and told us that while they had Christopher under the anaesthetic they would insert tubes to help him breathe. He said that once the tubes were inserted the gasping for air would cease and Christopher's breathing would be eased. We were asked to wait in the waiting area and much later the casualty doctor came and spoke to us and told us that Christopher was in the safest place. He had to go back to casualty and a woman doctor was looking after Christopher. We could still hear Christopher gasping even though we were at least 25 metres from the intensive care unit. Later we couldn't hear him and the woman doctor told us that he was still breathing heavily but his condition had improved and he was sleeping. She told us that there was nothing we could do so we might as well go home. We asked the woman doctor whether the tubes had been inserted and she said ''no, we don't think it is necessary at this time''. We took this as a good sign and his breathing was still laboured but his colour was good.

We went to see Christopher before leaving and he seemed much better. They were monitoring his heartbeat and he had an intravenous drip in his arm. The sister told us that this was to give him fluids without waking him in the night. She said that what he needed mostly was plenty of rest and as we were leaving she said ''don't worry-he'll be alright''. My husband asked her how long they usually stay in intensive care and she answered that Christopher would probably be much better in the morning as these things usually clear up quickly once they were in the steam tent. She said that Christopher would probably go into the ward in the morning.
I interpolate that in other evidence the foster mother stated that she and her husband arrived home some time after midnight, after having looked at their child. The letter continues:

At 6.00 a.m. on Monday morning I rang intensive care and enquired about Christopher and was told that he was much the same as he had been the previous night. I said I'd ring back in a couple of hours. About 8.15 a.m. Dr ... rang and asked if I was Christopher's foster mother and had taken Christopher to hospital. I said yes and asked if Christopher was alright and he answered ''no he's not, he died''. My young son rang his father who came straight home. My twenty year old son David came home from work and we went to the hospital on the way picking up our daughter Jan. We saw Christopher in the chapel in the morgue in the company of two sisters from intensive care. The sisters took us back to a room and made us a cup of tea and I started crying and blaming myself for Christopher. One of the sisters went out to get some tranquilizers for me. The other sister said ''How do you think we feel having had to stand by and do nothing''. I said ''Why couldn't you do something to help him?'' and she replied ''because we were ordered by the doctor not to''. I asked her ''Who ordered you not to do anything to help Christopher? and she replied that Doctor had.
Again, the name is here in full-

I asked her if she could have done something anyway and she said that they had done more than they were supposed to by turning him over to stimulate his breathing. She also said that ''we couldn't understand why we weren't allowed to help him-it was against everything we had been taught. They had tried to get other doctors to help him but they didn't want to get involved in Doctor W's case and the nurses said that they could only stand by and pat his hands and stroke his head and watch him die. She said ''Why did they bring him to us in the intensive care unit if they didn't intend to do the utmost to help him?'' I kept asking her why Christopher was allowed to die, was it because he was a Downes Syndrome baby and she said that that could have been the only reason.

The sister said ''Dr W's definitely not my favourite doctor-not by any means''. The sister didn't think that Christopher should have died. The other sister came back and heard a lot of this conversation. She didn't contribute much but she didn't deny anything. In fact she seemed to be backing up what the other sister said.

My husband, my daughter and myself called in at our doctor's surgery. He said that he would ring Dr G to complain about Christopher's treatment and he advised us to write a letter of complaint to Dr G.

Barbara, Christopher's real mother rang at about 5.00 p.m. and said that she had been told of Christopher's death. She asked if we would go with her to see Christopher. After she had seen him we went to casualty inquiring if the casualty doctor that we had seen on Sunday night was there but he had left an hour ago. The sister-in-charge saw how upset we were and took us to a room and got Doctor Byrne to speak to us. We told him the story and how we felt of Dr W's treatment of Christopher. He contacted the Deputy Director of the hospital, Dr Spence and they arranged a meeting at 10.00 a.m. on Tuesday with Dr W, Dr G and Dr Spence. As we thought, Doctor W did not turn up and we only saw Dr G. The meeting consisted of Christopher's mother, my husband and myself and Doctor G. The first thing he said was ''I believe you were told by staff that Chris had not been given full intensive treatment''. Doctor G said that he had spoken to the night staff and they denied having said anything to us. I told him that it was the day staff who had told us. He took notes and said that he would question them.
Other pieces of conversation then follow. The next relevant point states:

Doctor G kept harping on the fact that funds were limited for handicapped people and in his opinion things could only get worse as people weren't having large families and that there was an aging population. He said he could see that in about ten or fifteen years there would be too few young people in the world and to many old and handicapped and that he community wouldn't be able to afford to keep all these people. Dr G said that Christopher and others like him could be just a drain on the taxpayer, costing more to keep than a person on the dole.

I wish to state that I am quite happy to table all of these documents so that honourable senators are able to see them. They are parts of the coroner's report. I now come to the finding of the coroner who investigated this case. He investigated the matter over a long period in 1979 and came down with a statement on 13 November 1979. The statement is only one page long, but I think it is of great significance. It states:

Upon inquiry I find that Christopher Derkacz died on 22 January at Princess Margaret Hospital Subiaco from acute necrotising laryngitis associated with bronchiolitis, cardiac failure, early pneomonia of right upper lobe of the lung.

At approximately 7 p.m. on 21 January 1979 the deceased aged 23 months experienced respiratory trouble and his foster mother caused a locum doctor to attend the child at her home and he recommended he be admitted to Princess Margaret Hospital and his foster mother did this.

The child also suffered from Downs Syndrome. On arrival at the hospital at approximately 9 p.m. the doctor at Casualty examined him and he was admitted to Intensive Care Unit and placed in a croupette. A drip inserted and he was placed on a monitor. The doctor caused the resident anaesthetist to attend and he in turn called the consultant anaesthetist who examined him. He remained in Intensive Care Unit. The mother stayed in the hospital until a little after 11 p.m. and when she left Dr Curnow was attending the child who was still in Intensive Care Unit.

At that stage there appeared little room for criticism of the child's treatment. However after that time other than the hospital records there is little evidence of his progression, treatment or what medical attention he required or received. It is however noted that Dr Curnow attended him again at 4.15 a.m. but the notes indicate she was not called again until death. The hospital records do contain however an alarming note:
''No resus.''

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 'no resuscitation'.
—As Senator Martyr says, that stands for 'no resuscitation'. The finding continues:

SPEECH.PARA: ''(no E.C.M. no intubation)'' The child passed away at 8.05 a.m. 22 January 1979. The evidence suggests the child could have died quite suddenly.
Due principally to this lack of evidence I am unable to give a proper finding relating to the full circumstances of his death and therefore leave the finding open.

The finding is signed 'W. G. Wickens, S.M., City Coroner, 13 November 1979'. The coroner states that there was a lack of evidence. The reason for that alack of evidence is very simple. At the inquiry, two doctors and five nurses gave only their names, addresses and occupations and then stated:'I elect not to give any further evidence'. This event occurred in a recognised hospital for the purpose of funding under the then Schedule B2 of the Commonwealth-Western Australian hospital cost-sharing agreement. Furthermore, the coroner stated:
The hospital records do contain, however an alarming note:
'No resus. (no E.C.M. no intubation)'

It is quite clear from the evidence that was adduced at the hearing that had there been intubation it would have prevented the death of the child from laryngo-tracheo bronchitis. For confirmation of that statement I turn to page 31 of the evidence. Dr Anthony William Frederick Stroud, when giving evidence, stated quite flatly:
I was in court when the cause of death was given of laryngo tracheo bronchitis. I think intubation would have prevented the death from that cause.
I refer also to the evidence given by the anaesthetist registrar at the Princess Margaret Hospital, which appears at page 33, in which he stated:
I see this card on Christopher Derkacz 21.1.79. I do not recognise the hand writing of the bottom paragraph on this card. I assume it was done by the nurses in I.C.U.

However, as has been stated, there were two doctors and five nurses who refused to give evidence other than their names and addresses. The mother had stated that the child was a normally healthy child, apart from the Down's syndrome, of course. The mother in her evidence had indicated that she was quite happy to accept responsibility for the child and to look after the child throughout the whole of its life.

This raises the question as to what really is the life span of a Down's syndrome child. A lot of interest has been generated in the community over the last week in relation to Down's syndrome children. Only last Monday night, I think, there was a program on Four Corners on the question of Down's syndrome children, and a daily program, the Mike Walsh Show, had a similar program today which showed the love and attention that is poured out by the parents, and mothers in particular, on these Down's syndrome children. It is necessary, however, for the whole of the community to be aware of the difficulties that people experience and the need not only to give support to the families of handicapped children but also to give special support in the health areas for which Commonwealth moneys, taxpayers' moneys, are specified. Evidence was given at the inquiry by Dr John Millar Napier Hilton, a forensic pathologist, on the life span of the Down's syndrome children. At page 8 of the evidence he stated:
I have performed post mortem examinations on Down's syndrome patients who survive in an institution to the age of 56, and I would not pretend that is the oldest Down's syndrome patient.

So many of these people, citizens of Australia, do live to adulthood. Some of them, of course, do not. As to the question of croup, Dr John Millar Napier Hilton, the forensic pathologist, was asked at page 6:
Croup is not normally life threatening?
The doctor said:
It can be, the majority of normal children in this age can survive croup particularly if admitted to hospital and put in a croupette.
Continuing with the doctor's evidence, he was asked:
Dr Godfrey's report says that the last attack of fatal croup at P.M.H. was six years ago. You do not dispute that fact?
The doctor said.
No.
At page 11 he was asked:
Had intubation been performed, is it likely or even possible that this would have given essential time for antibiotics or other medications to take effect on the deceased?
The doctor said:
It is possible, yes.
The questioner asked:

Would you agree that had the deceased managed to survive this particular outbreak of croup and be discharged in apparent good health he may well have lived months or even years, notwithstanding the other abnormalities that were noted?
The doctor said:
He may have survived, days, weeks, months, perhaps years.

There we have a situation in which a 23-months old boy had croup. He was admitted to a hospital which was funded by the Commonwealth. It appears from the records that there was no resuscitation, no ECM, no intubation. From the evidence it would appear that had that occurred the boy's life could have been saved. It appears that a number of people need to answer a number of questions. However, my purpose in raising this matter tonight is not to put people on the spot but to see that the Commonwealth and this Parliament ensure that money which we appropriate now to go through the States to hospitals is used to save the lives of the patients. Patients must not be allowed to die just because some people consider that they are social problems, and I say that advisedly. One of the most frightening aspects of this matter is the hospital note, which says of Christopher Derkacz, the patient:
Downs' syndrome: Social

What does that mean? Why would a person have put that word 'social' on the official hospital record? That is the question we must all ask ourselves. Of course, it is something that only the person who wrote it down knows. Only that person knows, but presumably that person will not tell. Is it because there is some opinion abroad that handicapped people are social problems and therefore do not deserve the treatment that is available to everyone else, let alone the special treatment that should be given to such people? I will quote from page 25 which concerns the notes on the hospital records. Dr George Clothier, the Pediatric Registrar at the Princess Margaret Hospital states:

As we have already heard in the court some of these children have a short life expectation and have problems which are associated with their conditions and makes their life not a normal one. And so the child is allowed to pass away.

I will table this evidence. I ask in fairness that those honourable senators who are obviously interested in this issue look right through the evidence and note the very telling words of the city coroner when he talked about the alarming note on the hospital record. Have we reached a situation where we allow persons who are social problems to die? Who will decide who is a social problem and who is not? I seem to recall that the national socialists were among those in Germany in the 1930s and the 1940s who had a similar point of view. It is not limited only to this case. Sir William Liley, the world famous New Zealand doctor who is a pioneer in the techniques of surgery upon the baby in the womb, drew attention to a New Zealand case in 1974 involving a Down's syndrome baby who had bowel obstruction. This could have been overcome by simple surgery but because the child was also mentally handicapped the child was allowed to starve to death as he could not be fed if the obstruction were not removed. On that occasion dying took 13 days. A registered nurse and mid-wife in Wananui, Anne Wham also commented:

I have personal knowledge of cases where infants have been put into cold rooms, given chloral (a sedative) and left. To preserve appearances the doctors may give instructions that the child be fed 'on demand' . . . . .

What demands can a handicapped infant make after a dose or two of chloral? In conclusion I will quote from a speech made by Professor Victor Rosenblum at the International Conference on Infanticide and the Handicapped Newborn held in Chicago in December 1980. Before I do I remind the Senate that we have a responsibility to ensure that the funds we distribute to hospitals throughout the States on taxpayers behalf are used for the purpose for which they were designed, and that is the preservation of life. We do have now a Human Rights Commission. I think the public should be aware that incidents such as that which occurred in the Princess Margaret Hospital in Perth on the night of 21 January 1979 and the morning of 22 January 1979 are of a type which could be referred to that Human Rights Commission. In conclusion I will quote Professor Rosenblum's words. He said:

When the defective newborn is left to die, something vital dies within us all-our sense of justice, our self-respect, our mission as human beings. When that child is left to die, we become idolators of the plastic, the cosmetic, the illusory and the elitist. When, on the other hand, we help that child to life, we affirm our capacity to love, our respect for human difference, our dedication to the democratic values of heterogeneity as instruments of creative achievement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always with a deep sense of sadness that I speak about this matter. Already I have asked one question on this matter since I have been in the Senate. When I was in the other place I spoke about this matter several times. It always produces in me a deep sense of sadness. I have to ask myself and I think the citizens of this country have to ask themselves why these things go on. They have not happened just by accident. In this country possibly for the last 12 or 15 years there has been growing what I call a cult of death. It seems that the medical profession-and I do not say all the medical profession but a sector of it-has become so profoundly insulated from pain, suffering and death that it sees no other way of solving, except by killing, the difficult problems of this life which abound. Tonight I begin my remarks on this matter in support of Senator Harradine by saying what I said in the House of Representatives on 15 November 1979. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned because I know that the massive abortion rate in this country has conditioned the Australian people to accept this sort of thing.
This sort of thing was just described by Senator Harradine. I went on to say:
I wonder whether it is not true that Hitler has finally won, that he may have lost the war but won the philosophical battle.

We should remember that wars are fought not just for territory. They are fought for philosophical principles also. I would hate to think that this country would have this or any other similar sort of horror going on. I hope that the Government will do something about it. It is very difficult for the Federal Government to act in all of these circumstances. That is why it is so appropriate for Senator Harradine to mention these matters tonight. Now the Federal Government is in a position to monitor just where the taxpayers money is going, to see that the money is spent properly and carefully, to see that everybody who is admitted to a public hospital in receipt of Commonwealth funding is given the maximum care and attention and to make sure that doctors do not make decisions about life and death. Those of us who are believers state quite unequivocally that it is God who calls, it is God who creates life and it is God who takes us. The role of the doctor has changed almost magically in these last few years. I fear that some doctors have reached the stage of believing that, in fact, they are gods on earth. I think that some of the attitudes displayed in the case Senator Harradine has mentioned will give some truth to what I have said.

The doctor in charge of this case-I think he is now retired-at the Princess Margaret Hospital had to admit under oath that there was no evidence of any firm diagnosis of epilepsy, although on the boy's Princess Margaret Hospital record card he was described as having epileptic fits. During the inquest, counsel for Mrs Stresnik tried to get Dr Godfrey to admit that he had told Mrs Stresnik, the foster mother, that the boy was better off dead, that it was best that they did not give him treatment, et cetera. The doctor insisted that he did not recall the details of the long interview he had with the foster parents after the boy's death. However, he did think it possible that he had tried to comfort them by pointing out the problems the boy had had and would have had. He had found that that approach often helped other bereaved parents of Down's syndrome and handicapped children.

There is a clear indication of what I am talking about. Here are doctors dealing with a case that is not extreme, as I think all the evidence that Senator Harradine gave us tonight and the same evidence that I gave a year or so ago in the House of Representatives shows. All of that evidence indicates that this child was not an extremist or about to die. He was, in fact, left to die. My money and that of other senators deserves a better result than that because not only does our money keep these hospitals going but also it educates these doctors.

I am wondering about the sort of philosophy that abounds in medical schools these days. I have had one or two experiences of that philosophy. I have been invited to address medical schools and give them my particular view about the high rate of abortion and the dreadful scourge which it is in this society in which we live. The attitudes of mirth and disdain that I have encountered in medical schools that our taxes are paying for, I find utterly appalling. I do not mind being laughed at. It is not the first time it has happened and it will not be the last. I probably laugh more at myself than anybody else does. When we are invited to speak with some medical students about serious matters, they find themselves quite incapable of being serious because they appear to have no concept of the importance of the vocation that they have-the vocation of healing. Tonight, as Senator Harradine had pointed out, we have a clear case of what is going on in the medical profession. Ever since physicians began talking of the quality of life or of the desire to live as a criterion to determine who should live, they have been losing the confidence of their patients. Hints of euthanasia have introduced the element of doubt that the great first physician, Hippocrates, tried so hard to dispel.

I have enormous respect for most of the doctors I know, but there are some I have no respect for whatsoever because they are the ones I describe as the merchants of death. They will solve every single problem, whether it is the problem of Down's syndrome, which Senator Harradine spoke about tonight, whether it is the problem of extreme old age, or of course, whether it is that massive problem that causes me occasional sleepless nights, the enormous rate of abortion, which is accepted by apparently all of us in this country as not being a very great problem at all. I am sure that this enormously high rate of abortion, this contemplation of death that is so rampant in the community, must have an effect on the people whose jobs are basically to heal and to give us a concept of the importance of human life. This is why incidents like the death of young Christopher Derkacz occur; this death syndrome in this community has become so strong. I have never been a Jeremiah and I hope that I never will be, but we may be witnessing the beginning of the end of our civilisation in Australia. This sort of thing cannot go on and it certainly cannot go on without action by governments to stop it. I hope that everyone in the Senate realises that we are funding these things that are going on. We are actually paying people to kill their young. How long does a society last when this sort of thing is going on?

What are honourable senators prepared to do about it? The first thing I hope honourable senators will do is to support what Senator Harradine has done, but we have to go a long way to get ourselves straightened out. What sort of country worries about a bit of sales tax on pet meat and at least 60,000 to 80,000 abortions a year are carried out, and we are funding them. That just seems absurd to me-absolutely absurd. I have said before that the greatest problem that this country has at the moment is this problem right at the heart of our civilisation. We have to do something about it. But tonight I did not want to speak specifically on abortion. I felt compelled, as one who had originally raised this matter so long ago in the House of Representatives, that I had to support Senator Harradine, and I hope that the Senate also will support him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table the document from which I read, which is the transcript of evidence of the coroner's inquiry into the death of Christopher Derkacz.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot help but be concerned when one hears of the case which Senator Harradine brought up in the Senate tonight. From long experience, I would be very cautious of making firm judgments and too firm conclusions from what I have heard. I will certainly look at the evidence and the coroner's report which Senator Harradine has tabled tonight, so that I can judge the whole issue in detail. Let me say first of all that I firmly subscribe to the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons, which reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Disabled persons, whatever the origin, nature and seriousness of their handicaps and disabilities have the same fundamental rights as their fellow citizens of the same age, which implies first and foremost the right to enjoy a decent life as normal and full as possible.

Let me secondly say that as a human being, as a doctor and, I suppose, as a socialist, the concept that any person should receive discriminatory treatment in a hospital or elsewhere, or that any person should be allowed to die because of his or her disablement or social status, is absolutely abhorrent to me. I believe that Senator Martyr-understandably, because of his deep and passionate feelings about this, to which I have no objection-has overstated his generalised criticism of doctors in the community by calling them merchants of death on the strength of one case which has been brought to our attention from one hospital in Western Australia. To say that that case, if it is as bad as it would seem to be from Senator Harradine's remarks, is indicative of the general practice of doctors in this community-and, let us face it, I am as critical of doctors as most people are in this place: In fact, my colleague Senator Walters, who is not here, is always criticising me for doctor bashing although sometimes they need defending-and that these sorts of things are going on in hospitals all over Australia all the time, which one could fairly imply from the remarks of Senator Martyr, is wrong, unfair and unjust.

I am as disturbed as anyone at the reported remarks of one doctor in this case, who is obviously allowing his philosophical, or even his political, views to interfere with his treatment of patients, as I was disurbed the other day to read of the gynaecologist in South Australia who, because of her disapproval of unmarried mothers or mothers who were separated from their husbands, felt that she could ignore her responsibilities as a doctor and not treat them. There are always exceptions in our community. There have always been, through the history of medicine, times when people have made bad judgments and allowed people to die under certain circumstances. There are, indeed, other situations in which sometimes it is best not to proceed rigorously unnecessarily and sometimes against the wish of the patient, which certainly did not apply in this case, with treatment to prolong life for a day, a week or some other period. It is not always black and white. There are sometimes grey areas.

When I saw the terms of the motion, not knowing the details of the case, I really wondered what we would achieve by passing it because there are certain things and certain questions which have not been answered by Senator Harradine and, particularly, Senator Martyr, who I understand has had a long interest in this case. It seems to me that the law of Western Australia, and I would have said before Senator Harradine gave us the evidence that the law of Western Australia is the law in most of the States, should be sufficient to cover such situations and to protect the rights of this boy and certainly the rights of his foster parents in any such decision.

I am at a bit of a loss to understand how people can refuse to give evidence at an inquest and how a coroner can bring down such a disturbing decision without some inquiry, some government action or some legal action following the outcry which obviously must have arisen in such circumstances. I say to Senator Harradine that I cannot imagine such a situation arising in our State of Tasmania. Therefore, I merely ask the question: Are there other facts and factors that we do not know about? It is inexplicable to me that a coroner can say: 'I cannot make a proper finding because people have elected not to give evidence', and nothing happens. It seems to me that at the very least the law in Western Australia-I would be interested to ascertain whether it applies in other States-is deficient in this regard. I believe that this Parliament or the Western Australian Parliament would be taking much more effective action if it could take some steps to make sure that in the event of this sort of occurrence people do not just walk away from an inquest by saying that they elect not to give evidence.

I have only one concern about Senator Harradine's amended motion, and that is the part at the end of the motion that the Senate recommends that the Minister for Health investigate existing practices in hospitals which are partially funded by the Commonwealth through the States and report to the Federal Parliament. This is a very broad request. I assume that it refers to circumstances in respect of the treatment of disabled and handicapped people such as this unfortunate child who suffered from Down's syndrome. I assume that it refers to the rights of parents and foster parents in circumstances such as this. I assume also that it refers to the rights of doctors to make judgment of the type that seem to have been made in this case. Even if it refers only to that area, it involves a massive investigation. It involves not only an investigation but also a long term monitoring of the situation in hospitals. It also involves a situation in which the Commonwealth Government would be going in and making an investigation of this sort in hospitals which under law, I believe, are in fact regulated by State regulations and State laws.

I certainly have no objection to the motion down to the word 'attention'. I do not suppose that I would worry much about the rest of the motion, except that I wonder about the practicality of it. I wonder about what we are going to achieve by doing this. Is the Minister for Health to send a team of workers on a long term continued investigation of what is going on in this area or is he just to send a few officers around to ask a few people in each hospital a few questions and get the same sort of answers that the coroner got and end up in the situation in which the coroner found himself when he really could not come to a reasonable decision? If this is what will happen we will have achieved nothing. Would it not be better to look at the state of the law which protects the patients and the parents? Would it not be better to spend the money that would be involved in an investigation of the sort suggested by Senator Harradine on developing skills and ensuring that in fact the positive aspects of hospital treatment were being carried out? Would it not be better to do this than to have an inquiry which would report to this Parliament in, I suggest, an inadequate way? I would be interested to hear what the representatives of the Government have to say about that. I will be interested to hear what Senator Harradine has to say in reply.

All I can say is that the case that Senator Harradine has raised certainly disturbs me. That people, on the face of it, could take such action in such a case equally disturbs me. That there is even a suggestion that any patient in any hospital in this country is classified as socially less desirable or at a lower social level than anyone else and therefore receives treatment such as has been outlined certainly disturbs me. That a coroner at an inquest in this country can bring down a report in which he says: 'I cannot make a proper finding because I have not got enough evidence and the reason I have not got enough evidence is that people will not answer my questions' certainly should disturb everyone in this place. But what is absolutely inexplicable to me is that all of those circumstances can occur and yet apparently the case stops there. No action is taken after the coroner's critical decision. I understand from my colleague Senator Giles that there was considerable public outcry in Western Australia after that decision was given. I do not understand the position. I would like an explanation. I would like to think that we could do something more positive about the law in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is clearly motivated by a very deep concern on Senator Harradine's part about the continuing debate within the community concerning children born with recognised handicaps, their prognosis and the level of intervention undertaken by health professionals in providing care for them. I think we have all been very reflective in the Senate this evening about what has been said by the honourable senators who have spoken. I share with everyone who has listened intently to this discussion the feeling that that very precious quality of life was placed under some question by the incident that has been recalled.

SPEECH.PARA: The case referred to by Senator Harradine in his motion relates to the death in January 1979 in the Princess Margaret Hospital for Children, Perth, of a 23-month-old child, Christopher Derkacz, who suffered from a respiratory complaint. The case aroused a considerable amount of public controversy and received widespread coverage in the media due to allegations that Christopher, who was a Down's syndrome child, had not been given full medical attention at the time. The incident was the subject of a number of representations to Government members and, as the matter was primarily one of concern for the Government of Western Australia, the Commonwealth had no authority to intrude into an issue of this nature. As we have heard, a coronial inquiry subsequently reported an open finding due to lack of evidence.

We have heard the comments of Senator Grimes and others with regard to that matter. It is recognised that such situations clearly have a tremendous impact on the parents of the child and on the health professionals involved and they raise deep moral issues for many people not directly affected by the particular case. The reaction of a parent to a situation in which a child might be seen to be needing health services and the response of the health professions in providing those services are issues which, if necessary, should be handled by law rather than through the administration of individual institutions.

Problems of possible conflict between the rights of childen and parents and the uncertainty of medical practitioners and other health professionals as to their legal position in providing or withdrawing services in certain situations prompted recent examination of the questions by the National Health and Medical Research Council at its Eighty-Eighth meeting in October 1979. That Council recommended that the Australian Law Reform Commission be requested to review the existing legislation throughout Australia concerning all aspects of the provision of medical services to minors, with the view to recommending uniform legislation setting out circumstances in which such services may be supplied by medical and other health professionals.

I think this touches on a point raised by Senator Grimes in that we would have to ask how the state of affairs described could exist in the treatment or lack of treatment that may be required by patients in hospitals or other institutions. Following referral initially to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, it was agreed that the Western Australian Law Reform Commission be nominated to examine the matter-that is, this matter the subject of our consideration tonight. I understand that liaison between the latter group and the National Health and Medical Research Council has been established and investigations into the several issues are proceeding.

The fact that a particular action takes place in a recognised hospital as opposed to any other type of hospital is not really relevant to the appropriateness or otherwise of the care provided in a particular instance. However, the implication of the motion is that in a situation where the Commonwealth Government is cost sharing hospital services-I remind the Senate that this now only applies to the States of South Australia and Tasmania-as a provider of funds to the States the Commonwealth should accept responsibility in relation to the specific services provided within each of the States' health services. Without in any way seeking to detract from what might be behind Senator Harradine's motion, this would seem an unrealistic expectation. I share with Senator Grimes the concern that he expressed with regard to the very broad request that is involved in the motion before us.

Senator Grimes also touched on the constitutional position of the Commonwealth Government in regard to the hospitals which have the provision of State law for their administration. In fact, I really ought to say there is no basis upon which the Commonwealth could launch an investigation into professional medical practices in a State-run health service such as a public hospital. The States' historical and constitutional role in this area is clearly defined. Of course, the Commonwealth is concerned to see that the highest standards of professional responsibility are observed; the Commonwealth is concerned also to see areas of doubt and confusion over legal issues minimised. As I said, such matters were discussed by the Attorneys-General earlier following this case. However, I do not believe that a specific Commonwealth investigation into the internal administration of a State health service would now be appropriate. This is quite apart from the more basic issue of the Government's concern not to interfere with the day to day running of health services to which it contributes through general revenue grants. The purpose of moving to general purpose grants was to ensure that health service priorities and operations were fully accepted as the responsibility of the States; with the exception of those two States which are still being funded under the old arrangement.

The Government has great sympathy for the motion moved by Senator Harradine. Because of the constitutional difficulties involved in it, I suggest an amendment to the motion. If Senator Harradine and the Senate wish to look at the amendment the Government would be happy to support we may, if Senator Harradine wishes to have a right of reply, deal with that amendment this evening. Judging by what Senator Grimes said on behalf of the Opposition, I feel he also may feel the Opposition would support this amendment. Perhaps the amendment can be circulated amongst honourable senators. If the Senate will bear with me, I will read the amendment. I move:
Leave out the words after 'that' (first occurring), insert-
'The Senate-

(1) Notes that in 1979 a twenty-three month old Down's Syndrome boy was admitted to a 'recognised hospital' under Schedule B2 of the then Commonwealth-Western Australia Hospital costs sharing agreement and that he died the following day in circumstances in which his parents and many other people believe that insufficient effort was made to preserve the child's life.

(2) Is of the opinion that-(A) being the international year of disabled persons it would be particularly appropriate for special attention to be devoted to the care and treatment of disabled persons; (B) disabled persons who suffer from physical and mental handicaps and incur some additional form of illness require particular assistance and attention.

I think that what is encompassed in the amendment is that we comprehend the concern of the Senate for the particular case and have noted the particular case brought forward. We have stressed that it would be particularly appropriate for special attention to be devoted to the care and treatment of disabled persons and that we believe that people who have physical and mental handicaps and who incur some additional form of illness require particular assistance and attention. I feel that is a very positive way in which to express the view of the Senate, not only in noting this particular instance but also in showing our opinion of the care and attention that is required.

I have moved the amendment in this form simply to overcome what would be very real difficulties in the constitutional position of the State hospital system for the Commonwealth to conduct the type of inquiry that may have been envisaged in the original motion. We have great sympathy for the motion. The way it has been debated in the Senate I think has provided a good opportunity for the expression of the kind of ideas in the amendment. I commend that amendment to the Senate and seek from Senator Harradine his reaction to the support of the Senate for an amendment of this nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report upon all aspects of the civil defence programme against nuclear attack, with particular reference to-
(a) Location and numbers of underground nuclear attack shelters; and

(b) identification of and planning for areas in peripheral regions of major Australian cities in which inexpensive civil defence activity might greatly assist in the saving of life in the event of nuclear attack.
(2) That provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent Resolution.

I move this motion from a sense of deep conviction that this is a subject about which we are not doing enough. We are beholden as members of this Parliament to look at the matter and consider again perhaps things we have looked at before and considered in certain light and which may have altered with the passing of the years with the altering of circumstances in the world, particularly in relation to weaponry.

Last year world-wide military expenditure amounted to more than $1m for every minute of every day. This year, especially with the emphasis placed by President Reagan on nuclear superiority over the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, military spending and in particular spending on nuclear weaponry will reach unprecedented heights. In spite of this the Government, on the evidence we have had and the utterances we have heard so far, has elected, as a conscious policy, to turn a blind eye to the civil defence of our population. To me this seems to be an abdication of responsibility of a degree which is almost mind-shattering, although I am not, because of this neglect, unduly critical of the Government because I think it, for one reason or other, has seen the problem either as too huge or one which various people in the community have induced it not to look at at all. In fact, I think it is short-sighted and rather blind, but there might well be good reasons for its being that way.

Our major cities-all of them are close to the coast-are surely among the most vulnerable in the world to nuclear attack. Oddly enough, as many of us must reflect, for a society with strongly rural traditions we have one of the highest rates of urban concentration in the world. Something like three-quarters of our total population lives in these exposed cities near the sea, and probably 90 per cent of our heavy industry is there. Much of our defence capability is centred on these main cities, although at least in this area there is now beginning to be some effort at decentralisation, which the Australian Democrats applaud. In passing I would like to mention that the location of the major naval base at Garden Island in the centre of the main city area of Sydney seems a most curious and dangerous anomaly in this day and age and it is something which ought to be looked at from a proper point of view. Indeed, that is an area which could attract attack from perhaps even a quite small force to take out what appears to be an important base. At the same time this could destroy large areas of the biggest and most populous city in this nation.

It is an axiom of modern war that if enough missiles with nuclear warheads are dispatched some must find their mark, and this would apply even when there are powerful defence mechanisms. Because we are too small a community to afford such defence mechanisms, our position is all the more naked and exposed. Let us face the fact that our cities are sitting ducks. If an enemy wished to attack them, even with a quite small force, that attack would succed. Do we have defence associations which make us more susceptible to attack in the event of war? I suggest that in recent months there has been a growing awareness in the community that indeed we have. Having faced up to that I think we also have to face up to its implications. The Pine Gap base has been described in the United States magazine Aviation Week Space Technology as part of the United States vital western Pacific radar fence. The Tranet satellite tracking station at Smithfield on the outskirts of Adelaide is one of the 22 stations which make up the world-wide United States Navstar system-the navigational system which provides United States nuclear missiles with their pinpoint accuracy.

The head of the United States Strategic Air Command has told the United States Congress of plans to use B52 aircraft operating from bases outside the United States of America armed with tactical weapons to attack Soviet forces in the Middle East. A Darwin-based B52 would have the range to reach most areas of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics without refuelling. It would be naive of us-surely we would be hiding our heads in the sand unduly-to imagine or have fond hopes that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is not aware of this. Of course it is aware of it. In fact, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics may well be far more aware of what goes on in the bases on Australian soil than we are. Our cities then could be attacked. Would they be attacked with impunity? Granted a situation in which our major allies were occupied, even extended, elsewhere, the answer of course is yes. We have no means of defence, no means of striking back. Our appalling lack of civil defence, I suggest, makes us, in the cold logic of modern military planning, a more attractive target. Looked at with the cold eye of attack strategy, it is obviously more profitable to hit an enemy who is unprepared and against whom an attack will have the maximum effect than one who is prepared. I think it devolves on us to face these hard truths.

There is a further factor the Australian Democrats believe we ought to take into account. Because of the remoteness, especially of our larger cities on the eastern seaboard from centres of population in any other nation, an enemy would not be deterred by the fear of nuclear fall-out on a third and possibly friendly power as he would be in Europe as a result of attack. This then adds to the probability of an attack on Australian cities in the event of war. It has been theorised regularly that one step short of major war may well be the 'taking out' of small allies on both sides. Australia must present itself attractively in this role, and the closer our defence association with a major zonal power the greater that likelihood must become. This growing risk has been admitted by a number of our leaders and some defence officials. According to an article in the Australian on 30 July 1980 a Department of Defence official had conceded that Australia could be the target of a nuclear attack if war broke out between the Soviet Union and the United States. The Department's first assistant secretary of strategic international policy, Mr Bob Hamilton, told a two-day seminar at Laverton Royal Australian Air Force base that there was little Australia could do if such a nuclear attack were launched. In February 1981, Mr Robert Malthans, who until 1979 was a senior officer of the Joint Intelligence Organisation, gave evidence to a parliamentary sub-committee on foreign affairs and defence, in his expert opinion, in the case of war between the super-powers, North West Cape would be a prime nuclear target and Pine Gap and Nurrungar would also be likely nuclear targets. In July this year Professor Butlin of the Australian national university said the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics could be tempted to a deterrent 'demonstration' strike as tensions mounted and whilst several countries might offer themselves as suitable targets, Australia certainly would because of the United States installations.

I raised this matter myself on 27 February last year in a series of questions to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick. I raised it at that time because not a single word was mentioned about civil defence in the three closely typed pages in the overall defence statement on Afghanistan put down in February by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Nevertheless the Prime Minister himself at that time conceded that Australia was coming into greater risk of being involved in war. His comment to me, a supremely ironic one, was 'as the risk increases, it is prudent to increase insurance'. Is there any hint that there might be an increased risk? When I asked Senator Carrick whether a single submarine, armed with nuclear weapons, could cause extensive casualties and what preparations had been made for civil defence in Australia, he answered:

The Commonwealth Government, through the Prime Minister, has been attempting to restore conditions in this world to a balance of nuclear power so that we have peace, however unhappily, on the basis of mutual terror.
Senator Carrick agreed that any city could be wiped out from such a submarine as I mentioned, and said he was not aware of the precise progress made in the area of civil defence around Australia.

On 25 March 1981 the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) issued a 35-page statement. Again there was no mention at all of civil defence, as if this area of defence was something of no importance at all in our community. The Government's attitude seems to us plain enough. It represents a simple, appalled throwing-up of the hands, a policy of complete and, to me, dangerous irresponsibility for the safety of the Australian people if deterrence fails as a policy, and surely that could happen at any time. Surely this is a contingency which all of us know and live with from year to year, from decade to decade. When this is associated with plain statements from our own Prime Minister that indeed war may be close and deterrence may indeed fail, I believe the situation calls for urgent re-examination. Is the picture indeed so gloomy and hopeless within Australia as to justify the Government's view, which seems to me to be inspired by the view that if there is a nuclear attack on this country we will all be destroyed and nothing will survive? If I could believe that, I could perhaps understand the Government's point of view, but is that view based on a certain carelessness, a certain laziness, a certain failure to look coldly and with perception at the likely scenarios?

At the twenty-sixth session of the Western European Union in Paris in June 1980 the Union underlined as a major cause of concern the impelling need for civil defence shelters in its own countries of France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, Luxembourg, Belgium and Holland. All of us who know anything about the continent of Europe understand that the closeness of population and civilisation there-the intenseness and tightness of the cities with their huge population areas-makes these underground shelters an absolute necessity if any of the people are to survive in the event of a nuclear war.

Australian cities are altogether different. Although they are vulnerable enough to attack, they are different in character from most European cities. They tend to sprawl over much larger total areas and they are further removed from other smaller areas of population to which people could be evacuated and which would probably be immune from any damage in the case of an attack. The existence of this greater extent of space in our country seems to be a vitally important consideration.

Assuming submarine-based attacks which might be launched, I think feasibly, from only two submarines on a basis of one missile per city, it is generally accepted that the major Australian cities would not be completely destroyed. One submarine-based conventional nuclear war missile, depending on wind speed and direction, might destroy perhaps half of the buildings and kill perhaps half of the population from the initial firestorm, blast and high level radiation. These ideas have been developed on a number of occasions by commentators. In fact, it has been estimated that one conventional nuclear missile with a one-megaton warhead would kill at least 30,000 people in the first minute after impact and at least half a million people within 12 months from radiation sickness brought on by radioactive fallout. I draw the attention of honourable senators, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the contrast between those two figures-30,000 who would be killed immediately and half a million who would fall victims of radiation sickness over the next 12 months.

The scenario of an attack with the enhanced radiation warhead, the so-called neutron bomb, would show a similar effect although not so devastating, perhaps. This warhead is designed to minimise the output of blast and heat and maximise the output of prompt radiation in the form of neutrons and gamma rays. The accepted lethal dose of radiation would be inflicted on individuals within a radius of about one kilometre from the projected point of impact. If the device were exploded at approximately 900 metres above the ground virtually no blast would reach the ground at all. In addition to destroying living cells, the radiation from this warhead has also been demonstrated to knock out radar systems in the vicinity. Most of the irradiated area then could be re-entered one or two hours after exposure. Granted efficient and organised, although minimally expensive, civil defence procedures, the peripheral regions of our cities could be evacuated and probably the lives of millions of people saved.

Without such procedures most of these people would die. Furthermore-I am talking about women and children-their deaths would not be easy ones, but painful and protracted, caused by minor injuries, mild radiation sickness, consequent infection and exposure and starvation, which would be associated with attempts to escape, without help and without organisation on an individual basis. The scenario is surely horrifying enough. Even more horrifying is the thought that we are not regarding it with a degree of responsibility we should do as members of this Parliament. These are the key considerations which I believe need further examination and which should in form our overall policy. They are far beyond my ability to comprehend or analyse or that of the Australian Democrats. That is why I believe a select committee of the Senate ought to have that responsibility, and soon.

Would attacks on our cities be made by only one missile or would there be a blanket attack of, say, 10 missiles a city, which would effectively destroy the environs as well? My own belief is that, for a variety of reasons, the most probable scenario would be a single weapon attack. Limited nuclear exchange, if such a thing were possible, probably would not involve attack on the Australian cities, except perhaps Adelaide which would be involved with the base, although this might depend a good deal on the zone of the major operation-whether it was close to us, say in South East Asia, or remote, as in Europe.

However, even in a zone of operation close to us, a limited war would probably involve attack only on such facilities as Pine Gap, the North West Cape, Omega in Gippsland and the Tranet tracking station outside Adelaide. The threat of strategic strikes at the Australian cities could come in circumstances where our allies would be least likely to be able to provide us with any support-a nuclear exchange which closely approached or actually was all-out zonal war. Granted a major conflict between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, it seems likely that attacks would be made by missile-bearing submarines on allies of the major protagonists. Indeed, one finds this now in every military text book on nuclear war. Indeed, some analysts assert that such cities are already included in the computerised target lists of nuclear submarines. I have no doubt that our cities are on those lists and that only a push of a button would be necessary to launch the missiles against them.

The rationale for this appears to be, strategically, that, if the major zonal powers were severely weakened by the consequences of nuclear attack, it would be dangerous to allow an ally of the other side to remain untouched. In such a case, former middle powers might emerge in a dominant position and even represent a threat to the erstwhile major powers. From the point of view of a major power that seems, if a diabolical, at least a respectable point of view. There is, of course, no problem about launching the weapons. There are many more submarines and weapons than would be necessary due to the overkill nature of nuclear weapons on both sides. A comment on the extent of overkill was made in August1980 by the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Authority, Dr Sigvard Eklund, when he remarked that some 50,000 nuclear bombs in existence now had a combined explosive power equal to over a million times the power of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945.

Such an attack on middle power type allies would probably be in the form of a single strike, launched without warning, and could be over in a matter of minutes, or at most, hours. Its objective would be to weaken the morale and fighting effectiveness of the middle power by striking at its major centres of population, government and industry. No intent ultimately to occupy or conquer the middle range power would be involved. The intent would merely be to cripple. This scenerio naturally spells major destruction when applied to the crowded industrial cities of northern Europe. Australia's case, because of the existence of large country towns far from these major points of attack, the amount of spacing between settled areas and the dispersed nature of the major cities themselves, the effects would be altogether different in this type of attack.

These implications should be studied closely. The Australian Democrats believe in a policy to develop the rescue of as much of the metropolitan populations as possible. We believe, in view of its tremendous importance, that this can be done at reasonably low cost. It seems relevant, for instance, that there are fertile areas, including hinterland cities, near our largest cities, near our metropolises, which should emerge intact from a nuclear attack on the metropolis itself. I think of such places in New South Wales as Bathurst-Orange to which there is a highly efficient train line and good quality roads. Almost 10 million Australians live in the State capitals and other major coastal cities, including Geelong, Newcastle and Wollongong.

A single submarine-based nuclear weapon strike on each of these major cities would destroy the central areas and the suburbs for between three miles and six miles from the point of impact. It should be mentioned again how much wind speed and direction must influence other effects. A strong westerly would, for instance, carry fall-out over Sydney safely out to sea and would leave much of the western suburbs of Sydney relatively unscathed. The summer afternoon north-easters would extend a pattern of fall-out across a major additional region of population, namely, the south-western suburbs. More than 4 million Australians live on farms and in country cities and towns. These people would, with minimal precautions against eventual fall-out, survive the kind of attack which would affect almost the whole national population of, say, the Netherlands or Belgium. A first long term requirement of Australian civil defence should surely be to make our inland regional cities as autonomous as possible, with some adequate means, locally, of producing at least motor spirit and electric power. This is an important reason--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the drop forgings?

—Yes, that is a good point. In other words, we would have to have a basis of industry there as well. There are the sorts of matters which would emerge, I suggest, in an inquiry by a select committee. Obviously we have to have something there that can get industry together again. This is an important reason for the long held Australian Democrats policy favouring regional distilleries, for instance, producing fuel ethanol from crops as an alternative motor spirit even if for some years such ethanol production is at higher cost than imported oil. Highly intensive, localised, all-eggs-in-one-basket projects, such as the unfortunate Rundle shale efforts, which we heard so much about last year but about which I suspect we will not hear so much in the future, and the Gippsland project to produce oil from coal do not, and never could, meet this strategic requirement, quite apart from any other consideration. They could be knocked out very quickly and easily with a single bomb. Where would we be then? I sometimes think that foreign defence planners must think we are a curiously naive society when they see the direction in which we are developing our industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There are arguments that small, localised hydro-electric or solar electricity facilities are not cost effective, although with the latest research promising plastic, mass-produced photo-electric material on plastic or metal substrates, power will be produced at 50c per peak watt. I believe the Government ought to be keeping a close eye on regional plants which would eventually use such methods and which should also use wind generators where possible. There facilities could feed power into a national grid and could provide minimal but reliable power resources if major power houses or reticulation lines were destroyed. Batteries of wind generators in suitable areas ought also to be considered. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
