SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening I was referring to the necessity for the decentralisation of facilities in our regional cities which conceivably-I hope this is not the case-will be at some stage the beginning again of civilisation such as we have in this country. I think they should be regarded in that light as a precious asset which we have and which is almost unique in the world. Very few countries of our size have that kind of social and geographic organisation. These regional cities are strategically important because they would be the obvious evacuation areas in which those from the outer environs of the major coastal cities could be accommodated and treated.

SPEECH.PARA: These people could be assumed to be suffering mostly from exhaustion and mild radiation sickness. Hence large supplies of blood plasma would need to be held in these evacuation centres as blood transfusion is a key factor in the treatment of persons suffering from mild to moderate radiation sickness. Indeed, blood transfusion can influence a person's very life or death in many cases. I think that if that were put properly to the Australian people there would be no difficulty in obtaining those stocks of blood plasma. Certainly in the event of a nuclear attack of the type I have postulated many hundreds of thousands of people would need organised, systematic help, which would include that kind of blood transfusion, to save their lives.

It would be reasonable to suppose that the survivors of such an attack-not necessarily the injured or sick, but the survivors-could amount to half the population of our major cities; that is, a total of five million people. Of those people, perhaps one million or two million might be in urgent need of medical attention. What about the other half? Can precautions be taken on their behalf? The answer is that such precautions could be taken, including mainly the construction of huge numbers of properly built and equipped underground shelters. However, as other countries have found, the cost of the diversion of the national effort to such a program would be enormous. For instance, Switzerland is carrying out such a comprehensive civil defence program at an initial cost of $A2.4 billion. Such shelters would also be very many years in the building stage even after a decision had been taken to go ahead. The Australian Democrats believe that they would be inappropriate and that we should look at how we can cut our losses most easily. The proposal I am now advancing would be much more sensible and certainly much more modest in cost.

I have been informed by those now struggling on in the civil defence area that, in their opinion, much could be done with a budget of perhaps $10m a year initially, provided it was spent in an organised and professional fashion. This could be based on a fully researched and detailed program to use existing means of transport, especially trains on lines, to get people to key country cities where emergency accommodation and first aid could be provided following an initial simple program of decontamination and clothing replacement.

Decontamination, in the case of mild exposure to radiation, is in theory simple-transport out of the contaminated area, shedding of contaminated clothing, cleansing the skin with soap and water in a shower stall, and providing clean clothing. Used or discarded clothing could be recycled or organised for this purpose and held in stores. Portable shower stalls in groups, perhaps of a knock-down design which could be carried in trucks and erected on any site where there is a clean water supply, would meet the first need of decontamination. There is no need for us to try to design those from scratch; they are already provided in other countries and have existed for many years. It would not be too difficult for us to do the same thing. Work on evolving and making such facilities has been done as a part of civil defence planning in many places.

Efficient use of existing transport facilities at any time at short notice would seem to be dependent upon constant monitoring and holding on computer programs of the movement of trains actually in the system at all times. These could then be commandeered and used in an organised way to provide a shuttle evacuation service from points in the outer areas of the cities. Existing railway stations could be used as pickup points. Buses and even convoys of private cars could be organised in a similar way and controlled so that roads could carry maximum traffic in one direction without becoming jammed and hence useless. Consider what the situation would be without this organisation on the roads outside our major cities if there were a nuclear attack. Any honourable senator who cannot imagine the horrors of that situation cannot have very much imagination. This, then, could be easily changed by a little forethought.

None of these objectives is beyond a simple, fairly expensive but professional and efficient organisation which is maintained and funded adequately and provided with sufficiently good technical staff. It seems painfully obvious to me that evacuation procedures would need to be controlled. This is not something that could be done effectively at short notice: it is not something that we will be able to do when the bombs have started falling. It has to be planned in advance and there has to be a state of readiness 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year. I mention the unpleasant things I have referred to with some distaste. I am sure honourable senators must hear them with distaste. Yet I think they must be considered and faced up to because they would quite inevitably be the result of lack of action now on the part of the Government and the community.

What is happening in other countries? I have mentioned the Swiss effort, the intensity of which is interesting, since most important decisions are taken in Switzerland as a result of consultation with the community as a whole. I have also mentioned the urgency with which a number of other European countries view this problem. Norway already has shelters to house 70 per cent of its population. Denmark has shelters for 60 per cent of its population. In the United States, the civil defence program is administered by the Defence Civil Preparedness Agency-the DCPA. About 7,000 people are already directly employed in civil defence programs. the 1978 budget was $98m but many people actually involved in civil defence planning consider this sum inadequate. The United States plan is based on relocation of the population from high risk areas such as metropolitan centres, the vicinity of military bases and industrial areas to low risk regions and on sheltering the population from fallout in specially built centres. However, the program has not as yet really begun to achieve its objectives, that is, 125,000,000 adequately stocked shelter spaces and the training of 2 1/2 million people in radiological monitoring, shelter management and other related skills. I stress to honourable senators the importance of radiological monitoring and I point out that a group of people has been in touch with me and is only too ready to organise that as a voluntary organisation in this country if the Government would only ask it.

The DCPA in America is concerned about the program which it says has been hampered by a lack of funds and public apathy. This question of public apathy has arisen in Australia. But I suggest that it is reasonable that members of the public should feel apathetic about this matter. They have to live their lives. It is not something that they should be worrying about. It is not something about which they should have to make decisions. It is something that we should be making decisions about on their behalf.

For information about what is happening in the Soviet Union, the researcher is entirely dependent on information from Soviet official sources and observations made by Soviet migrants. According to these sources, the civil defence program of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is under the management of General A. Altunin, Deputy Minister of Defence and a full member of the Soviet Central Committee. Each Soviet republic has a general in command of its own civil defence program. Expenditure in the USSR on civil defence has been estimated at the lowest at $A1.8 billion per year. The four major elements of the program are: Protection of the population; protection of the economy; post-strike rescue and recovery; training of the population.

The protection of the population includes the following: The urban population can be relocated in a rural area within 72 hours. There is even speculation that plans are so detailed that each rural family knows the name of the urban family to be billeted with it. It is planned to equip every citizen with a gas mask, protective clothing and a first aid kit. Blast shelters have been built and are designed to accommodate 300 people each. The Moscow subway, which is equipped with blast-proof doors, can accommodate one million people as a shelter. Fallout shelters are being built in suburban and rural areas.

Protection of the economy includes the following: Dispersal and hardening of industry-that is, bomb resistant construction, low building density and protection of fire departments, pumping stations and power systems; urban planning, including making each region self-supporting; agricultural protection including protective masks for critical livestock, fallout-proof barns and storage facilities and training of agricultural workers in the decontamination of crops and livestock; stockpiling of enough food and grain to sustain the population for one year at subsistence levels and also of coal, oil, iron ore, steel, cement and cotton.

Rescue and recovery operations include 100,000 members of the armed forces in civil defence units; industrial personnel and farmers are also being organised into units and trained in the following areas: Clearing and decontamination of access routes and work areas; communications; medical and paramedical skills; monitoring of levels of radiation and chemical contamination; rescue of population from strike area. Again, this is a major priority always. The rescue and recovery operations also include fire fighting, repair of broken water and gas mains and power lines. It is planned to train at least 30 million citizens in civil defence skills.

Civil defence training in the USSR is compulsory. Courses are taught in school grades two, five and nine, youth organisations, universities, factories, training villages and at a four-year course for officers at the civil defence academy in Moscow. I think it is obvious-I have detailed these things for honourable senators-that in other parts of the world this problem is being taken very seriously indeed. I suggest that surely we are not so clever here that we feel we have any kind of immunity, that the problems that these people are going to so much trouble to cope with are not going to be visited on us. I think we would be naive and foolish to take that view. Australia must consider this matter seriously. This country needs a viable program of civil defence and needs it now. I have said previously, and I say it again, that I am by no means an expert in this area, although I have tried to find out some facts on it. It is an area that needs a concentrated opinion brought to it by responsible and informed members of the society. Those people exist, and many of them have been in touch with me since I first raised this matter. I think the ideal way in which this should be done would be by a select committee of the Senate. The task, I believe, is an urgent one. If we let it slide and we do nothing about it, the day might come when every one of us in this chamber might regret it bitterly. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement by the National Health and Medical Research Council on the herbicide 2,4,5-T presented to the Senate on 29 March 1979.

I should have thought that the Senate would have had enough of me for the moment. I will not speak for very long on this rather antique report. I think it has certain current relevance, and I am hoping that if honourable senators are indifferent to the problem of civil defence, perhaps they are not also indifferent to the problems of 2,4,5-T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly not.

—I should think not. In moving that the Senate take note of the statement by the National Health and Medical Research Council on the herbicide 2,4,5-T presented to the Senate on 29 March 1979-a rather elderly report-I would like to discuss some of the more recent developments which have occurred in the matter of the safety of the herbicide 2,4,5-T.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators will know, it is the toxic trace contaminant TCDD, commonly known as dioxin, which is implicated as the cause of the statistical link between the use of 2,4,5-T and cancer, birth defects and other abnormalities in those who come into contact with the herbicide. TCDD is formed unavoidably during the production of 2,4,5-T and it is not possible to eliminate it from the herbicide completely. We have read recently of dumped dioxin, concentrated and extremely dangerous, which is still lying buried in public, earth-filled dumps in the Sydney area. Honourable senators may remember that in February of last year I raised the question of what was to be done with this waste dioxin and how the New South Wales State Pollution Control Commission proposed to deal with future dumping of this poison. I have still not received a satisfactory answer and I still consider those drums of dioxin are a time bomb, ticking away towards some future contamination. Used properly, with all precautions taken, 2,4,5-T may be relatively harmless. But is it always used properly? Is it used responsibly even most of the time? I suggest that that is probably not the case.

Residents in the area around Bright, in northern Victoria, recently forced their Forests Commission of Victoria to postpone the spraying of pine plantations with 2,4,5-T by threatening to seek a Supreme Court injunction on the grounds that the use of the herbicide constituted a health risk to residents. These people became concerned when they heard that a helicopter would be used to spray the plantations. Pregnant women were, of course, particularly concerned and many felt that they would have to stay elsewhere while the spraying was in progress and until the spray settled properly. A Victorian State instrumentality planned to spray this suspect herbicide from aircraft whilst a Victorian Government financed study on the link between soft tissue cancer and exposure to 2,4,5-T, announced three months earlier, is in progress. This leads me sometimes to despair about the processes of government.

What of the actual level of TCDD found in the 2,4,5-T used in Australia. The acceptable level in this country-if indeed any level is acceptable-is 0.1 parts per million. This sounds like, and indeed is, an extremely small amount. But it should be kept in mind that one medicine drop of pure dioxin has been estimated to be able to kill 1,200 people if dispersed in water or in some like way. Earlier this year Dr Peter Hall and Dr Ben Selinger of the Australian National University published a paper demonstrating that a firm statistical link existed between the hundreds of tonnes of agent orange imported into Australia in the early 1970s and the highly significant increase in Australian neonatal mortality in the mid-1970s from certain types of congenital abnormalities.

Agent orange, of course, is a mixture of 2,4,5,-T and another herbicide, 2,4-D. It contains, and this is the important point, very high levels of dioxin-somewhere between 180 and 260 times the acceptable level of dioxin in Australia now. The Australian Democrats would like to know where all this imported agent orange went to. Apparently it was sold somewhere in this country as acceptable 2,4,5-T, either in its original form or mixed with herbicide which was manufactured here. That happened in spite of its enormously high dioxin level. Some of it is probably still around now. It may be being sprayed and used even this week as we sit in this place.

That was an appalling state of affairs, but it did happen 10 years ago. Surely nothing like it could occur again? Or could it? This month the West Australian Government recalled 4,000 litres of 2,4,5-T because it contained four times the acceptable level of dioxin. There is no doubt that 2,4,5-T can be dangerous. But how dangerous is it? Can it be used safely if strict rules for use are drawn up and strigently enforced? Should we draw up these rules? Should we look at matters such as spraying it into waterways or on to the roofs of houses from which the water is collected and drunk by the people who live there? Can we continue a situation in which there is only very small printing on cans and containers and people perhaps using more herbicide in the belief that more is better, as is often the way when people are using insecticides and substances of that kind?

In the time I have been in the Senate I have asked four times-I believe I am a patient man; I am getting more patient as time goes on-for a public inquiry into the effects of 2,4,5-T. I feel that the study of the effects of agent orange is finally getting somewhere, and this must be applauaded. However, agent orange did have a much higher TCDD content than commercially used 2,4,5-T, and it is recognised that its effects must be different. This must be considered in any kind of inquiry. We must study the effects of commercially used 2,4,5-T on both the human system and the environment in the long term. There are prospects that we may do this soon. The Australian Democrats welcome and applaud that, and we believe that the Australian society will do so as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate deplores the victimisation of and discrimination against the single unemployed by the Fraser Government, which has rejected their rights to benefits in line with all other pensions and benefits.

I direct my remarks to item 11 standing in my name on the Notice Paper. I can assure the Senate that I am not one who transgresses Standing Order No. 407. The text of the motion is that we express our concern at the victimisation of the single unemployed in relation to the compilation of various social security payments. It is not the practice of the Australian Labor Party to make a broad statement and not back it up with factual material. I simply say that the Government is unable to escape criticism of this nature. To understand why, we have to go back a long way into the corridors of time to the action of the Liberal-National Country Party Government in the 1950s when it jettisoned the concept of a social security levy which was originated by the Chifley Government. We might argue about various ideas of social security structure, but whatever the type of government in Europe-apart from the United Kingdom-the idea of providing, in a levy concept, for a rainy day was always accepted. People ask what the Australian Labor Party Government of 1972 did. In relation to Medibank payments it attempted to provide for the people under the same levy system, which this Senate rejected. We hear that the single unemployed are different from others. The fact is that people on this earth, particularly in Australia, do not always find themselves with the backstop of a viable family. Secondly, it is obvious that in a country the size of Australia people in search of work have to indulge in a fair amount of travel across the continent. Finally, it is quite obvious one does not purchase commodities or pay rent according to whether rebates apply.

I simply say that we put this matter on the Notice Paper because we think that the Government should face up to the fact that Australia should have a broad and stable social security system which provides constant reimbursement. I remind the Senate of the opportunities that have been lost. The Menzies Government in 1939 instituted a massive inquiry into insurance. Even in Germany in the time of Bismarck, this whole idea of national insurance was accepted and was followed by other countries. A national insurance system was established in Britain. In Australia, a succession of governments from, I suppose, 1910 onwards accepted the idea that such a system should be paid for by a slice out of revenue. However, other factors intrude on the Budget structure and such expenditure must be whittled back. In 1939, a massive inquiry into the national insurance system was undertaken. This inquiry envisaged a contribution of one shilling and three pence from the employee, one shilling and three pence from the employer and one shilling and three pence from the State. Of course, when the war clouds gathered, the Menzies Government decided that this research was to be wasted, and nothing happened.

In the post-war years when work neglected during the war was being undertaken, Australia had a substantial high wage income work force. This was the time when a massive amount of money could have been set aside in a Budget for the purpose of a national insurance scheme. Of course, the Chifley Government was in office during 1948-49. In the early 1950s, Fadden was Treasurer. Although he is regarded as a master Treasurer, I would call him a man of little faith. Instead of showing some foresight he simply scratched and wiped off this welfare fund concept. That is an attitude that, having inherited, we have enshrined ever since.

I, in common with some other senators, during the last non-sitting week met some people at big Community Youth Support Scheme demonstrations. I talked to people at those demonstrations. I said to one boy: 'Look, maybe there is a heavy concentration of unemployment in the western suburbs of Sydney. Why don't you go out into certain areas where there is seasonal work?' The plain fact is that such a person would go to a strange town where he was unknown. He would have to get accommodation. I can assure honourable senators that such a single person would find that he would pay more for board and lodgings than he would at his home in metropolitan Sydney or metropolitan Melbourne. I do not know what the Government had in mind in relation to compliance with the wishes of the Treasury in relation to the Budget. I suppose the redoubtable Mr Stone of the Treasury is like Fouche during the French Revolution, the sinister influence behind the scenes. Of course, everyone cannot be like Mr Stone who early in his life gained a lucrative Commonwealth Government job.

We can talk about the militancy of the unemployed. This action is one situation in which the Government puts the economic boot in and draws distinctions. Our idea in using this parliamentary device was to put on record our belief that the Government's policies simply compound the misfortune and the destitution of many Australians under 25 years of age.

The Government talks about manuals which deal with job attributes, about applicants looking well groomed and all the rest of it. The Government complains about people fronting up for a job interview wearing thongs and so on. I put it to the Senate that, if the Government is to cut back an unemployment person's income, the money that that person has will be spent on food and board, and clothing will come a bad third.

The Government, in all the inquiries it has had on social security, has never faced up to or admitted the mistakes that were made by the then member for Darling Downs, Fadden, in the 1950s who used a simple device to achieve a balanced or nearly balanced Budget. He turned the tap off, as it were, in respect of building up reserves for a national welfare fund. There is nothing revolutionary about such a fund. It is not a question about which party happened to be in power in Canberra but surely in the boom years funds for this concept could have been accumulated.

I speak with some feeling on this matter. It is regrettable that Australia does not have such a fund. I know that John Wheeldon, who was a very fine Minister in this chamber, tried to establish a national compensation scheme. Unfortunately, a number of little minded Australians were against it. I am fairly broad in my criticism of those who objected to the scheme. We struck objections from some sections of the Labor movement which were fearful of the scheme. Insurance companies and other professional groups also objected. I know that I am diverting a little from the subject of the victimisation of the unemployed. However, I draw the attention of the Senate to a series of articles in the Sydney Morning Herald about the pitfalls or obstacles in our compensation law. How much better off we would be if we had a national system such as that which operates in New Zealand?

The motion before the Senate was put on the Notice Paper some time ago. All the fears that we had were manifested in the last few weeks in the capital cities when we mingled with and spoke to teenage demonstrators who were rightly concerned about what was happening. On top of this, Neil Brown, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, today bravely said that in his eyes the CYSS scheme is overboard-that is it. I have made a plea tonight about victimisation. However, somewhere tucked away in Neil Brown's latest statement is a small paragraph which relates to the questions I asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The Minister told me about the alternative youth training schemes. She said that counsellors will go out and have a look at a person to see whether he can fit into such a scheme. But we argue that there will not be an all-embracing absorption of these people into training schemes. What is going to happen to the thousands of people who will not make it, who will not be absorbed into the schemes? My motion condemns the Government for making a distinction between single and married people. The Government is urging single people to go to other States where it claims there will be greater employment opportunities. There may be industrial trends but the Government is certainly not making it easier for these people. In deference to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I have kept my speech strictly within the confines of Standing Order 407 and I hope my eloquence gets a response from the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what dates in 1979-80, 1980-81 and 1981-82 did the Commonwealth Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government Employment meet.
(2) What working papers have been produced.
(3) What codes of practice have been established.
(4) What other matters have been considered.
(5) Which Commonwealth department will supervise the occupational safety and health standards in the Commonwealth Government and non-Government areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government employment met on 14th November 1979, and 9th December 1980. It had not met during 1981-82 and the Review of Commonwealth Functions' decision announced 30th April 1981 abolished the Committee. Since September 1974 when the Government adopted the Code of General Principles it was the Committee's practice to meet annually to consider submissions from its working party and any other business. The working party comprised members of the main Committee, representatives of other departments and statutory authorities and the Standards Association of Australia. The working party met six times during 1979-80 and four times during 1980-81.

(2) Working papers produced were agenda and progress reports from the working party, together with codes of practice for approval and recommendation to the Minister for his endorsement, publication and distribution. In addition reports were tabled on the future work program of the working party, procedures for consultation and preparation of joint occupational safety and health codes of practice, information papers on accidents statistics, Standards Association codes, departmental publications and updated occupational health guides from the National Health and Medical Research Council. At working party meetings the papers produced related to draft codes of practice in various stages of preparation, together with suggested amendments (reflecting comments from users) to those codes of practice already approved and distributed with the Minister's approval.

(3) Thirty seven codes of practice have been established and approved by the Minister-titles as per the attached list. A further four are awaiting Ministerial approval pending the outcome of the RCF review.

(4) Other matters considered by the Committee included reports on legislation/regulations by the representative of the State Departments of Labour and Industry, discussions of the results of a questionnaire concerning the implementation of the Code of General Principles and whether there should be mandatory observation of the codes of practice. Consideration was also given to present and future procedures to secure wider implementation of the Codes, overseas trends in occupational safety and health legislation, the attitudes of management and unions to safety matters, causes of accidents, accident costs and loss control and risk management. Members of the Committee and the working party also reported on progess within individual departments and statutory authorities on particular safety measures and occupational health developments.

(5) Subject to the outcome of the review to scale down the function of the Industrial (Physical) Working Environment Division (RCF decision 30th April 1981) any residual activities will be transferred to the Department of Industrial Relations. The supervision of occupational safety and health standards rests with the respective State governments in non-government areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981, (Hansard, page 3019) Senator Chipp asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the advertising of cigarettes.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

There appear to be two surveys bearing on whether cigarette brand names containing terms such as 'mild' and 'extra mild' lead people to believe they are smoking low-tar cigarettes. In a complaint last year to the Trade Practices Commission the Movement Opposed to the Promotion of Unhealthy Products (MOP UP) referred to a survey of 100 shoppers which indicated that 60 per cent of respondents believed that the word 'mild', used in reference to cigarettes, meant 'low tar and/or nicotine'. MOP UP also claimed to hold copies of letters in which one manufacturer claimed to be aiming promotions specifically at the low-tar buying market. However, as the survey methods and results do not appear to have been published, and the letters referred to have not been produced, no great weight can be attached to MOP UP's claims.

The second survey was a public-opinion poll, commissioned by the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, in which the brands smoked by smokers who believed they had changed to low-tar brands were investigated. Eighty-two per cent of these smokers were found to be smoking brands with tar yields of 11mg or more.
I accept that the findings demonstrate that many smokers who believe they are smoking low tar cigarettes are not doing so.

The Government has accepted that smoking at any level is harmful to health. The findings of the Anti-Cancer Council's opinion poll provide further justification for the Government's announced response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare: 'Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society?', and strengthen the case for smokers to be able to make an informed choice, based on medical assessment that smoking lower-yielding brands is not as harmful as smoking higher-yielding brands.

Consultations with the tobacco industry are proceeding concerning implementation of plans for the printing of tar and nicotine yields on cigarette packets, the establishment of upper limits for tar and nicotine yields of cigarettes, and their progressive reduction over time.

These consultations with industry, involving detailed consideration of a number of complex issues, are necessarily lengthy. Proposals for implementation will be submitted to me for consideration as soon as possible following completion of the consultations.
